Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative:
My rights, as protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2 ( b ), have been blatantly disregarded, leading to significant personal and financial distress. 

Despite my repeated attempts to rectify these inaccuracies, including direct communication and provision of evidence to your the credit reporting agencies, the wrongful information persists. Under the FCRA, you are obligated to conduct a thorough and reasonable investigation of disputed information upon receipt of a consumers dispute. Failure to do so, as evidenced in my case, is a direct violation of 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( a ). 

I have never knowingly entered into any agreement or contract with Navient or XXXX, nor with any entities they claim to represent. The documentation provided by Navient in response to my request for proof of debt was grossly inaccurate, containing personal information and a name not attributable to me. This is a clear violation of 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ), which requires credit reporting agencies to follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. 

Moreover, XXXX has completely neglected to respond to my requests for validation, further exacerbating the issue. This non-compliance is an infringement of my rights under the FCRA and demonstrates a lack of due diligence required by law. 

The ongoing misreporting of my credit history has led to significant financial loss, reputational damage, and emotional distress. This situation is further compounded by the fact that I have been a victim of identity theft, a circumstance that has been aggravated by the widely reported XXXX data breach. Despite providing substantial evidence to support my claims of identity theft, as required under 15 U.S. Code 1681c-2, my documentation has been repeatedly overlooked for 2+ years now. I have compiled multiple certified green receipts between these companies showing proof that I have repeatedly mailed via USPS documentation proving these accounts to be inaccurate, incomplete and not mine yet Navient and XXXX continue to willfully report this false information on my CONSUMER file. 

To date, the resolution of disputes I filed, most recently on XX/XX/, has been grossly mishandled. Notices from XXXX, for instance, declare the account in question as certified by Navient and XXXX without providing requisite proof. This approach not only contravenes the FCRA stipulations for accuracy and verification but also my rights under the Consumer Credit Protection Act ( CCPA ), which emphasizes fair and respectful treatment of consumers in the credit marketplace. 

The negligence exhibited by your organizations in handling my credit information is a clear violation of the FCRA, particularly sections pertaining to the accuracy and integrity of credit reporting ( 15 U.S. Code 1681e and 1681i ). This negligence has cost me time, money, and a significant detriment to my financial reputation and enjoyment of life. 

Consequently, I demand the immediate and complete removal of all false information from my consumer file pertaining to the alleged accounts. Should this issue not be resolved promptly and satisfactorily, I am prepared to escalate this matter by filing formal complaints with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ), the XXXX XXXX XXXX, the federal Bureau of Investigation, ( FBI ) and pursue legal action in the appropriate civil courts. 

I expect a written response confirming the rectification of these inaccuracies and a detailed report of your investigation findings, sent to me via the United States Postal Service, as a matter of urgency and legal compliance. 

Once again, I do not, nor have I ever had a loan or a contract with Navient or XXXX and am requesting a copy of the original contract in question, signature and ID used to verify the identity of the individual Navient and XXXX claim owe them. I demand a copy of the alleged contract with my signature on it the displays my information, signature and ID and if no such contract can be produced, I demand that these fraudulent accounts be removed from my CONSUMER file immediately.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing this to ask for full discharge of all of my student loans that were previously managed under Navient. Navient has crossed the line with their misrepresentation of how a loan company should act towards their customers, their deceptive practices, and failure to provide their previous and current customers proper guidance regarding loan repayment. 

Navient has misled me by not giving me the adequate information regarding the income- driven repayment plan. The customer service agent on the other end of the phone calls that were supposed to be experience in their job never informed me of all the different options that were available for me at the time of my multiple calls to get the best relief inorder to start my repayment. I was repeatedly offered to go back into forbearance. If I had known all my available options at the time, especially more about non-profit forgiveness I would not be writing this letter. I definitely was not aware that I needed to annually recertify my enrollment. 

Navients conduct has caused financial harm, sleepless nights worrying about how I can afford to pay back these student loans, especially when they are unwilling to work with you. Yes, I XXXX, and I thank XXXX allowed me to finish, but the amount of my student loan, and with the interest topped on it very difficult to be able to afford. At the end of the day, I relied on Navients guidance when I trusted them to provide me advice. This misconduct has caused me financial burden in more ways than one, and I ask that my Navient loans be fully forgiven. 

Thank you for considering my request. I hope that CFPB will take action and hold Navient accountable for these actions and provide borrowers with a fair resolution.

Once the program moves through the XXXX XXXX, we expect to fully launch the program to all interested and qualified borrowers some time in the next few months. Because of your expressed interest in this program, you will be notified once it has been fully implemented. We apologize for the delay in our response. 
XX/XX/XXXX : I filed a complaint with the CFPB due to being denied an application XX/XX/XXXX : I received a generic response from Navient via XXXX XX/XX/XXXX : I received a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX via my Navient account inbox XX/XX/XXXX : I sent a completed app of XXXX pages, which included evidence to support my school misconduct claims, including numerous reports of known widespread wrongdoing and lawsuits against my school, XXXX XXXX XXXX, and its parent company, XXXX, along with documentation to show a long-standing pattern of financial hardship repaying my loans for close to 20 years. 
XX/XX/XXXX : I was notified via XXXX that my application was received XX/XX/XXXX : I received formal notice via my Navient account inbox that my application had been received and that they needed up to 60 days to review it. 
XX/XX/XXXX : I received a XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX denial letter via my Navient account inbox that provided no reason for my denial, only saying, We have completed a review of your application and have determined your applicable private student loans are not eligible for discharge due to the following reason ( XXXX ) : Navient carefully considers a variety of factors in determining whether a private loan should be discharged based on school misconduct and you do not meet the requirements for discharge based on misconduct by your school.

Of the original {$26000.00} loans taken out to fund my education, I repaid {$29000.00}. A refund of only {$410.00} for a fraudulent education is a slap in the face. It's on record that Navient was aware of the misconduct on the part of my school based on its parent company, XXXX XXXX XXXX 's ( XXXX ) inclusion in the XXXX XXXX XXXX, which lists XXXX on page XXXX of Appendix A of the final judgement. Between the XX/XX/XXXX settlement date and XX/XX/XXXX, I continued to pay a total of {$10000.00} and, at the very least, should have received a refund for that amount, given that there were no opportunities available to apply for any school misconduct and failing to repay would seriously affect my credit. Yet again, I was taken advantage of. A full refund for the {$29000.00} spent on an education program that provided no value and led to extensive debt and XXXX  and emotional anguish should be the expectation.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint against Navient for their deceptive practices, misrepresentation, and failure to provide accurate information regarding my student loan repayment options. As a borrower, I have experienced significant financial harm due to their actions. 

Navient misled me by steering me away from income-driven repayment plans, which would have made my payments more affordable. Instead, I have been making payments that primarily go toward interest, causing my overall loan balance to increase substantially. This has resulted in a ballooning of my debt, which far exceeds what I originally borrowed. 

Furthermore, Navient has repeatedly misreported my payment status to credit reporting agencies, which has severely damaged my credit score. The misinformation provided by their representatives has delayed my ability to pursue more favorable repayment options, contributing to an overwhelming amount of accrued debt.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Navient violated the Consumer Financial Protection Act, the Fair Credit Reporting Act, and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In addition to its unlawful steering activities, the CFPB alleges Navient harmed student loan borrowers by : Misleading myself and my mother who is the co signer about income-driven repayment plans : Navient failed to adequately notify borrowers who enrolled in income-driven repayment plans about the requirement to annually recertify their enrollment. 
My loans have had varying interest rates and monthly payments. 

I was told my mom could be released which was a lie. I was deceived about Navients requirements for cosigner release : Navient made representations to private loan borrowers that if they paid down their loans in a certain way, they could apply for their cosigners to be released. But Navient did not honor those representations for some borrowers.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom it May Concern : This is concerning my private student loan disbursed by Sallie Mae that spit into ( 2 ) companies known as Navient corporation. It has recently come to my attention that there are multiple lawsuits concerning Navient Corporation, a nonbank that owns and services student loans. The Bureau alleges that Navient Solutions and Navient Corporation engaged in abusive and unfair acts and practices in violation of the Consumer Financial Protection Act of XXXX ( XXXX ) by steering borrowers experiencing long-term financial hardship into forbearance, a costly option designed for borrowers experiencing short-term financial hardship, instead of adequately advising them about more beneficial income-driven repayment plans. 

I attended XXXX back in XXXX - XXXX and Im still paying on my loan as of today. The original loan amount was just shy of XXXX. My mother took out a loan and I signed one for myself at the age of XXXX to attend a trade school named XXXX XXXX XXXX located in XXXX XXXX. Ive been paying on the loan for quite some time until I ran into a long-term financial hardship due to a XXXX XXXX XXXX  I called Navient to see what could be done and they suggested that do a forbearance instead of offering me another low-cost program that would be cost efficient and conducive to my overall financial situation. This original loan of {$9000.00} is now at {$14000.00} and still accruing interest at an alarming rate! 

The Bureau also alleges that Pioneer and Navient Corporation engaged in deceptive acts and practices in violation of the CFPA and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act by misleading borrowers about the effect of loan rehabilitation on their credit reports and the collection fees that would be forgiven in the federal loan rehabilitation program. On XX/XX/XXXX, Navient moved to dismiss the complaint, which the court denied on XX/XX/XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX, Navient filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings, which the court denied on XX/XX/XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX, the Bureau filed a proposed stipulated judgment and order, which if entered by the court, would require defendants to pay {$100.00} million in consumer redress and a {$20.00} XXXX penalty. The order would also, among other requirements, permanently ban Navient from servicing Direct Loans, prohibit Navient from conducting consumer-facing servicing activities for Federal Family Education Loan Program ( FFELP ) loans, and permanently ban Navient from acquiring additional FFELP loans. 

Due to the negligence and deceptive practices from this company thats been banned to even servicing loans, I ask that this account be removed as a courtesy and compensation for being misleading and causing a colossal financial disaster in my family. I tried to log into my Navient account today and it allowed me to retrieve my user name and a temporary password but when I attempted multiple times to login, the website stated that there was no account found! This is very frustrating on my behalf and unprofessional and negligent on the businesses end. 

Thanks, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Illinois XXXX To Whom It May Concern, I am writing regarding my XXXX XXXX XXXX, which was cited for unfair lending practices in XXXX by Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. I have disputed my student loan balance for many years, and to date my loan is still {$18000.00} and taxed at 8.5 % interest. 

I started college in XX/XX/XXXX and at the time I received Pell Grants to fund my education. Additionally, I served in the military for 16 years ( Army Veteran ) and the Department of Defense paid {$20000.00} via my GI XXXX XXXX towards my student loans. 
I started college at XXXX XXXX XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX and at that time I believe I was awarded a XXXX XXXX to fund my education cost. 
After leaving XXXX XXXX, I attended XXXX XXXX XXXX, a local junior college for XXXX years and transferred to XXXX XXXX XXXX. After one year, I transferred to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) in XXXX, earned my Bachelor of Science Degree and graduated in XXXX. 

Between XXXX, a personal banker at XXXX convinced XXXX to consolidate all my student loans into XXXX loan. At the time I was young and naive, and I did not understand the ramifications of this financial arrangement and certainly did not know that this debt would morph into a massive balance due to high interest. 

The interest rate has never fallen below 8 % and I have been struggling to pay this loan off for many years. I am now XXXX XXXX XXXX and 90 % service-connected XXXX per VA and I would like to have my loan reviewed for accuracy and request loan forgiveness due to all the mismanagement, massive fees, high interest rates and late fees. 

Most of the loans that I consolidated were federal direct subsidized or unsubsidized loans that are now consolidated into a variable rate private loan. 
Additionally, XXXX is one of the schools accused by the Federal Trade Commission of misrepresenting its job and salary outcomes through ads. The university also settled with the Education Department and borrowers. 

I have never been able to write off payments on my tax refund, I have been charged late fees and massive interest and many other issues with XXXX loan which is now served by Navient student loan. To date, I still owe {$17000.00} on my loan despite many payments, consolidations, and the Department of Defense payment due to the high interest rate and constantly transferring my loan from one servicer to another. Its as if the Department of Defense payment were never made. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX  XXXX Attended XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

I contacted Navient on XX/XX/XXXX about my my student loan payment and my IBR. I was told at that time the payment of XXXX could not be stopped because it was already being processed. I then submitted a W-2 on XX/XX/XXXX did not find out that it was not viewed as enough information by logging in XX/XX/XXXX. Upon which I resubmitted a W-2 on that day. I then called on XX/XX/XXXX and they were closed due to XXXX XXXX. 

I called on XX/XX/XXXX and was disconnected two times after talking to representatives. The first person I spoke to told me that they would be able to refund both payments from XXXX and XXXX and that they had all the paper work required from me. I asked could she give an estimate on what my new payment would be and then I was disconnected. I immediately called back and the next rep told me that if they refunded me the payments than I would go into default because my IBR had not been approved. Then I was told to hold and was disconnected again. Upon speaking to the third representative I was told that they couldn't refund me and that I would go into default if they did and that I had no more forbearance. She then said that the notes said that they suggested consolidation. I had spoken to know one about consolidation. She then said that she could send me information on consolidation and she could give me forbearance. However I should wait until I get approval from the IBR department before making a decision. I have received no written information about this matter from Navient just deductions from my account.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX. I was XX/XX/XXXX years old at the time and was ensured that the student loans I opened through XXXX XXXX were federally backed XXXX Loans that I was afforded as a Ward of the State. At some point the loans were transferred to Navient due to XXXX XXXX losing the right to service federal loans due to misconduct. At all points of communication, the loans were referred to as federally backed student loans. I have been a forward XXXX XXXX in the XXXX XXXX since XXXX and have not been stateside to directly deal with the loans and have been relying on online pay and communication with Navient. On XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, I received a notification from the Department of Education about Student Loan Discharge Based on XXXX XXXX XXXX. " Your loan ( XXXX ) will be XXXX based on an XXXX finding that The XXXX XXXX made pervasive and widespread substantial misrepresentations that borrowers relied on to their detriment. '' When I contacted Navient about this release from the XXXX Department of Education in regard to the loans, I was told that the loans are considered private loans that I opened with Navient. At no point have I ever opened a private loan with Navient. I was then sent an application to submit with Navient to have my loans XXXX, which I submitted on XXXX XX/XX/XXXX. 

I received an email on XXXX XX/XX/XXXX that my loans are now being transferred to XXXX. Further research into the reasoning for the transfer is that Navient was barred from financing Federal Student Loans. 

Navient denied my discharge application on XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, however, gave no reason for the denial. I then called the number listed on the letter for the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX to speak with a representative about the denial. I confirmed with the person I was speaking that their office was the ones that made the determination on the letter sent. They refused to give reasoning for the denial and refused to send a copy of the original loan documentation they received from XXXX XXXX regarding my loans. My biggest contention with this process is that my loans were " federal loans '' or " federally backed '' when it best suited them and when a federal determination to discharge the loans due to misconduct was issued, now it is solely referred to as a private loan. Every single interaction I have with them they continue to refer to the loans as if I opened the loan with them directly. 

Now, XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, even after they informed me that my loan is transferred to XXXX, they called me saying I still need to pay them for my loans.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Co-signer
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have a private student loan serviced through Navient, with a co-signer, from XXXX. Had the co-signer not been paying the loan off it would have been part of the predatory loan settlement brought by several AGs a couple years ago. 

The co-signer is my ex-step father whom has been paying the loan for over 10 years, and was told by a judge in his divorce with my mom that he is responsible for it. As a single mom, who is already in a legal fight to get paid the child support/alimony I'm owed, I am unable to make payments on this loan. He has been the only one to ever pay on this loan. Now that he is no longer married to my mom, he intentionally stopped paying the loan so that he could try to work a settlement deal with them. Despite being a XXXX. This is where I am finding it hard to understand if this is legally available for Navient, because on the promissory note it states we are both jointly & severally liable for the full amount. They told me today that they approved him for waiver based on him letting them know I can pay it, despite the tax return information I have provided. 

While I have heard of a co-signer release, I have never heard of a co-signer waiver. Navient has just approved for the co-signor to pay a percentage of the loan off to have his name removed without affecting his credit, then leaving the remaining balance solely on myself even though I have provided evidence of not being able to afford payments. Nor would I be approved for a loan without a co-signor, currently. The supervisor even made a comment to me about whether or not I knew this would affect me being able to take the bar if I dont pay it, once they remove him. Once the co-signer pays the 70 % of the current loan amount, more than double of the original loan will be paid back to Navient. Even more, they offered to settle the loan for less than what they are accepting for the co-signor waiver. 

I have searched everywhere on the internet for information regarding co-signer waiver, cant find anything. I have tried to reach out to the top executives at Navient ( CFO & Chief Legal Officer ), regarding this issue, I have requested a signed copy of the original loan agreement, and no-one will email/call me back. While I have been provided the promissory note, they will not provide me with the full signed loan agreement. I was yelled at over the phone by a case manager saying they can do it but not explaining how, legally, where it is stated in the loan agreement. I feel like this is wrong, and was hoping you could maybe point me in the right direction.

Consumer complaint narrative: We were recently discharged from a XXXX  XXXX XXXX. My Navient private student loans were part of that discharge. These are non-qualified private student loans, so they are not exempt from discharge under the bankruptcy code. They were taken out as direct consumer student loans, not certified by the school, and they were in excess of my scholarship and the federal student loans that covered by tuition. No further petition needs to be filed with the court for the discharge, according to the bankruptcy code any non-qualified private student loans are automatically discharged. I spoke with Navient about this and they ( aside from seeming to have very little knowledge about it ) just kept saying these are private loans and cant be discharged which is incorrect. I do have the paperwork from the court stating such as well but they refuse to alter my account and have put me back into repayment.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am a former XXXX XXXX XXXX student, currently experiencing wage garnishment for a private student loan originally serviced by Navient, despite having submitted a misconduct discharge form on XX/XX/XXXX. Under the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX to Repayment ( BDR ) provisions and recent actions by the XXXX XXXX, I believe my loans qualify for discharge due to XXXX XXXX documented fraud and misconduct. 

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) has issued actions and a proposed order against Navient for improperly servicing student loans and engaging in deceptive practices with XXXX XXXX students, and the Federal Trade Commissions Holder Rule also protects borrowers like me from deceptive institutional practices. Additionally, the XXXX XXXX recently approved group discharges for XXXX XXXX borrowers under XXXX Action in XXXX, addressing widespread harm to XXXX XXXX students. 

Since submitting my discharge application, I have encountered significant difficulties obtaining information about my loan status and discharge eligibility. Here is a summary of my attempts to get clarification and protection from wage garnishment : XX/XX/XXXX : I submitted a student misconduct discharge form to Navient, but despite the HEAs Borrower Defense protections, I received no response for almost 60 days. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I contacted Navient customer service to request an update on my discharge form status. The representative advised me to wait but could not provide any information on the application review or loan status. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I contacted Navient again and was informed that my loans had been transferred to XXXX for servicing, without prior notification. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I spoke with a XXXX representative, XXXX, who confirmed that my application had been received on XX/XX/XXXX and was under review for a XXXX period. When I requested a written confirmation of this review to halt the wage garnishment by XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX stated that no documentation was available and advised me to contact the XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I contacted the XXXX XXXX XXXX and spoke with XXXX XXXX, who confirmed my applications receipt but suggested contacting Navient Charge-Off Department due to the loans being in charge-off status. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I contacted Navients Charge-Off Department, but they also could not provide documentation confirming my loan 's forbearance or ongoing review. I then followed up with XXXX, who reiterated that no documentation would be provided to XXXX XXXX XXXX to halt wage garnishment. 

As an XXXX XXXX student borrower, I am eligible for discharge under the XXXX administrations XXXX group discharge approval, which specifically applies to former XXXX XXXX students affected by the institutions fraudulent practices. Additionally, the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( XXXX ) of XXXX provides the CFPB with oversight authority to address cases where servicers engage in unfair, deceptive, or abusive actssuch as Navients lack of transparency and responsiveness in processing my application and their failure to protect borrowers from further financial harm while applications are pending.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My Student Loan was initially a HEAL loan ( Health Education Assistance Loan ). It was initially managed by XXXX XXXX, now taken over by Navient. 

The Navient name and loan number are : XXXX XXXX XXXX Loan XXXX Loan type FFELP, initially HEAL I began repaying my loan in XXXX, after finishing my residency. In XXXX of XXXX, XXXX XXXX sent a document to me stating I could reduce my interest by a half percentage point by linking direct payments from my checking account to automatically pay the loan each month. Not trusting them from previous experience, I called and spoke to loan services two times prior to signing the direct deposit. I called to be assured that all this form was doing was allowing direct payment from my checking account on my existing loan, and that they would NOT call this a new disbursement and new loan, with a new 30 year payment schedule. I had already been paying on the loan for 15 years, and was finally at a point where I was paying some principal on it. I was assured, twice, that this was not the case. I signed the direct deposit form ( the only form I signed ), and they immediately issued a " New Loan '' with a new 30 year schedule of payments that will last until XXXX. 

I would have completed my payment of the loan three years ago, if XXXX XXXX had not fraudulently " signed '' my name ( a printed name not signed by me ), and " issued '' a new loan. 

I initially borrowed {$36000.00} for tuition and books. I have, to date, paid payments totaling {$150000.00}, and still " owe '' {$33000.00}. 
I have contacted Navient several times over the last five years. I was told I would need to file a " Fraud and Identity Theft '' complaint with their internal fraud department. XXXX XXXX, in the years surrounding XXXX, when this happened to me, has been found guilty of falsely extending loans with practices such as what occurred to my account. 

I have written to the XXXX XXXX, and was told I would have to take care of it with Navient. Navient is unresponsive, and says they can't forgive the remaining balance of the loan. To be honest, at this point, I don't know who to turn to. 

When XXXX XXXX " issued a new disbursement '' I demanded to see papers that showed I had " asked for a new loan ''. I had simply signed a form to have the payments made automatically from my checking account. I never received any of their " paperwork ''. 

I did, 5 years ago, find a somewhat sympathetic ear at Navient, and she was able to find the form I supposed signed for the new disbursement request. It simply had my name typed on it in the signature box. 

This is the heart of the matter with the current student loan situation. XXXX XXXX committed fraud, misrepresentation of information and documents, and identity theft in issuing a new loan that I not only did not request, but called them specifically to insure they would not call it a new disbursement. 

I would appreciate any help CFPB can provide in this situation. With the current " loan balance '', I will be making payments into my late seventies, and will have paid on the loan for 45 years. I have already made payments of nearly 5 times the amount I borrowed, and the remaining balance remains close to the initial amount of my loans. 

Thank you for your consideration and help. Please let me know if there is any other information I can provide to you to help get relief from the remaining portion of the student loan. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
XXXXXX/XX/XXXX

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I took out XXXX student loans through Navient/Sallie Mae back then with my schools guidance several years ago ( XXXX ) My school insisted they would be manageable payments and pressured me to just sign and read later. At the time they gave me the paper they asked I sign it then and there and could read the terms afterwards. As a first generation college student, I didnt realize just how for profit my institution was ( Illinois XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I took out XXXX loans in the amounts of XXXX and XXXX. The interest rate was variable. Once I graduated in XXXX, it took me a while to get finally stable so I deferred the loans as long as possible until I had to start payments. I was given a high payment rate of around {$270.00} per month ( and this is in addition to my other Sallie Mae loans. My interest rate started around 10 %. I was temporarily unemployed and was told that there were zero options for repayment since I used up my forbearance. I was given zero options and told that I either pay the listed amount of default. Those were my two options. I fell behind 3 months because I had to pay for rent with my limited income vs. my student loans. To this day I can not reconsolidate my loans due to these negative remarks for these 3 months being on my credit report. Other than those 3 month, I have paid on time and consecutively for 5+ years and my interest rate along with payment continues to soar with no options to lower either. I am now paying {$470.00} a month with interest rates of 17 and 18 %. The worst part is, on my credit report these loans are -75 % paid off. NEGATIVE 75 %. How is that even possible when a large chunk of my month income goes to the loans. I paid almost $ XXXX interest alone last year. I understand I took out the loan, I signed and I have to pay it back but this is truly fraudulent and downright terrible when I put myself through school to make a better life for myself only to have sunk myself in a hole with these student loans where the interest keeps raising, the payment keeps raising and the negative percentage I have paid off of these loans keeps getting bigger. My school closed several years ago and my government loans have been forgiven but Im still stuck with paying XXXX back in private student loans across Navient and Sallie Mae. Sallie Mae has also made my financial hardships unmanageable as well. They have also hiked the interest rate severely and offer zero options other than paying almost $ XXXX. Between Sallie Mae and Navient, my monthly payment is {$1200.00}. Both offer zero option for any type of lowered payment and state - pay or default. Those are the two options.

My Federal Student Loans have been forgiven through the Borrower Defense to Repayment, due to widespread misconduct from XXXX XXXX XXXX There have already been several settlements from Navient for widespread, unfair and deceptive student loan servicing practices and abuses in originating predatory student loans for for-profit schools, such as XXXX XXXX XXXX 

They held onto my application for 45 days before denying my application and provided me with the following reason : Navient carefully considers a variety of factors in determining whether a private loan should be discharged based on school misconduct and you do not meet the requirements for discharge based on misconduct by your school. I contacted Navient customer service for clarification per instructions on the denial and the only answer I was given was customer service doesnt know what criteria these loans applications are judged by so ( they ) cant help. 

There is no actual reason for the Denial given. This is another dishonest action from Navient to keep student loan borrowers indebted to them. There is overwhelming evidence of misconduct on behalf of both Navient and XXXX XXXX  XXXX tied to these loans.

Consumer complaint narrative: I received a loan from XXXX XXXX ( Navient ) in XXXX. The loan was for XXXX XXXX XXXX Navient has been used multiple times as a result of the actions that they have taken regarding these loans. They have been accused of payment processing errors and forbearance steering, resulting in higher fees and interest for borrowers. My loan should have been included in the original relief that was provided in XXXX with the Attorney General 's multi-state lawsuit. I was part of the original suit where each student was provided a check for an equal amount for the misrepresentation of payback options, I did receive a check from that, however when it came to for loan forgiveness due to predatory and misleading they did not include me. I contacted the Attorney General for my state and filed a complaint. In order to qualify it stated that you would have to have missed payments XXXX consecutive months. When the XXXX contacted Navient, they advised that my loan had never been in default. The information they provided is not correct. My credit report shows where I was continually reported for non payment. Navient also originated predatory subprime private loans to students attending for-profit schools even though it knew that a very high percentage of such borrowers would be unable to repay the loans. I was also advised that my Co-signer would be able to be removed from the loan, however that also has not happened. I have been paying on this loan that originated back in XXXX since that time however the loan has not decreased. In fact the loan was originally for {$4000.00} however it is now over {$8000.00}. I have been paying enough to keep it off my credit ( even though I can't afford it ) because I have worked hard to fix my credit that Navient helped to ruin. I am called multiple times a day regarding this loan and every time I have asked about trying to settle this loan, I was always denied. Every time I make a payment, the loan amount never goes down, it just seems to continually increase because the payment is going towards interest and late fees that I am steadily being charged. I feel as though my loan should have been included in the original lawsuit for forgiveness, however almost 20 years later, I am still paying on a {$4000.00} loan that is now at {$8400.00} with a 13 % interest. I just made a payment on XX/XX/XXXX of {$130.00}, however I am {$250.00} past due with a current amount due of with a current payment of {$120.00} due, and unpaid late fees of {$6.00} for a total of {$390.00} that they are currently expecting me to pay and none of it goes towards the principle, it will all be put towards interest and fees, so I am just spinning in a hamster wheel with no way to get off. They also continue to call and harass my co-signer, who they said would be able to be released from the loan.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these online for profit schools, such as XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against them.

My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the Sweet Vs. Cardona settlement for which I was a full class member.

I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit online schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW! 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

I am fully aware of the School Misconduct Discharge Pilot Program and I would like to participate in it. If you don't address this, Ill be reaching out to my state and federal legislators, and anyone else I can think of to get the ball rolling.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to file a formal complaint against The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and Navient ( formerly Sallie Mae ) regarding the deceptive practices I experienced as a student and the subsequent denial of my application for a discharge of my private student loans. 

Background : I attended The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX to XXXX. During my enrollment, I was pressured to take private loans in order to secure my place in the program. The admissions staff misled students about job placement rates and expected salaries after graduation, creating a false impression that our degrees would ensure employment and financial success. 

Issues Faced : Deceptive Practices : The school provided misleading information regarding the job market, including inflated job placement rates and salary expectations. 
Financial Burden : Although federal loans have been forgiven due to the school 's fraudulent practices, my private loans remain a significant burden. The interest rates on these loans are exorbitant, and I have been unable to secure work in my field that pays enough to cover these payments. 
Denial of Loan Discharge : I applied to Navient for a discharge of my private loans based on the schools misconduct. My application was denied without any clear explanation, despite my understanding that other students with similar circumstances have been approved. When I contacted Navient for clarification, representatives were unable to provide a reason for the denial. 
This situation has left me in a precarious financial position, struggling to manage the loans that I was misled into taking. 

Request for Action : I urge the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to investigate the practices of The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and the handling of my loan discharge application by Navient. It is crucial that students are protected from deceptive practices that lead to insurmountable debt. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I appreciate your assistance and look forward to your response.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Complaint Regarding Denial of Student Loan Misconduct Discharge Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Complaint Team, I am writing to formally file a complaint concerning the improper handling and denial of my student loan misconduct discharge application by Navient Solutions , LLC, the original loan servicer, and XXXX, the current servicer of my loan. Despite providing substantial evidence of institutional misconduct, my application has been denied twice without clear or justifiable reasoning. 

Loan Information : Loan Account Number : XXXX Application Reference Number : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX First Denial Date : XX/XX/XXXX ( Navient ) Second Denial Date : XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX ) Background : I am a former XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX of XXXX XXXX, which has been the subject of multiple legal actions for fraudulent and predatory practices. The institution misled students about job placement rates, career outcomes, and the overall value of the education providedpractices that have been legally recognized. 

In XXXX, the parent company, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ), reached a {$95.00} XXXX settlement with the XXXX Department over illegal recruiting tactics. 

Following widespread acknowledgment of these deceptive practices, the U.S. Department of Education approved over {$6.00} XXXX in student loan forgiveness for former XXXX XXXX students, including those who attended the XXXX XXXX campus between XXXX and XXXX. 

Despite these clear findings, Navient, as the original loan servicer, denied my school misconduct discharge application without justification. XXXX, now servicing my loan, appears to have adopted Navients decision without conducting an independent or thorough review of the evidence I submitted.

Under the FTC Holder Rule, I am entitled to assert defenses against loan holders when institutional misconduct occurs. Given the legal precedents set against The XXXX XXXX and Navients role in facilitating these loans, I believe Navients initial denial was both insufficient and improper. XXXX  reliance on that flawed decision perpetuates this failure. 

Concerns : Primary Investigation Failure : Navients denial raises serious concerns about the integrity of its review process. XXXX  subsequent reliance on that decision is inadequate. 

Lack of Transparency : Neither Navient nor XXXX has provided specific reasons for the denials, preventing me from addressing any perceived shortcomings. 

Failure to Address Evidence : The substantial evidence I provided demonstrates institutional misconduct. The repeated denials suggest that my case has been ignored or inadequately reviewed. 

Requested Actions : Investigate Navients Role : I request that the CFPB conduct a full investigation into Navients handling of my school misconduct discharge application, including its review process and compliance with borrower protections. 

Require XXXX to Conduct a Fair Review : Direct XXXX to independently review my case without relying on Navients flawed decision. 

Provide a Clear Explanation : Issue a detailed explanation of the denial, including specific reasons and any additional steps I may take to appeal.

The continued denial of my rightful discharge has caused me significant financial and emotional hardship. I respectfully urge the CFPB to investigate Navients mishandling of my case and ensure that XXXX fulfills its obligation to fairly review borrower claims in compliance with federal protections.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am currently paying 2 loans. 
My Student Signature loan has a current balance of {$28000.00} and 10.5 % interest. The loan was disbursed almost 20 years ago on XX/XX/XXXXXXXX The original principal was {$22000.00}, and the total accrued interest is {$38000.00}. 
My other loan ( Tuition Answer ) has a current balance of {$8400.00} and 11 % interest. The disbursement date was on XX/XX/XXXX. The original principal was {$11000.00}, and total interest accrued is {$15000.00}. It has been about 20 years, and I owe more than the original loans ( and the amount of interest accrued on both loans are more than the actual loans ). The original lender was Sallie Mae ( now Navient ), and another company is soon to take over. They have been sued for various reasons including misleading borrowers, overcharging, etc. I myself have been steered into forebearance numerous times. I feel like I am a victim with never ending unfair payments, and I should have been part of the loan forgiveness.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative: I went to the LA location, which closed down shortly after I graduated. This school has been found guilty of fraud in the XXXX XXXX  XXXX case and my federal loans will be forgiven due to their recruiting tactics, promises of job placement, etc. I graduated right before the recession of XXXX and was never given any follow ups or assistance with finding a job or help with my student loans. Ive tried to file forbearances on my private loans to no avail, as they arent allowed. The interest on these loans is so great that Ive now paid over the original amount of my loan 3 fold. Ive requested for them to provide totals and they only list out the payments Ive made indvidually, with no total at the bottom line. I was also unaware that my public loans would be commercially held, therefore XXXX no longer able to get reimbursed like some of the others will in the settlement. I was never informed why I needed public and private loans either. Ive been paying this loan since XXXX and Id love to see the remaining balance wiped off and my credit restored. In XXXX, I filed for bankruptcy due to the total amount of my student loan debt with compounding interest. In my opinion, I couldnt keep those plus the credit card debt I had racked up from trying to survive during the recession, so I filed. Id do anything to eliminate my student loans. And being reimbursed for an education that was subpar from the community college I had attended prior would be ideal.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Attended the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX. Received both federal and private loans. Loans originated from Sallie Mae but are now serviced by Navient.

My federal loans will be forgiven under Borrower Defense to Repayment under the XXXX XXXX XXXX settlement. The Department of Education has admitted that fraud exist, along with countless lawsuits from State Attorney Generals, and the Department of Justice investigations/lawsuit into XXXX, who was the parent company of XXXX at the time I attended school. The DOJ investigation found that XXXX had a boiler-room style sales culture in which recruiters were instructed to use high-pressure sales techniques and inflated claims about career placement to increase student enrollment, regardless of the applicants qualifications. 

These loans were the direct result of fraud, misrepresentation and deceit including, but not limited to, false claims about career placement, false claims regarding job placement statistics, predatory and high-pressure sales tactics, misrepresentations about the cost of a degree, and misrepresentations about the value of a degree from the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

Navient is obligated to cancel these private student loan because of the Holder Rule, which makes all current " holders '' of an initial loan responsible for any fraudulent misrepresentations made in the selling of the product. The FTC has stated that student loans are within the scope of the Holder Rule. The Department of Education also has regulations applying principles similar to the Holder Rule to many federal student loans. For private loans, the borrower may be able to cancel existing debt if a school fraudulently induced the student to enroll and had some relationship with the lender. It's important to note, that XXXX was the guarantor for one of my private loans at this college. 

The CFPB also found that lenders are misleading some borrowers and keeping them in repayment for debt they do not owe. The CFPB found that lenders ignored consumers claims that the FTC XXXX XXXX allow private borrowers to bring a claim against their school to their lender.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: I have XXXX student loans outstanding with a current balance outstanding of {$12000.00}. The servicer is Navient. The loans have interest of 4.3 % and Im set up for monthly auto pay. I have been paying {$140.00} monthly. I paid off {$2000.00} in a XX/XX/XXXX. I called Navient multiple times asking them to recalculate the monthly payment because I paid off a portion of the principal and interest accrues on the remaining principal balance. Since I paid off {$2000.00} and I reduced my principal balance, they should be reducing the monthly payment amount accordingly. Navient is refusing to recalculate and lower the monthly payment. The loans are all in an Extended Repayment - Level/Fixed plan and their scheduled payoff isnt until XXXX. Navients practice of continuing to bill me the same monthly amount and by planning to continue to do so until XXXX clearly violates how basic loan amortization works and are defrauding me as a consumer. They also make it really hard to contact. I contacted them 3 times in XXXX and every time I was on hold for more than 1 hour. The Navient rep who answered was eager to get off the phone and was quick to tell me they cant make any changes to the monthly payment. Even when I spoke to a supervisor, they wouldnt even listen to my explanation. I attached a screenshot showing the amount I paid off in XX/XX/XXXX and how the monthly payment is still the same. The loans were issued in XXXX and XXXX and I have been paying off monthly since XX/XX/XXXX without missing a single payment.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have 3 private student loans with Navient. Back in XXXX they were put into in school deferment status without my consent. When I re-entered school at least half-time, in XX/XX/XXXX, I checked Navients website to find out if I needed to do anything to prevent my loans from going into deferment, as I didnt want this to occur. The following is what I found : 1. On their Help center, Common Questions page there are two sections that speak about deferments. Both are under the Apply for section. The first, is A Deferment, the second, is An In-School Deferment. Under both sections it says for private loans that you must contact them at XXXX to see what options your loan is eligible for. 
2. In both of those sections the last line is a hyperlink ( one for private and one for federal loans ) where you can find out about deferments. I selected the private loan link. It brings me to a new page about private loan payments. On this page, if you select Deferment it tells you that to apply you must Complete a deferment request form and return it to us. There is no unique section for in-school deferment in this situation. However, the information in the introductory paragraph as well as the description of types of deferments both show in-school as a type of deferment so this information must apply to that type too. 

After that research I determined that there was nothing I needed to do because I did not want a deferment and their website indicated I would have to apply for an in-school deferment if I wanted it. 

I periodically check my account with Navient about every 2 months. Every time I would log in my payment would show {$0.00} owed. This is typical. When you select the i icon next to the payment amount it states that your payment amount will show as {$0.00} when you are enrolled in autopay. I have been in autopay for years now so this explanation made sense and aligns with what I expected my account to show during a normal payment period. 

On Wednesday, XX/XX/XXXX when I checked my account I noticed the total balance on my loan did not align with what I expected. I looked further and realized my payments had not been taken out. I also realized that Navient capitalized interest on XX/XX/XXXX in the amount of {$220.00}. I immediately knew something was wrong and started searching my entire account and it was only after drilling into the specific details of the loan discovered by drilling far into my loan details that my loan status was in-school deferment on my 3 loans. I called Navient. I spoke to a representative, XXXX, and asked for a supervisor immediately because I knew this was beyond the practices of the front-line workers. 

The supervisor confirmed my account was in an in-school deferment status. She stated that in-school deferments were automatic. I advised her that this is contrary to everything on their website and detailed the locations where I had received all of the information ( as Ive listed above in this statement ). She reiterated it was automatic and that I should know that my status was in-school deferment because I was notified based on my monthly statements. I informed the supervisor that this was not the case. Statements do not have the loan status on them and that I actually do not ever get notified by Navient that my statements are ready, I just have to know to log into Navient, despite getting refinancing email offers from them on almost a daily basis. ( Unsurprisingly, on Friday, XX/XX/XXXX after this call to Navient, I received the first email in years notifying me a statement was available in my Navient account ). However, as I informed the supervisor, not a single section on the statement shows my loan is in a deferment status. Therefore, the information the supervisor was providing me was false. I also let her know that I have no specific documents in my Navient inbox ever telling me the status was changed as is customary on federal loans. 

I again asked how I was to know that this occurred. She only could tell me it was automatic even though there is no indication that this is proper practice for private loans based on their website. I told her that I find this to be deceptive loan practices and that I feel Navient is telling borrowers one thing while doing another that is more favorable for their income generation. I let her know the resolution I wanted was : 1. The {$220.00} of interest that was capitalized in XXXX was to be uncapitalized. 
XXXX. The interest that has accrued on the {$220.00} since XXXX should be credited back to my account. 
XXXX. My loan should be removed immediately from an in-school deferment status effective XX/XX/XXXX. 

She said she could not do the second one but could do the first and third. I still do not believe this is satisfactory but accepted as the first and third were the immediate concerns. 

She did not offer any information about when I would need to repay the interest or how quickly this would occur. I had to prompt for all of this information. She stated it would take about 2 weeks ( 10 business days ) to process and then I would get a letter in the mail letting me know it was completed. I asked how quickly I needed to repay the uncapitalized interest ( {$220.00} ). She stated I should do it as soon as possible because that payment will be considered delinquent. Although flabbergasted that they could call my account delinquent immediately upon rectifying their error I notified her I would check my online account in 1 week and make the payment on the uncapitalized interest immediately and then would expect to have my normal payments come out. We then ended the call. 

On Sunday, my cosigner ( mother ) received a voicemail from Navient that I was delinquent and about to enter default. I also received a call from a California number but was not left a message and assumed it was spam. Today, Monday XX/XX/XXXX I received a call from Navient and this time they left a message. The message was from XXXX XXXX. She let me know Im delinquent in the amount of {$560.00} on 2 loans. She said I have until Friday to clear the account, or it will be charged off to collections. 

There are a number issues here : 1. I have 3 loans. They have only fixed 2 and fixed is not the correct term. 
XXXX. The supervisor on Wednesday confirmed I would just need to make the payment for the uncapitalized interest ( {$220.00} ) not all of the payments since XX/XX/XXXX that Navient hadnt taken out due to their error putting my account in deferment. 
XXXX. I again was never provided any notice that I owed any money at this time. On Friday, XX/XX/XXXX I received a statement in my Navient inbox. However, that statement again shows I do not owe any money. Although that may have occurred prior to fixing the account I still have not received any communication from Navient other than a phone call threatening me with default in less than 5 days that there has been any changes to my account. 
XXXX. Navient is calling my account delinquent when I have not had any payments owed to them for 9 months. When I spoke to the supervisor, I did not ask for my deferment to be reversed through XX/XX/XXXX. I asked for it to be terminated effective XX/XX/XXXX. I am now again being penalized for Navients errors and deceptive practices. My account was in deferment status until sometime between Thursday and today ( Monday ). They are now also telling me they will be reporting this to the credit bureaus as delinquent. This is COMPLETELY unacceptable and false information. 

This entire situation stems from Navients actions violating the information they are providing to borrowers. Nothing on their website says my loan should have gone into deferment. When I notified them of this, instead of fixing the error by updating my status to remove the deferment effective immediately, uncapitalize the interest, and credit the interest accrued while that {$220.00} was capitalized, Navient instead back dated my repayment status to XXXX, called me delinquent on my loan, threatened default, required on 9 months of payments for 2 loans, and still left one loan in an in-school deferment. 

When I spoke to XXXX XXXX today, she said a supervisor will call me tomorrow. I then made the {$560.00} and she said they will for sure call me now by Saturday. Honestly, I believe a larger party needs to be involved. Nothing Navient has done to rectify this situation is appropriate. I have been penalized by their deceptive practices and now by their efforts to fix that. 

What I want from the situation : 1. My third loan that is still screwed up to be put into repayment with an effective date matching the day they do it. 
2. My two loans that are currently being called delinquent to be fixed to show they were in deferment until Friday XX/XX/XXXX ( as that is the best guess I have as to when they fixed the status ). 
XXXX. My credit report will not be affected. If Navient has already reported me delinquent. They will fix it immediately to show no payments were owed. My cosigners credit report should also be updated if affected. 
XXXX. I will be credited any amount of interest that was accrued on the {$220.00} since XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX. I will be notified by email and phone by an advanced Navient member when this is fixed. 
XXXX. Navient will either stop automatically putting private loans in an in-school deferment to match what their website states or will update their website.

Issue: Communication tactics
Sub-issue: You told them to stop contacting you, but they keep trying

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Back in the early XXXX  of XXXX I did a campus tour of The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. I was given a campus tour of the cafeteria, the dorms, and the industrial design lab. From the outside everything looked normal. They even did a seated introduction to the programs, telling us about the 90 % job placement and work-study programs that they always had available. The tuition rates posted up on a poster were not even close to what I ended up paying. 
After the tour I headed back home to Delaware. Little did I know that the school tour consented to the financial aid offices, XXXX XXXX ( The Dean ) personally calling me and not just once or twice. The financial aid offices and the student advisors called me three to four times a week for five months until I finally consented and talked my parents into attempting to cosign for me. I had no credit and was told after running my credit that I would not be able to get a loan by myself. That is when Sallie Mae/Navient was pushed on to us. No other loan program was offered, it always seemed to be Navient that made it work. I was in the student financing office every three months for the three and a half years I was there. It was the most stressful process ever. We were applying for loans so often that my mother could no longer qualify to co-sign for me to finish school. My dads girlfriend at the time decided to help me for one semester ( Three Months ) and I was back in the office again trying to figure it out. They hounded me daily to come up with financing. At one point during my 3.5-year term I somehow managed to get a loan all by myself without signing any documents or being made aware that I was on the loan without a co-signer. I never made over {$10.00} an hour consistently the whole time I was in school. How I qualified for a loan by myself with barely any income and no credit does not make any sense. 
I went to XXXX XXXX to attempt to get a work study to find out that there was not any available. I was in the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and with all the XXXX  companies in the area they had nothing available for me. With no work studies available I requested information on available jobs that they may have been aware of or that I could apply for that was within my scope of work. The lady told me that at this time there were no XXXX XXXX opportunities, but she has heard that XXXX was hiring down the street and I should go ask them. I couldnt believe it. The school that told me that they had a 90 % job placement rating and work study programs available at all times had nothing for me but to check out the XXXX down the street. 
By this time I was struggling financially, I had to go in to my financial advisor again to once again try to get a loan with a co-signer only to find out I had completely tapped out my Moms credit, My dads girlfriends credit and was in no position to be able to get one by myself and was eventually kicked out of school due to funding issues. I had managed to get 3.5 years in with XXXX credit and could not finish my degree. I was at the top of my class, on the deans list and honor society and I had nothing to show for it. I tried to hit the ground running and get a job but after the six-month mark when the student loans were not allowed to be charged, I was required to pay {$1500.00} a month in eleven separate loans at 13-17 % interest rate back. I hit rock bottom. I lost my apartment, I was homeless, my credit was destroyed and the only thing I could do was defer my loans with the accrual of interest rate over time. By XXXX I was over XXXX XXXX dollars in debt, with no home of my own, no car and a job that I was making {$16.00} an hour at. But Navient and Sallie who gave me these loans could have cared less. That hunted me, they called my family, my friends, anyone they could contact that could contact me. They called me 5 times a day. 
I fell into XXXX. Ended up having to take XXXX to keep my head up from all the negative thoughts that were running through my mind. I could not get an apartment because my credit was destroyed, I couldnt get a loan for a car, I was scared to get into a committed relationship due the how bad off I was financially and worst of all I was couch surfing. I had no home. This school was a fraud that prayed on me from the beginning. They sold me big dreams, easy payback schemes and the ease of getting loans and jobs that would make it all worth it in the end. That did not happen. And for the longest time I struggled emotionally and mentally to recover who I was. Navient/Sallie Mae played a big part in all of this. The XXXX XXXX and Navient/Sallie Mae worked together to get every once of money out of me and my family that they could. 
So, when I say this CFPB complaint is due to predatory lending, high pressure sales tactics or recruiting. That is just the small part of it that it all started with. There is also the problems with the interest rates that are criminal. The loan opened without my knowledge. The confusing and misleading advertising and the constant issues with financial aid. It should not be this hard to get a solid education. 
With all that being said I Submitted a Borrowers Defense Application on XX/XX/XXXX, and received confirmation from the Department of Education on XX/XX/XXXX. After researching my prior defense application, I found out my application was lost so I resubmitted my defense on XX/XX/XXXX. Which was part of the XXXX XXXX that happened. XX/XX/XXXX, I made a request for reconsideration. Finally, after all of that time and the accrual of additional stress and interest rate burden the Defense to Repayment was approved. 
Which was approved XX/XX/XXXX. 
Borrower Defense Application # : XXXX Borrower Defense Application School : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( The ) Pursuant to the Sweet settlement, the Department of Education will do the following : -Discharge your federal student loan ( s ) taken out for your enrollment in the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The ) ( " Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ) '' ) ; -Provide a refund for any payments made to the Department of Education on your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ), including Relevant Federal Student Loan debt that you previously paid off ; and -Delete the credit report tradeline associated with the discharged loan ( s ). 
In addition : I have submitted consumer complaints to both Delaware and Maryland Attorney Generals, in which states I have lived after being rejected from attending the XXXX XXXX. 
I have written my congressmen, The Honorable Dutch Ruppersberger and The Honorable XXXX XXXX I am apart of : The Project on Predatory Student Lending and the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Navient has inaccurately reported late payments on multiple student loan accounts despite the fact that these accounts were never late, as they were under enrollment deferment, standard deferment, or hardship deferment. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ), furnishers of information to credit reporting agencies, such as Navient, are required to report accurate information. When I contacted Navient on multiple occasions to request verification and correction of these inaccuracies, they failed to respond or rectify the errors as required by law.

Additionally, under 15 U.S.C. 1681i, the credit reporting agencies are obligated to conduct a reasonable investigation when a consumer disputes information on their credit report. Despite my formal requests to XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX to investigate these errors, none of the agencies completed a proper investigation or corrected the inaccurate information.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have over the course of the past 16 years disputed the three loans they state where given to this institution under my name. I asked them that they provide some kind of documentation with my signature on it where I indeed signed to attend this institution. 

I was sent a document containing my actual signature. However, it was to an actual institution I in fact was at the time and did attend. I called and explained this to them. And stated this institution ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) I never disputed attending. It was in fact another institution ( XXXX  XXXX XXXX ) that I disputed attending. They then provided me with an enrollment document as was the same kind they provided me with from the school I actually did attend. Although, there was NO handwritten signature on the document. It was in fact typed in. 

So, I then requested an investigation for this be done. Finally, a few months ago they agreed. They asked me to provide multiple documents. Which I provided what they had requested of me. After approximately 30 or so days, they responded that they have obtained an actual document with my signature on it proving I did attend that institution. I demanded to see it. They said they could not show it to me. 

I informed them that anything that they have in their procession that contains my signature, I have a right to have a copy of or see it. They told me they would not be supplying me with the document. I reminded them they had no problem with providing me the signed document from the institution I actually did attend which was handwritten and signed by me. Although, they can't by law provide me the same document they say they received from the other school! Why? 

They then said I have to contact the university itself to request an investigation through them. This is not right. They are the ones that gave the loan freely. Now prove to me what document you state you have in your possession that gave you the legal right to provide these loans!

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint against Navient Corporation ( " Navient '' ) for its violations of the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ), the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) in connection with my student loan account.

I. Violation of the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ) Navient has engaged in unfair, deceptive, and abusive practices that have caused significant financial harm and emotional distress. Specifically : Misrepresentation of Loan Terms and Repayment Options : Navient provided me with incorrect and misleading information regarding the repayment terms of my loan, which resulted in confusion and an inability to properly manage my debt. 

Failure to Properly Apply Payments : Despite making timely payments, Navient has misapplied or failed to credit these payments correctly, leading to inflated balances and unwarranted fees. 

Unlawful Servicing Practices : Navient has failed to provide adequate support, transparency, and information on available repayment programs, particularly income-driven repayment plans.

These actions violate the CFPA 's prohibition against unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices ( UDAAP ) as outlined in 12 U.S.C. 5531.

II. Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Navient has also violated the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) by failing to ensure accurate reporting of my account status to the credit reporting agencies. Specifically : Inaccurate Reporting : Navient has inaccurately reported my loan as delinquent despite timely payments, resulting in derogatory marks on my credit report that have caused me financial and reputational harm. 

Failure to Correct Errors : After notifying Navient of these inaccuracies, the company has failed to investigate and correct the erroneous information within the required time frame. 

Lack of Proper Notice : I have not received proper notice of the reporting or the ability to dispute the inaccurate information before it was reported to credit bureaus. 

These violations have severely impacted my credit score and ability to obtain new credit, in direct violation of my rights under the FCRA.

III. Violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) In addition to the above violations, Navient 's debt collection practices have also violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ), including but not limited to the following : Harassment and Intimidation : Navient representatives have engaged in aggressive, harassing, and intimidating collection tactics, including repeated phone calls and threatening language. 

False Representations : Navient has falsely represented the amount owed and the legal status of the debt, causing confusion and distress. 

Failure to Validate the Debt : Despite my requests, Navient has failed to provide proper validation of the debt as required under the FDCPA. 

These actions have caused me undue stress, financial harm, and emotional distress, and constitute clear violations of the FDCPA 's protections against unfair and abusive collection practices. 

Conclusion and Demand for Relief Based on the aforementioned violations of the CFPA, FCRA, and FDCPA, I am seeking the following relief : Immediate cessation of unlawful practices ; Correction of all inaccurate information on my credit report ; Recalculation of my loan balance and removal of any improperly applied fees ; Debt validation and proper application of all payments made to date ; Compensation for damages incurred as a result of Navient 's unlawful practices ; Any and all other relief that I may be entitled to under federal and state law. 

Principal Loan Amount ( XX/XX/year> ) = {$54000.00} Accrued Interest = {$39000.00} Thank you for your immediate attention to this serious matter.
