I believe their denial is unjustified, as my federal student loans for the same degree program were discharged by the U.S. Department of Education due to school misconduct under the borrower defense program. 

Background Information : * School : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX * Enrollment period : XXXX * Federal Loan Discharge : My federal loans, which funded the same program, were discharged due to findings of school misconduct and fraudulent practices by XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX 

* Private Loans : The private loans I am seeking to discharge were obtained from Navient to finance the same education program. 

Issues with Navient : * Despite the approval of my federal loan discharge, Navient denied my request for discharge of my private loans. 

* I received no specific explanation for the denial, despite multiple attempts to seek clarification. 

* I have submitted all necessary documentation, including employment and salary history after graduation, and the discharge letter for my federal loans, but Navient has not responded with a valid reason for their denial. 

* I believe Navient is acting in bad faith by failing to address my concerns and refusing to provide an appropriate discharge for loans that funded a fraudulent program.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Navient Corporation and Navient Solutions , LLC for FTC Federal Violation 16 C.F.R. 433.2 Missing from For-Profit Private School Loans Dear CFPB and FTC, I am writing to formally report violations of FTC Federal Regulation 16 C.F.R. 433.2 by Navient Corporation and Navient Solutions , LLC on three separate occasions. 

On XX/XX/year>, I received a School Misconduct Private Loan Discharge Application ( EXHIBIT A ). I completed this application, providing evidence of school misconduct along with federal violations committed by Sallie Mae, now operating as Navient Corporation and Navient Solutions , LLC . This completed application, along with the supporting evidence, was mailed on XX/XX/year>, with a return receipt. 

On XX/XX/year>, I received a notification through my Navient portal confirming receipt of my Private Loan School Misconduct Discharge Application ( EXHIBIT B ). On XX/XX/year>, I received a letter from Navient stating that my School Misconduct Discharge has been approved, and Navient has waived the remaining balances of my private student loans in the amount of {$16000.00} ( EXHIBIT C ). Enclosed with the letter was a check for {$630.00} ( EXHIBIT D ). 

However, Navient has, on three occasions, given, received, enforced, and accepted payments on private loan contracts where the Holder Rule was absent from the promissory notes for these three loans ( EXHIBIT E, pages 4, 5, 6 ). This constitutes a violation of federal law.

The Holder Rule, established by the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), requires that a specific notice be included in certain consumer credit contracts, including promissory notes for private student loans. ( EXHIBIT H ). This notice preserves the consumers right to raise claims and defenses against any holder of the loan that they could assert against the original creditor. If this rule is violated, it renders the contract unenforceable or provides the consumer grounds for seeking refunds of payments made under that contract. 

By approving my misconduct application, Navient has admitted that my school engaged in misconduct. However, the check issued to me, covering payments made only since XXXX, is grossly inadequate. I have not cashed this check, as I do not accept a mere {$630.00} after years of payments made on fraudulent contracts and a school proven to have engaged in misconduct. 

In my application, I outlined that Navient is in violation of federal law by accepting payments on three contracts that lack the Holder Rule, as required ( EXHIBIT F, pages 26, 27 ). Navient has had the opportunity to rectify this by issuing full restitution through my School Misconduct Discharge Application. I am entitled to a refund for all payments, including interest ( EXHIBIT G1 and EXHIBIT G2 ), on these three loan contracts that violate federal law. 

Unlike federal student loans, each private student loan contract requires a corresponding promissory note. There is no statute of limitations on the Holder Rule ( EXHIBIT H ). Each violation is subject to a {$50000.00} fine by the FTC. Even if a loan has been paid off but the promissory note did not include the Holder Rule, the contract is unenforceable. 

I am entitled to recover the payments I have made. I have included my application outlining proof of these violations, along with the contracts and promissory notes, for your review. Navient is not entitled to state that their decision on payments is proprietary, especially concerning impactful decisions related to federal violations and individuals ' financial well-being. 

I request your assistance in addressing this matter and ensuring that Navient complies with federal regulations. I seek a full refund of all payments made on these loans, along with the applicable interest, and enforcement of the fines for these violations. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern : I am writing to file a formal complaint against Navient for its refusal to refund all payments made on my private loans, which were taken out to attend a for-profit educational institution, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX that XXXX XXXX misconduct. Despite Navients acknowledgment of this misconduct, I have only been refunded a single month of payments. This response is not only inadequate but also in clear violation of the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) Holder Rule, as explicitly stated in my promissory notes.

Relevant Facts : 1. Promissory Note Terms : My promissory notes contain the following notice : I understand that the following notice is only applicable to loans issued to finance educational expenses at for-profit educational institutions or institutions otherwise subject to the FTC Holder Rule under 16 C.F.R. 433.2. 
NOTICE : ANY HOLDER OF THIS CONSUMER CREDIT CONTRACT IS SUBJECT TO ALL CLAIMS AND DEFENSES WHICH THE DEBTOR COULD ASSERT AGAINST THE SELLER OF GOODS OR SERVICES OBTAINED WITH THE PROCEEDS HEREOF. RECOVERY HEREUNDER BY THE DEBTOR SHALL NOT EXCEED AMOUNTS PAID BY THE DEBTOR HEREUNDER. 


2. Navients Acknowledgment of School Misconduct : My application for a school misconduct discharge was approved by Navient, indicating their acknowledgment that the school engaged in fraudulent activities. 

XXXX. Navients Awareness Since XXXX : Inquiries to Navient about the limited refund led to the revelation that Navient has been documenting complaints related to school misconduct since at least XXXX, demonstrating their long-standing awareness of the issue. 

XXXX. Extensive Payments Made : I have been making payments on these loans since XXXX and have paid double the amounts owed in interest alone, amounting to substantial financial harm. 

XXXX. Repeated Appeals for Fair Treatment : Over numerous phone calls, I have expressed the inherent unfairness of repaying loans tied to a fraudulent institution. Had Navient listened to every phone call I ever made, they would see that I mentioned the misconduct of my school well before receiving the application from them in XX/XX/XXXX. Despite these appeals, and my request for a closed school discharge application ( which Navient no longer offers ), my concerns have been dismissed or inadequately addressed. It is unfair for Navient to put the ownus on the borrower, when they have always made it explicitly clear, no matter what argument we had, that the only way out of a private loan was death or XXXX. 

Complaint : XXXX refusal to refund the full amount of payments made on these loans is a blatant disregard of the protections afforded to me under the FTC Holder Rule, as noted in the terms of my promissory note. By approving my school misconduct discharge application, Navient has implicitly acknowledged the fraudulent nature of the educational institution and, therefore, my entitlement to a full refund of all payments made under the compromised loan agreement. 

Furthermore, I would like to highlight that Navients recent Attorney General settlement included provisions for refunding borrowers under similar circumstances involving school misconduct, particularly for loans that had been in default. This settlement underscores Navients recognition of their responsibility to remedy financial harm caused by fraudulent educational institutions. However, in my case, despite my loans not being in default, Navient has unjustly refused to refund the payments I made. The inconsistency in their actions between the settlement agreement and my situation is both unjust and indefensible, demanding immediate correction. 


Demand for Resolution I demand that Navient : 1. Refund the full amount of all payments made towards these loans, including principal and interest, in accordance with the FTC Holder Rule.

2. Provide a detailed accounting of all payments made and the specific reasons for their refusal to issue a full refund.

Failure to address these issues adequately will leave me no choice but to escalate my complaint to additional regulatory bodies, including the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs and the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, and to seek legal recourse to recover the funds wrongfully retained by Navient. 

Conclusion The ongoing financial and emotional distress caused by Navients actions is unacceptable and must be rectified immediately. Why does Navient have borrowers outline in a 14page application, the financial and emotional harm they have suffered paying these loans, only to refuse refunds.

I expect a prompt and comprehensive response to this complaint, detailing the steps Navient will take to comply with its legal obligations under the FTC Holder Rule.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I called Navient asking about my loan being transferred to XXXX and an automatic payment that is scheduled on the transfer date. I was informed I had no payments due in XXXX. Today, XX/XX/XXXX, I received a billing statement from Navient with a bill for XXXX. I called and received a very argumentative representative who told me I do have a bill but nothing is automatically scheduled. I asked why since I have been on a payment plan and why I am paying over the bill amount. She told me my payment plan has ended and XXXX of my loans are in forbearance now. I never put my loans in forbearance because I have no forbearance available per Navient who continually put my in forbearance years ago. I also never received communications that my payment plan was ending. It had the plan listed as indefinitely previously and now says it ends on XX/XX/XXXX after the loan is transferred. She argued with me and the statement and said no it ended in XXXX. Navient has repeatedly messed up my accounts, given bad guidance, and failed to communicate. Now I doubt my correct loan amount will be transferred if they are still taking payments as they transfer. I was instructed to just pay late since I have a XXXX days grace period and pay XXXX instead. Why is nothing being communicated and why are my loans being placed in forbearance without my awareness. I had to transfer all my XXXX federal loans away from Navient due to their negligence. 

Additionally, the representative said XXXX of my accounts are in forbearance as of now for XXXX. That I was paying {$380.00} instead of the bill 's listed {$200.00} because I was paying interest only for all loans, but now XXXX are in forbearance. I am attaching documentation that says all of my loans are in repayment. Not forbearance. I also am attaching my statements since XXXX showing that every month the bill has only been {$200.00} yet I have been overpaying for " interest '' only {$380.00}, yet my balance has not been coming down even with overpayment. I am also in a XXXX repayment plan, not XXXX months that she mentioned. All the info she provided was incorrect and a lie.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XXXX XXXX XXXX I submitted the School Misconduct application sent by Navient Corporation. This application was to submit documents and paperwork that would suffice for full discharge of my private loans taken out for my education at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
Per the application, in writing, they stated that they would return correspondence in 60 days or less. 
It is now XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/year> and have heard nothing. No confirmation of receipt or any sort of message asking for anything or any outcome. This is unacceptable. 
The only correspondence I have received from Navient is that they will be transferring all my loans to XXXX. 

I have submitted these similar applications to the Dept of Education which also have sent me correspondence and discharged my Federal Loans.

Navient has kept those loans in limbo. They have not moved, been discharged, but are just sitting there with no action to them either.

The private loans though are still up - and I have been paying as much as I can to keep them from defaulting or from going into forbearance which would elevate them due to interest accumulated. I have reached out to the California State Attorney General as well as the DFPI ( Department of Financial Protection and Innovation ) and filed complaints. 

I have yet to hear back from Navient.

Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Sub-issue: Debt is not yours
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Navient Student Loan Services/ Whom It May Concern : I am writing to formally dispute the alleged debt reported by Navient Student Loan Services on my credit report. I believe this debt to be fraudulent, as I have no knowledge of this account and have never entered into any contractual obligations with your company or the original creditor.

In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I am exercising my right to request validation and verification of this debt. To resolve this matter promptly, I request that you provide the following documentation : Proof of Authorization : Evidence demonstrating your authorization under 15 U.S.C. 1692 ( e ) and 15 U.S.C. 1692 ( f ) to handle and collect this debt.

Legal Basis for Collection : A detailed explanation of the legal grounds upon which this debt is being collected.

State Authorization : Proof that your organization is authorized to operate and collect debts in my state of residence.

Evidence of the Alleged Debt : A complete and accurate copy of any contract or agreement, including my signature, that would obligate me to this debt. 
Full Account History : A comprehensive account history, including any charges, fees, and all collection-related activities.

Pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 602 ( a ), I demand the immediate cessation of all communication and collection activities until the alleged debt has been validated as required by law. Additionally, under 15 U.S.C. 604 ( a ) ( 2 ), I remind you that no information regarding this debt should be reported to any credit bureaus without my explicit written consent.

Your actions in reporting this alleged debt to the credit bureaus and attempting to collect it violate several key provisions of the FDCPA, including : 1692d : Prohibiting harassment or abuse in the collection of debts.

1692e : Prohibiting false, deceptive, or misleading representations.

1692g ( b ) : Requiring the proper disclosure of my rights and validation of the debt.

1692f : Prohibiting the use of unfair or unconscionable means to collect a debt.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted a complaint to receive an application for the XXXX XXXX XXXX. I qualified for an application, however, was just sent a denial letter with no explanation on why I did not qualify. 

Not only was another XXXX my loans from Navient, from the same school and same XXXX XXXX, part of the XXXX settlement, I provided email evidence of how the school presented XXXX XXXX as the preferred lender to their students when applying for financial aid through the XXXX XXXX employees. 

I do not see how my loan would qualify for the XXXX settlement, and this one not be granted relief through borrower defense. 

The only reason this loan was not part of the XXXX settlement is because I had a co-signor and based on the XXXX terms, my loan did not qualify due to the CO-SIGNORS XXXX XXXX. However, Navient allowed the CO-Signor to be waived by paying $ XXXX towards this loan to have his name removed from the loan. Navient made this decision despite the proof of income I showed as a single mother. 

So, XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX allowed a loan to be taken out only because of a co-signor, and because of that co-signor the loan was not part of the XXXX XXXX, but not the co-signor is removed, which was the only reason it did not qualify for the settlement. Because all other claims in that lawsuit were for preferred lender status and giving our subprime loans knowing the borrowers could not afford to repay those loans. 

If my borrower defense application is being denied solely because the co-signor just paid $ XXXX and they would need to return those funds, I am asking for an investigation.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
CFPB Complaint against Navient and XXXX XXXX The student loan debt assumed to my name of ~ {$50000.00} was sold off for ~ {$5000.00}. This was after I filed for bankruptcy protection after a long bout of no and underemployment. Having paid Navient for a year and a half after bankruptcy until I ran out of money and was no longer able to pay. I have been dragged into court enough that I learned how to write legal responses because I couldnt afford an attorneys help after a time. Fast forward 6 years from when my payments were unable to be continued, I have continued to get judgement liens and so much legal paperwork that it is over a foot high. I have diligently worked for the last 2 years, saving, finally getting XXXX XXXX after a long bout of under and no employment. After adverse action was taken against me, I reached out to my lender with a settlement offer of {$20000.00}. This was after the attorney told me settlement was not possible, after first choosing not to respond to me ( Please see exhibit A & 1 ). P.S. I dont ever remember signing an agreement. It was a XXXX  time in my life having lost both incomes, my having to file bankruptcy & it being discharged. I had no job, & not even {$50.00} in the bank & writing my own legal responses. My settlement offer was accepted ( XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX ). The lender then called the debt attorney to notify them that my settlement offer had been accepted. ( Please see Exhibit XXXX where the email states that Navient would reach out to the attorney notifying them of acceptance of the offer. ) I was called by Navients attorney/representative ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX ). I missed the call. Called back and got the run around like I was running the XXXX m run at the Olympics. 

After not being able to get the lenders attorney to call back to settle, my attorney, XXXX XXXX, contacted Navient/SLM/Sallie Maes attorney for the update as to when the settlement paperwork would be sent so the payment could be made and the cases closed. Navients attorney told my attorney that we had to prove that their client accepted the offer. ( Please see Exhibit 3 where Attorney XXXX XXXX sent proof of acceptance of the settlement offer to NAVIENTs attorneys by XXXX XXXX, XXXX @ XXXX. ) After 5 days of no response, I and my attorney XXXX XXXX reached out by phone and email to Navients attorney ( Please see exhibit XXXX XX/XX/XXXX @ XXXX ). After multiple phone attempts and finally an email by my attorney XXXX ( See exhibit XXXX XX/XX/XXXX @ XXXX ), XXXX XXXX XXXX to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ) saying he was awaiting confirmation and clarification from their client concerning the resolution. Remind you, Navient contacted the law firm on XX/XX/XXXX and told them the offer was accepted. 

Fast forward to XX/XX/XXXX ( See Exhibit XXXX -email XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX ) Navients attorney XXXX XXXX XXXX sends an email to my attorney, XXXX XXXX XXXX and says that the client are not accepting the {$20000.00} and want {$39000.00}. They had agreed to the {$20000.00}. They waited until after the garnishments ran dry because my contract ended. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX told XXXX XXXX this when the initial settlement offer was made to them through my attorney XXXX XXXX ( See Exhibit XXXX ). I found out about the garnishment when I got my paycheck and it was short. I definitely would have tried to settle & seek representation if I was aware of a wage garnishment before it happening. ( See Exhibit XXXX & XXXX when I emailed my HR Dept inquiring about my income. ) The garnishment notice was sent to the company. ( See Exhibit 9 ) Now understand, this is not a case where I came or are coming empty handed. I have went through bankruptcy and had it discharged. Survived XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, where the XXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I have survived a host of XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. Worked hard & diligent on trying to pay off everything & everybody I owed. I live frugally so I never have to file bankruptcy again. I finally got XXXX  XXXX  after a long time. XXXX ended. I made a settlement offer with NAVIENT. I had it accepted, then had it reneged upon. Then more court papers ( XXXX sent to my attorney XX/XX/XXXX ). THIS IS NOT RIGHT. 

Typically, when one goes through a bankruptcy discharge, this allows a person to move on and start afresh financially. Instead, I have been sued up the wazooie, & continued to be affected financially ( 8 years after insolvency ).

I am asking for your assistance to quell this matter. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ( I was underemployed. But it became rewarding work. ) from XXXX. During that time, I helped XXXX clients either obtain a modification to keep and stay in their home or transition respectfully. The thing about that process was there was an end. There has been no end to this process. I am asking for your help to settle this. This private student loan issue is akin to the Foreclosure XXXX XXXX that started in XXXX. It took up motion during the XXXX  XXXX. Started a fast walk/run pace during the Trump administration and is continually taking wings to soar on during the Biden administration . This is not going away. 

I ask your help because I have gone through this and had some assistance through my attorney. How many people is this happening to where NAVIENT is accepting, reneging, and continuing this unending vicious cycle? I know Im not the only one. I ask for your help. Im sure with your help and the help of our elected and appointed leaders, on the local, state and federal levels, XXXX can come. If XXXX can file bankruptcy on, by some accounts over {$3.00} XXXX dollars and walk away paying nothing, why cant I be allowed for my settlement offer be accepted and free to move on? Im not asking for a {$0.00} effort. Im asking for help in working with them to accept what they agreed to in writing, release me from all liens, and move forward. 

Warm regards,

Consumer complaint narrative: Over the last several years, I have been working with the WI AG 's office and the Project for Predatory Lending regarding incorrect info and practices regarding the loans that the school took out in my name via copy & pasting my signature, high pressure tactics where inaccurate info and misrepresentations were used, pushing me into more expensive plans to pay back the fraudulent debts, and denying me relief I was entitled to, amongst other things. All of this info can be found in my approved Borrower 's Defense to Repayment application, that was approved, resulting in my Federal loans being discharged. My private fraudulent loans should have been discharged in the multi-state Attorney General settlement against Navient, but they weren't. Navient has given me a multitude of reasons, but the fact of the matter is that they have known for years that the info school listed on my loans is incorrect, and are now using it as an excuse to not discharge these fraudulent loans, coincidentally continuing with the shady practices that got them sued in the first place. Because of their refusal to correct things on their end, I also can not apply for and am not included in any other legal proceedings or discharge programs that have been created, due to their fraud. The bottom line is : Navient/Sallie Mae was found to be defrauding students alongside XXXX XXXX XXXX The loans they have listed in my name should have been discharged years ago. They have received roughly {$60000.00} from me, in an attempt to preserve my credit while fighting these fraudulent loans, and yet, the fraud continues.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX - Loan was disbursed by Sallie Mae {$23000.00} Making regular monthly payments of {$130.00} XXXX - Started having a stretch of late payments as personal finances struggled was suggested a forbearance by the representative. 
End of XXXX - Started having late payments again and took a forbearance due to a divorce I was going through after the representative suggested it. I moved into an apartment in spring of XXXX. In spring of XXXX my lease was up so I moved into a cheaper unit in the same complex. XXXX XXXX was sending me letters to either end the forbearance or continue it but these were going to my old mailbox. I wasn't aware of this until my wage was garnished. At that point, the loan was over XXXX XXXX XXXX and I had paid almost {$16000.00} on it leaving over {$8000.00} on the balance. The XXXX  XXXX XXXX then worked with me to rehab my loan which was then over {$16000.00} because of penalties, fees and interest! They said if I made my monthly payments for 12 months in a row it would go back to it's normal balance. 
As soon as my 12 months were up, they " sold '' it to Navient with the penalties, fees and interest for a total of {$15000.00}. When I said what they promised me the representative was smug and said that has nothing to do with them! 

At the time it was very disheartening to think I have about {$8000.00} left to pay to only learn I really have double that! As a single father it was tough to take in. It wasn't until a few years later that I learned I wasn't the only one they did this type of thing to, when I learned of the massive lawsuit. 

I have included some personal documents from the loan.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
" The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681 ) says ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system.

So whenever there is a violation under the FCRA, it impairs the efficiency of the banking system. This is a violation of TILA US Code 1666B since I was never late.

I recently reviewed my consumer report and noticed an incorrect late payment record on my NAVIENT XXXX. I have always maintained timely payments on this account. Under the Fair Credit Billing Act ( FCBA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), creditors are required to accurately report consumer transactions and provide a mechanism for correcting errors in a timely manner. Please conduct an investigation into this matter, and if you can not provide documentary evidence of these supposed late payments, I demand these payments to be updated to on time as they should be as I was NEVER late. I expect these updates to be made promptly, in compliance with the law.

"

I spoke to the attorneys from both bankruptcies and they said the loans should have been automatically discharged and that they did not know what they should send to Navient and to where they should send it. The documents, including the discharge order and the petition, from the XXXX bankruptcy are attached.

Sub-issue: Bankruptcy
Consumer complaint narrative: Navient is attempting to illegally collect on a student loan XXXX by bankruptcy. Navients response to a previous complaint states that the loan was a qualified education loan. This position is incorrect as referenced in Bulletin XXXX : Unfair Billing and Collection Practices After Bankruptcy Discharges of Certain Student Loan Debts, where the CFPB explains XXXX Second, Fifth, and Tenth Circuits have held that the educational benefit exclusion does not apply to student loans. ( XXXX, XXXX XXXX at XXXX ; XXXX, XXXX XXXX at XXXX ; XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. ) The CFPB also states that this type of loan was not exempt from general order of discharge because it was a loan made in excess of the cost of attendance ( see attached statements ). The CFPB states that the practice of attempting to collect on a loan such as this constitutes a violation of federal consumer financial law. Navient is even in breach of the Navient XXXX XXXX XXXX where Navient is to refrain from informing private loan borrowers that their loans are non-dischargeable in bankruptcy. Several agents told me private loans were non-dischargeable in bankruptcy. This loan was not made, insured, or guaranteed by a governmental unit, or made under any program funded in whole or in part by a governmental unit or nonprofit institution. The loan is not a qualified education loan per IRS code XXXX ( d ) ( XXXX ) as it was higher than the cost of attendance, paid directly to me by check, and was not used solely to pay qualified higher education expenses as my first year was paid for by scholarships, grants, and federal student loans. I have included statements from XXXX that prove this fact as no money from the loan was paid to XXXX at any time. Any private loans in these categories ( loan in excess of cost of attendance as this one was ) are XXXX by standard bankruptcy discharge orders, just like most other unsecured consumer debts. ( See, e.g., XXXX, XXXX XXXX at XXXX ; XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX at XXXX ; XXXX, XXXX XXXX at XXXX ) The CFPB examiners discovered XXXX student loan servicers engaged in unfair acts or practices, a violation of the Dodd-Frank Act, when they resumed collection of debts that were XXXX by bankruptcy courts. The conduct caused or was likely to cause substantial injury to consumers because the representations made to consumers in billing statements and other collection attempts were likely to result in consumers making payments they did not owe. Navient is attempting to do this to me now even as I have repeatedly told them that this loan was XXXX because it was not a qualified education loan and is treated as any other consumer debt. In addition to this complaint, I have recently written letters to CFPB XXXX XXXX XXXX, CFPB Private Education Loan Ombudsman XXXX XXXX, and Congressman XXXX XXXX to alert them to Navients activity. I wish for this to be resolved before Navient transfers this loan to XXXX, a servicer who is known to mishandle loans. Attached are the statements from XXXX, the bulletin from the CFPB, and my bankruptcy discharge order.

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear NAVIENT, I am writing to formally address a serious violation concerning the unauthorized reporting of information to my credit report. This issue is in direct violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) under Sections 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), 1681c ( a ) ( 2 ), and 1681s-2 ( a ), as well as the Texas Finance Code under Sections 392.301 and 392.305, and identity theft laws as outlined in the Texas Penal Code Section 32.51.

It has come to my attention that NAVIENT has engaged in unauthorized reporting to my credit report without my explicit consent. Under federal law, specifically the FCRA, consumer consent is a mandatory requirement for any credit reporting activities, as stated in Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ).

Moreover, Texas state law reinforces this requirement. Section 392.301 of the Texas Finance Code clearly states that consumer consent is necessary for credit reporting. Additionally, Section 392.305 provides guidelines for the fair reporting of consumer credit information. The identity theft laws, particularly Texas Penal Code Section 32.51, highlight the seriousness of unauthorized access and misuse of personal information. 

I unequivocally assert that I have not granted consent for NAVIENT to report any information to my credit report. This lack of explicit permission constitutes a clear violation of my rights, potentially damaging my creditworthiness and showing a blatant disregard for both federal and state laws. 

I demand that NAVIENT immediately cease any further reporting of information to my credit report without my explicit consent, as required by Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ) of the FCRA and Sections 392.301 and 392.305 of the Texas Finance Code. Should you fail to comply within the next 30 days, I will consider this willful noncompliance, which may result in penalties under applicable laws, including those related to identity theft. 

It is imperative to understand that obtaining consent is not optional ; it is a legal obligation under these specific sections of the FCRA, Texas state law, and identity theft laws. This is not a negotiation ; it is a demand for adherence to both federal and state regulations designed to protect consumers like myself from unauthorized and harmful credit reporting. 

I expect your immediate attention to this matter and anticipate that NAVIENT will rectify these violations promptly, respecting my rights under federal and state laws. 
Done in good faith.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Was not notified of investigation status or results
Consumer complaint narrative:
" The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681 ) says ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system. 

So whenever there is a violation under the FCRA, it impairs the efficiency of the banking system. This is a violation of TILA US Code 1666B since I was never late. 

I recently reviewed my consumer report and noticed an incorrect late payment record on my NAVIENT - XXXX, NAVIENT - XXXX, NAVIENT - XXXX, NAVIENT - XXXX, NAVIENT - XXXX, NAVIENT - XXXX, NAVIENT - XXXX. I have always maintained timely payments on this account. Under the Fair Credit Billing Act ( FCBA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), creditors are required to accurately report consumer transactions and provide a mechanism for correcting errors in a timely manner. Please conduct an investigation into this matter, and if you can not provide documentary evidence of these supposed late payments, I demand these payments to be updated to on time as they should be as I was NEVER late. I expect these updates to be made promptly, in compliance with the law. 
"

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX, I took out a {$7000.00} private student loan from Navient to attend a school that was later deemed fraudulent. Despite having paid over {$20000.00} towards this loan, the balance has now ballooned to {$25000.00} and is in default. 

I have already been approved for a discharge of my federal loans under the Borrower Defense to Repayment ( BDTR ) program due to the fraudulent nature of the school. I believe the same logic should apply to my private loans, as they were taken out for the same fraudulent educational program. 

Over the years, I have made continued efforts to honor my obligation and resolve this debt through various repayment plans. However, Navient has denied my requests to apply the BDTR discharge to my private loans, even though the very nature of the loan has been determined to be based on fraud.

At one point, Navient offered me a settlement of {$13000.00}, but then instructed me to secure a high-interest loan to pay off this amount. I believe this is an extension of their predatory practices, as it would only serve to put me in further financial distress. 

Given that my XXXX claim was approved for my federal loans from the same fraudulent school, I assert that it should also apply to my private loans with Navient. I am seeking relief and a discharge of this debt, which has caused me significant financial hardship despite my good faith efforts to resolve it over many years.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/2024, my final payment to Navient for my student loan was to be paid via autopay from my bank act. A couple of days prior to the amount being removed for payment, I checked to make sure the full amount I was scheduled to pay covered the full amount remaining on my loan. I double checked the payoff amount if the loan were to be paid in full that day and then compared it to the amount that was shown to be removed from my act for my auto payment. On the XXXX, 3 days after my final loan payment was done, I saw a lower amount was taken out than what it stated was for the total payoff amount, and that I had another auto payment scheduled for XXXX. It also showed that I had a balance of {$0.00} left on my act. So out of pure disbelief - I paid the remaining amount, {$0.00} from my bank act on the XXXX. Navient has since received my payments and shows both have posted to my act when I checked today, the XXXX of XXXX. But what really threw me for a loop was that the loan still showed open, still showed a scheduled autopay for XXXX, and still showed that the act was in repayment when in fact the act had been paid in full. Once the company receives the final payment, and post it to the act, how are they not closing the act or changing the status of the act to reflect the accurate status? The loan is no longer in repayment because it is paid off. 

I called a Navient and was told that they require that the acts show that they are still open and in repayment for 2 months after the last date of payment. WHAT!?!?!? That they need that time to season the payment?? How is this legal??? I have never had a lender keep the act open, and have it show an inaccurate payment status for 2 months after the date of the last payment??? Not only that but it was still reflecting as to have scheduled auto payments for the future! I was told from a customer service rep that they keep it open so they can adjust the act over two months? No. Once the payment has posted to the act, there is no reason to be adjusting anything. If there was an overpayment, then cut me a check but show the act is closed and its in good status! 

What really concerned me was the fact that they changed the auto payment amount to a lesser amount and then still showed I had a balance owed on the act!!?! How can that happen??!? I had to make an additional payment of {$0.00} on my act to pay it in full!!! This is not the only loan Ive had in my life but the most ridiculous loan Ive ever dealt with. If the payoff amount reflected the same amount that was owed, online- why would they change the amount of money they took for the payment that already showed it was pulling out the total amount shown under the payoff amount and then they change that as the payment is coming out so I still owed money on the act and they could still gain money from interest and missed payment fees on the act. This is absolutely ridiculous.

I am filing this complaint because Navient has unjustly denied my application for a XXXX XXXX XXXX. Despite the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX being legally recognized for its predatory practices, and my federal loans being discharged under the Borrower Defense to Repayment ( BDTR ) program, Navient refuses to discharge my private loans.

I am requesting that the CFPB investigate this issue and ensure that Navient provides a transparent and fair review of my application.

Now just to point out the ridiculousness of this I could get a piece of stationary and put an image of the bank on my piece of paper and then write that my account number is valid and just sign it with somebody else 's name and they would take that. They told me to fax or snail mail the letter into them or download it on their site. But the factory XXXX did an order for me to bring my account valid. I have to agree to a set of terms with Navient that state that I agree to all the late charges and the accrued interest that has resulted from their error. To Whom It May Concern, In XX/XX/year>, I applied for Student Loan Forgiveness due to School Misconduct with the Illinois XXXX XXXX XXXX and loans with Navient. After this application, I received written communication from Navient that they were assessing the application over 60 days. Upon this period ending, I contacted Navient and was told that the period was extended further. At the end of this extension, I contacted Navient and received a call back the same day ( In XXXX ). This call told me that my student loans had been forgiven and that I was receiving a refund check. Upon asking further, the individual with Navient noted that they were looking at the wrong screen. A few weeks later, I received the denial letters from Navient with the same vague response, consistent with the first application. I do not believe that Navient is reviewing my application and is provided an automated response as they seem to be randomly selecting applications to approve as the reasoning that I have for forgiveness is no different than those online that have been forgiven ( for a school that has already been proved by the U.S. Department of Education to have committed fraud, which I experienced first hand ). I am applying again with Navient and want to have them review the new application again, with additional support, and provide the reasoning why ( or why not ) the application is accepted or rejected ( per the Holder rule I am entitled to have this loan dismissed ). I noted that the same letter I received is not only consistent exactly with my first application, however also exactly what has been issued to many others ( and identified by the U.S. Senate review as being an issue ). I look forward to your support in this application as I believe fraudulent activities have occurred here to my detriment. Thank you for your time. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I called Navient on XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX ext. XXXX to request a XXXX  misconduct discharge application. I found out about this application on a social media site. Navient had not notified me that my account was eligible for this program. The representative I spoke with said my account was eligible for review and it would take 30 days to complete. Once approved, I would receive an application. 

I called again on XX/XX/XXXX to follow up on the status. The representative informed me that I needed to fill out an application in order to apply for the discharge. I explained that was I told my account needed to be reviewed first. She said that was incorrect and sent me an application via my Navient inbox. The previous misinformation prolonged my application process unnecessarily. 

I received the application on XX/XX/XXXX, and submitted it on XX/XX/XXXX. Navient confirmed it was received on XX/XX/XXXX. 

I received a letter via the Navient inbox on XX/XX/XXXX stating my application was denied for the following reason : " Navient carefully considers a variety of factors in determining whether a private loan should be XXXX based on school misconduct and you do not meet the requirements for discharge based on misconduct by your school. '' I called Navient and asked the representative for a more detailed explanation of my denial and asked what specific requirements did I not meet, since it was already predetermined that I was eligible for this program. She stated she doesn't know the specific reason, and they have a lot of factors they consider. She could not provide what those factors are. I was told I could appeal the decision, but without specific reasons for my denial, I would risk being denied again for the same unidentified reason. 

I provided supporting documentation that shows my federal student loans are currently a part of a XXXX XXXX case and my application is still pending. I also provided a court case from XXXX that shows the XXXX XXXX XXXX  was a participating in fraudulent and misleading practices.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Today, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) filed a proposed order against the student loan servicer Navient for its years of failures and lawbreaking. If entered by the court, the proposed order would permanently ban the company from servicing federal Direct Loans and would forbid the company from directly servicing or acquiring most loans under the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. These bans would largely remove Navient from a market where it, among other illegal actions, steered numerous student loan borrowers into costly repayment options. Navient also illegally deprived student borrowers of opportunities to enroll in more affordable income-driven repayment plans and forced them to pay much more than they should have. Under the terms of the order, Navient would have to pay a {$20.00} XXXX penalty and provide {$100.00} XXXX in redress for harmed borrowers. 

For years, XXXX top executives profited handsomely by exploiting students and taxpayers, said CFPB XXXX XXXX XXXX. By banning the notorious student loan giant from federal student loan servicing and ensuring the winddown of these operations, the CFPB will finally put an end to the years of abuse. 

I applaud the CFPB for obtaining concrete relief for borrowers and deterring similar failures in the future, said XXXX. Under Secretary of Education XXXX XXXX. XXXX action builds on the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX hold loan servicers accountable and protect borrowers, including more than XXXX XXXX borrowers who have received debt relief by fixing past failures to properly track progress toward forgiveness, such as correcting harms from forbearance steering. 

The CFPBs investigation of Navient kicked off a series of efforts by state and federal agencies to examine forbearance steering and other breakdowns in the income-driven repayment program. Those efforts have resulted in more than {$50.00} XXXX in debt relief for more than XXXX XXXX borrowers who were wrongly steered into forbearance, as well as those who had payments miscounted. Todays order complements actions already taken by the Department of Education and state attorneys general to provide redress to borrowers harmed by Navient.

The CFPB sued Navient for failing borrowers at every stage of repayment. The lawsuit alleges that Navient steered borrowers who may have qualified for income-driven repayment plans into forbearance instead. This practice was cheaper and simpler for Navient, but detrimental to borrowers. By steering struggling borrowers into forbearance where interest continues to accrue and capitalize Navients illegal actions led numerous borrowers to pay additional interest charges. 

Navient is a repeat offender with a long history of regulatory violations. After a referral from the CFPB, in XXXX, the Department of Justice and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ordered Navient and its predecessor, XXXX XXXX, to pay almost {$100.00} XXXX for illegally overcharging nearly XXXX service tomembers. In XXXX, the Department of Education ordered Navient to return more than {$22.00} XXXX in overcharges. In XXXX, XXXX state attorneys general announced a {$1.00} XXXX settlement with Navient for originating predatory student loans in addition to its forbearance steering practices.

I recently received your email regarding my student loan account with Navient. I just wanted to clarify that I only have one private student loan with Navient ( formerly Sallie Mae ). 1. We previously serviced two additional Private Tuition Answer Loans, which youve since paid in full. 
2. As noted above, the Holder Rule applies to direct-to-school loans. However, the proceeds of your three Tuition Answer Loans were sent to you directly at disbursement, rendering them ineligible for our School Misconduct review process.

Firstly, the email mentioned that I have multiple private student loans with Navient. This is not accurate as I only have one private student loan with your company.

I would appreciate it if you could review my account and provide me with accurate information regarding my student loan. Please let me know if there are any discrepancies that need to be addressed. 


Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX XXXX back in XXXX / XXXX fresh out of XXXX XXXX like hundreds of thousands of others did my age. When I realized XXXX XXXX was taking loans out in my name without my authorization, I immediately stopped going to the school. 

Years later, the federal government closed XXXX XXXX due to massive Fraud. It is widely known by the public that XXXX XXXX committed fraud against ALL their students. I filed a defense to repayment claim with the federal government and the recent federal court case that was won, forced the feds to process all these defense to repayment claims that had been sitting for years. They approved my claim for XXXX XXXX and expunged all my student loans related to this school. 

I have been in bankruptcy on and off for the last 10 yeasr of my life due to this. But when I exited bankruptcy after my student loans were forgiven, i was shocked to see private student loans from Navient, that are from XXXX XXXX. I never knowingly took out any private student loans with them and had no idea these loans even existed until I exited bankruptcy. 

I filed a motion to have the loans discharged through Navient since XXXX XXXX literally frauded every single student they ever had, and figured that they would clear them out. Navient came back to me and said no they would not get rid of the loans and that I needed to pay them or they would sue me/ ruin my credit. They flatly refused to offer me any explanation as to why they denied my motion for discharge. 

Back in XXXX a former student of XXXX XXXX sued Navient for this same reason and won. This case, known as XXXX v. Navient, brought attention to the issue of predatory lending practices in for-profit education. XXXX XXXX won this case. So there is a precedent. 

I am currently attempting to hire the same law firm that helped XXXX XXXX back in XXXX but it is proving to be almost impossible. No one wants to help me fight this. I will not pay for loans that I didn't take out. I will live with bad credit forever before I pay for fraudulent loans.

Once again they put me on forbearance for another 3 months to bring my account back in good standing so I agreed to it to give them time to process my application. I am tired of them misleading consumers and not having good explanations when we ask questions. I need answers and at this point I dont know what to do.

Consumer complaint narrative: After graduating college in XXXX and struggling for multiple years to pay my then, XXXX XXXX loans ( now currently Navient ), I was finally introduced to a program, in XXXX, by their company called " Interest Rate Reduction Program. '' It was explained then that I would have my interest rates dropped to 1 % and was required to have payments automatically debited from account. It was explained that if my account remained in good standing for the two years, and if I remained with automatic debit, that I would then be placed into this program for " the life of the loans '' ( their words not mine ). I remained in perfect standing at all times since. I would randomly receive letters requesting information be sent to the company in order to remain in the program. I would always call, and was always told to disregard the letter and that no information was needed because my loans were set to 1 % for " the life of the loans. '' Regular customer service representatives never knew what I was originally referring to and I would have to request to speak to someone in the " interest rate reduction program. '' I was told to ask for someone in this program as they were the only ones that understood and was told that there are many separate departments and that regular customer service agents aren't aware of all the different options. I then purchased my first home in XXXX and soon afterwards received another letter requesting information in order to remain in the program. Due to having more financially responsibility at hat point, I became nervous and during the call with an agent in the " interest rate reduction program, '' I requested to have a letter sent to me stating that I was in this program until the life of the loan. They said this was not an issue and mailed me a letter from Navient ( as they had already transitioned over ) right away. I have the letter and I have also uploaded the letter into my Navient account and confirmed with them that they have this documented in my file. I continued to receive random communication from Navient stating that the program will come to an end, however again I always called and was told that I am all set and was required to do nothing. Now, as of XX/XX/XXXX, they are telling me that in XXXX of XXXX I will no longer be at 1 %. I have spoken to many different people on the phone, tried to provide email documentation ( Navient reps never respond to my emails ), and have even spoken to their XXXX about the situation. They are now saying that having the letter stating that I will be at 1 % until XXXX ( they wrote and year of XXXX in the letter instead of saying " life of the loan '' but in calculating it I figured this was acceptable due to the loans would be paid off by that year ) doesn't matter. They also can not and will not tell me what they anticipate my interest rate to be come XX/XX/XXXX, and they stated that they weren't any " parameters '' to determine my new interest rate. I was also told that the only way to even consolidate would be to take out a loan with someone else, that they can not consolidate due to the loans being " private '' ( I was hopeful that if consolidated I would end up paying less ).

On XX/XX/XXXX I sent this letter to Navient : I was going over the numbers on my student loan that I have with NAVIENT, and I was astounded by the amount of money that I have paid in going to my principal vs the money going to the interest. I have been making payments since XXXX ( XXXX  years ) and have paid a total of {$31000.00}. My original amount that was disbursed was {$27000.00}, I am still showing a balance of {$21000.00} and my student loan will not be paid off until XXXX. 

Below are all the numbers that I have laid out : - Disbursement of student loan on XX/XX/XXXX was {$27000.00}. 

- As of XX/XX/XXXX, the total current student loan balance is {$21000.00}. 

- As of XX/XX/XXXX, I have paid {$31000.00} towards my student loans. 

- Loan interest is XXXX XXXX. 

- From the disbursement of the student loan to the current student loan balance it shows that I have paid {$5100.00} towards the principal. 

From my records that I pulled from NAVIENT, I have paid NAVIENT {$31000.00} since XXXX and my balance has only gone down {$5100.00} ( principal ). That being said, {$31000.00} - {$5100.00} = {$26000.00}, this has been how much interest I have paid towards the loan since XXXX. To date I have paid {$26000.00} just in interest! Thats insane considering my original loan amount was {$27000.00}! 

Could someone please tell me how this is acceptable? Its no wonder why the middle class can not get ahead. With these numbers, I can see why people are asking for student loan forgiveness. 

Im just looking for answers and help. I tried the income driven side of this and was told we make too much money. With inflation on everything, I know for a fact we dont make enough money. Please give me an explanation for this as I am just astonished by how much interest has been paid to date. 
________________________________________________________________ Navient 's response was that I was not eligible for an income-based repayment plan and that I had a promissory note to go by and that since the loans were consolidated the terms changed and I forfeited any benefits from the existing loan. 
________________________________________________________________ My issue is that I have been paying this student loan for a long time now and the balance isn't going down. I consolidated the loan because I was told that was the best course of action for me, that was a lie and lead to forfeiting any benefits I had with my prior loan ( s ). Also, they told me my best bet was to go into forbearance or deferment if I could not make the payments. I did so because they suggested that, and I assumed that I was being lead in the right direction. Navient has been nothing but hard to deal with and it seems like I've not been lead in the right direction. Even when it came down to me trying to lower my monthly payment, they stated I made too much money and didn't qualify, they acted like they didn't want to deal with me. So, at this point since I've tried working with NAVIENT and have gotten nowhere and I've made over {$31000.00} in payments, I feel like I should have the balance forgiven. 

I started with a {$27000.00} student loan, I've paid {$31000.00} back and still owe {$21000.00}. With some forbearance/deferments in there I've been paying on it for roughly XXXX years and have only managed to knock off roughly {$5100.00} off the principal. I find that to be ridiculous. 
Please help!

Consumer complaint narrative:
In conjunction with a previous complaint filed regarding Navients high-default rate predatory loans and XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX misconduct ( CFPB complaint XXXX ), I would like to submit an additional complaint asking for my School Misconduct Application to be reassessed. ( THIS IS NOT A DUPLICATE COMPLAINT ) On XX/XX/XXXX Navient provided a School Misconduct Discharge application to my account inbox indicating that I could be eligible for discharge on applicable loans. I filled out the XXXX XXXX XXXX application and submitted it to XXXX XXXX XXXX  on XX/XX/XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX, I received both an email confirmation and a Navient Inbox message stating that my School Misconduct Discharge application was received by Navient. On XX/XX/XXXX, I received both an email confirmation and a Navient Inbox message with a letter stating that my School Misconduct Discharge application was denied. The letter stated that my applicable private student loans are not eligible for discharge due to the following reason ( s ) : Navient carefully considers a variety of factors in determining whether a private loan should be XXXX based on school misconduct and you do not meet the requirements for discharge based on misconduct by your school. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I sent an email to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX at XXXX XXXX XXXX requesting a detailed explanation of how and why my application did not meet the requirements for discharge based on misconduct by my school. On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX of Navient sent a physical letter to my home address that included a generic, blanket response that they have sent to other XXXX XXXX XXXX who were denied as well. I believe XXXX decision to deny my School Misconduct Discharge application was an inaccurate and unfair response to my experience as a student at a scam school ( XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX ). 
I am aware of XXXX decision to settle for {$1.00} XXXX when sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, like myself, were excluded from the settlement. Im also aware that XXXX XXXX XXXX  ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) was won by the Plaintiff in XXXX, XXXX where The XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) was recognized as a scam school by XXXX XXXX XXXX. Yes, the case is regarding federal student loans but I am referencing the acknowledgment of my school being a scam school and the loans they distributed ( which would include XXXX loans, of course ). Under the FTCs " XXXX XXXX, predatory student loans in Navients portfolio are subject to claims and defenses based on well-established school misconduct and predatory lending. It appears Navient is refusing to grant discharge in order to keep people like myself who have paid the original principle 2 times over as passive income and let the people who refuse to pay anything go because Navient doesnt want to waste overhead chasing and begging defaulting borrowers to pay. In a letter to President & CEO of The Navient Corporation, XXXX XXXX acknowledged that on XX/XX/XXXX, Navient announced it will outsource the servicing of XXXX XXXX student loans to XXXX in the coming months. But a large portion of these loans are eligible for cancellation. Navient is aware that borrowers have meritorious defenses to the enforcement and collection of these loans, and has set aside at least {$35.00} XXXX in anticipation of claims or defenses being brought against Navient for misconduct. For borrowers like myself, Navient shouldnt have to set aside {$35.00} XXXX in anticipation for legal action as I have already paid the original principal 2 times over and my accumulative payments do not constitute a loss for the company. Accounts like mine who qualify for federal discharge and who have paid the original principle back 200 %, should be XXXX if this company had any integrity. At this point, its greed and avoiding unaccountability that is driving this company. These factors, along with other lawsuits against Navient makes me question the integrity and business practices of them and schools like the XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  for which they have done business with. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a Notice of Borrower Defense Discharge Approval from The United States Department of Education. The notice stated that The U.S. Department of Education ( ED ) has determined that the federal student loan ( XXXX ) you received to attend XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX on or after XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and on or before XXXX XXXX, XXXX, are eligible for a full discharge. This means the remaining balance on the eligible loan ( s ) will be forgiven. Your loan ( s ) will be discharged based on an XXXX finding that XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX made pervasive and widespread substantial misrepresentations that borrowers relied on to their detriment. The XXXX.S. Department of Educations criteria is in part based on my schools misconduct. This confirms XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX misconduct in relation to my experience. If The U.S. Department of Education was able to identify my schools misconduct and the impact it had on me as a borrower, I do not believe XXXX denial of my application is fair or moral. I believe XXXX criteria for XXXX XXXX XXXX approval needs to be evaluated and investigated for legitimacy. 

As of today, I have paid {$54000.00} on this loan. The principal amount on the loan was {$25000.00} and the current balance as of XX/XX/XXXX is {$35000.00}. After 12 years of paying the loan and not missing payments, I have paid the loan twice already. Navient has made it so that most of my payments only apply to the interest on the loan with {$0.00} being applied to my principal on over half of the loan payments. After capitalized interest-grace end and repayment fee, when the loan repayment period started in XX/XX/XXXX, the balance was {$36000.00}. For me to have paid {$54000.00} over a 12 year span and the principal balance to only go down {$1600.00} is a prime example of Navients plan to have borrowers like myself in debt forever. These predatory loan practices are a prime example of the schools misconduct as my for-profit school and Navient looked to have worked hand in hand to distribute these high-default rate predatory loans to student borrowers like myself.

Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these online for profit schools, such as XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX An Affiliate of XXXX XXXX ( who purchased XXXX XXXX XXXX in late XXXX ), and my Fed. loans of approx {$50000.00} were discharged and my credit repaired.

I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit online schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative: I went to XXXX XXXX from XXXX. Before I applied and got accepted, the school had a prestigious reputation. There were some rumors and talks about a lawsuit where there were false claims from the school telling students they would make certain amounts of money. Everyone working at the school reassured me and the prospective students that these claims were in the past and the school was different now. Of course, I believed it and proceeded to apply to the school and be surprised when I got accepted thinking it meant they liked my work and saw potential in my photography. Then shortly after I started going to XXXX XXXX, it got sold to XXXX. Immediately everything changed. They sold the old school where XXXX XXXX started. XXXX changed a bunch of staff members. And as a young adult, I got pressured in to always applying for and taking the maximum amont of student loans that I could. Even after asking why because I could tell it was too much, the " counselors '' pressured me in to taking the max amount. I was told multiple times to take the max amount and then immediately pay back whatever I thought I didn't need. Looking back, I see how obviously predatory this was but at the time I did not know any better. I was not alone in this practice. All of my friends and classmates that needed help paying for the extremely expensive schooling were told the same things. Take the max amount whether you need it or not. We were also told time and time again that we could come out of school and immediately be making upwards of XXXX per year as XXXX XXXX Few of my classmates found work as XXXX  and none of them made anywhere near that amount. XXXX and XXXX XXXX lied and preyed on students repeatedly for many years. This is why all students who attended that school should have their loans canceled and all the money, including interest, should be returned to the students who fell victim to that predatory school. To date, I have paid {$97000.00} in private loans and I'm one of the lucky ones that managed to have a relatively lower, though still predatory and ridiculous, amount coming out of that school.
