XXXX XXXX Loan : Principal {$30.00}, XXXX, with Interest {$50000.00} - PAID IN FULL Percentage of income, based on Social Security income data from personal profile : 2008-  XXXX XXXX XXXX  Loan only- XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 2020- {$21000.00} ( collected XXXX, restaurant closed whole year ) - stopped making payment XX/XX/XXXX, in-school deferment ; attendance compliments of family who belong XXXX XXXX 2021- XXXX XXXX in-school deferment Did not know could have filed for Borrowers Defense, would have done it in the first year of repayment once Id learned just how worthless the degree is after multiple interviews and low management job offers o Have had substantial revolving debt since graduation to cover costs of living o Have been unable to manage savings and setting aside any money for retirement Additional complaints : o School lied about graduation rates and job opportunities available on graduation o NO real leads on jobs or career services o Told my father and I we had to take loans from Sallie Mae, as they were the only loan company they worked with ; we didnt know we could have gone to a credit union or another institution ( I am the first student in my family to take out student loans ) o Lied about the income we would earn and that prestigious institutions would require a degree Applied for work at XXXX XXXX XXXX via XXXX ; at that time, no one in the kitchen had attended culinary school and all management treated these degrees with very little respect and a lot of skepticism. They are more interested in hiring people who are trainable Earned far more as a server than what was offered in most management positions ; this is a problem known industry-wide that the school failed to mention at ANY point ; couldnt stop being a server to guarantee income to meet financial obligations as have no safety net o NO company hires people directly into management ; vast majority of establishments want to start you as a server and move you up as openings occur, very little to no formal training. Industry attitude is largely this is how we do it, we dont care how they do it elsewhere and this is how weve always done it School colluded with Sallie Mae loan servicer to extend loans that were designed to fail which are now managed by Navient Navient & Its Role In The Student Loan Crisis Explained ( XXXX ) Loans Designed to Fail : States Say Navient Preyed on Students - XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX ( XXXX ) Students Claim Sallie Mae XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : Students Claim Sallie Mae XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  ) - Sallie Mae aided and abetted a fraudulent culinary school by issuing student loans at " credit card rates, '' XXXX students claim in a federal class action. 
Lead plaintiff XXXX XXXX sued SLM XXXX and Sallie Mae, claiming they aided and abetted fraud at the XXXX  XXXX XXXX, which is not named as a defendant. 
SLM and its subsidiaries own, manage and service more than XXXX XXXX student loans totaling more than {$230.00} XXXX, according to the XXXX complaint. 
XXXX  XXXX XXXX has been sued repeatedly. XXXX of its recruiters sued the school in XX/XX/XXXX, claiming the companies that run the for-profit college " run the school like a used-car lot, preying on vulnerable students ... saddling them with loans they can not pay back, '' Courthouse News reported at the time. 
In a XX/XX/XXXX class action, the XXXX named plaintiffs claimed they each ran up {$50000.00} in debts for an education worth no more than {$2000.00}. Both those complaints were in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
According to the new complaint : " Sallie Mae misled plaintiffs and committed other unlawful conduct of its own, causing plaintiffs to take out enormous loans with credit-card interest rates, when Sallie Mae knew that these students had a relatively small likelihood of being able to repay the loans in full. Plaintiffs now seek to get their lives back on track by having Sallie Mae bear its fair share of the losses. 
" Plaintiffs had no idea that attending XXXX was an economically irrational act. Plaintiffs did not know that a XXXX education has little or no value. Nor did they understand that at no relevant time has there been a job market for XXXX graduates that pays sufficient wages to enable graduates to pay down the substantial debt they must incur to finance XXXX 's exorbitant education. 
" Sallie Mae knew these facts when it issued plaintiffs their high-interest private education loans ( 'high-interest private loans ' ) to pay for their XXXX education. It further knew that XXXX needed Sallie Mae to extend these loans in order to carry out its fraudulent recruiting scheme, and Sallie Mae, seeking to profit, happily obliged. The results harm to the plaintiffs has been catastrophic. 
" Moreover, Sallie Mae knew at all relevant times that there was an unusually high probability that plaintiffs would be unable to make the full payments necessary to keep these high-interest private loans from falling into delinquency and default. And Sallie Mae knew that plaintiffs did not know this. Yet, intent on issuing as many of these loans as possible, Sallie Mae purposefully did not tell plaintiffs any of these facts. 
ADVERTISEMENT " When Sallie Mae loaned XXXX purchase money to plaintiffs, it knew XXXX students were defaulting on much smaller, lower-interest federal student loans at rates that substantially exceeded the rates at which traditional college students default on such loans. Sallie Mae knew that by setting very high interest rates ( typically in the range of XXXX percent ) on its high-interest private loans-often XXXX to XXXX times larger than on federal loans-it was significantly diminishing plaintiffs ' chances of fully repaying these loans. Sallie Mae further knew that this would likely result in significantly raising the plaintiff class 's high-interest private loan default rates relative to traditional student loan default rates. Sadly, this likelihood has been realized ; the putative class has defaulted at extraordinarily high rates. '' The school lured students with a string of false promises, the class claims. 
" Among XXXX 's false and misleading representations were the following : ( a ) admission to XXXX was a competitive and selective process ; ( b ) a XXXX education increases graduates ' incomes and opportunities in the food-service industry to a degree that makes a XXXX  education well worth the sky-high tuition ( approximately {$48000.00} for the XXXX XXXX XXXX, {$28000.00} for the Baking and Pastry Program, and {$38000.00} for the Management Program ) and corresponding student-loan debt ; ( c ) XXXX  has an extensive network of contacts and close relationships with prestigious restaurants and other food-service employers where XXXX  graduates can easily obtain employment in one or more of the positions for which XXXX  promises to train them ; ( d ) XXXX  has an excellent reputation, and graduates will benefit from that reputation by being able to gain better and more prestigious jobs with a XXXX  degree than without one ; ( e ) XXXX  students have an extremely high rate of job placement in jobs for which the students seek to be trained ; and ( f ) the programs can be financed through student loans, with a resulting debt service burden that is reasonable and manageable in light of the income opportunities available to graduate, '' according to the complaint. 
Sallie Mae knowingly aided and abetted this fraud for its own profit, the complaint states : " XXXX had an agreement with Sallie Mae to recommend Sallie Mae as a 'preferred lender ' to prospective students : Sallie Mae would provide these students high-interest private loans to pay the balance of their educational costs not covered by federal grants and loans. '' Sallie Mae conducted its own research and analysis of XXXX 's graduation rates and employment statistics of its graduates, so it knew what was going on, the class claims : " Sallie Mae was acutely aware, by the time plaintiffs and class members sought loans to attend XXXX, that a XXXX education was not worth what it had been a decade prior, that a significant percentage of XXXX XXXX students were unemployed or making very low wages, and that XXXX students were financially unable to repay fully the high-interest private loans. '' XXXX of the XXXX lead plaintiffs are unemployed and all XXXX say they owe significantly more money on their loans than what they took out. 
Plaintiff XXXX XXXX claims he took out a {$45000.00} loan at XXXX percent interest. The balance has grown to {$140000.00}. He says he works as a line cook at a restaurant where he makes {$14.00} an hour. 
Plaintiff XXXX XXXX took out XXXX loans totaling {$16000.00} to finance her education at XXXX. She has already paid {$14000.00}, but with an interest rate of XXXX percent, her balance remains {$42000.00}, according to the lawsuit. 
" XXXX XXXX 's only culinary-related employment since she graduated from XXXX was a XXXX-month job as a cashier in a corporate dining cafeteria, where she occasionally performed light preparation work in the kitchen, '' the complaint states. " Her hourly wage was {$9.00}. She was unable to find any other culinary work after being laid off from this position, and she believes her XXXX credential actually hurt her culinary-job prospects. '' According to the complaint : " The sad, true fact is that a XXXX education does not significantly increase graduates ' incomes and opportunities in the food-service industry. XXXX 's reputation has plummeted since the XXXX. Indeed, food-industry personnel and potential employers snicker that XXXX stands for XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX. ' '' While plaintiffs and the class are saddled with debts they can not repay, Sallie Mae has benefited in XXXX ways, the complaint states : " First, Sallie Mae profited, and intended to profit, by inflating its balance sheet with billions of dollars of loans to plaintiffs and others at similar non-traditional schools. Sallie Mae 's scheme intentionally inflated its stock price and attracted potential acquirers. 
" Second, because the high-interest private loans have such high interest and Sallie Mae 's own cost of funds is so low, Sallie Mae can profit even if the loans are never repaid fully. " Sallie Mae 's cost of funds ( estimated at XXXX percent to XXXX percent ) is negligible compared to its high-interest private loans ' typical compound interest rates of XXXX percent. 
" Third, because student loans generally are not dischargeable in bankruptcy, Sallie Mae can squeeze out small amounts of money from the student borrowers for the rest of their lives. Sallie Mae demands plaintiffs ' small paychecks, even when the payments do not cover the accumulating interest, allowing Sallie Mae to profit while the XXXX students ' high-interest private loan balances continue to increase. '' Sallie Mae has acknowledged that it knew the students would not be able to repay the loans, the class claims. 
" Sallie Mae 's chairman acknowledged that these loans were 'predictably not collectible. ' He admitted that many students attending XXXX and other similarly valueless schools likely would never be able to earn sufficient income to repay in full the loans they were taking out, '' the complaint states. 
It adds : " Ignoring the financial burden its actions placed on borrowers, Sallie Mae blithely extended loans it never expected to be repaid fully- all for the purpose of manipulating its financial reports and increasing its revenue. Sallie Mae was fully aware there was a reasonable likelihood that plaintiffs and class members would be unable to repay their high-interest private loans in full. Yet it intentionally failed to disclose this highly relevant information to plaintiffs and class members at the time that it issued their high-interest private loans. '' Sallie Mae owns the class members ' " high-interest private loans under various names, '' the complaint states. It serviced the high-interest private loans under the name Sallie Mae XXXX XXXX XXXX which was a division of SLM until XXXX XXXX, XXXX, when Sallie Mae XXXX XXXX was merged into Sallie Mae XXXX , which took over the loan servicing. 
Plaintiffs seek declaratory judgment, rescission of loan contracts, and disgorgement of unjust profits. They also want compensatory and punitive damages for aiding and abetting fraud, unjust enrichment, and unfair competition. 
They are represented by XXXX XXXX.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Co-signer
Consumer complaint narrative: I have always struggled to be able to pay my student loan payment every month and on time. Between the poor payment history ruining my grandfather 's ( cosigner ) previously great credit and Navient beginning to call us each 3-8+ times a day every single day from the first day after the payment due date until the full payment was made ( which meant often we would get nonstop calls for over a month or two straight! ), my grandparents were severely distressed all the time. My grandfather called Navient to see what needed to be done to have him removed as the cosigner on my loan and they told him that if the loan payment was made on time every month for 12 consecutive months that we could have him removed as the cosigner, so my grandparents, who were already retired and on a fixed income, set up autopay and began paying my loan on XX/XX/XXXX. They even paid it for an extra 5 months, a total of {$3800.00}, to ensure there was sufficient enough good payment history for him to be removed. When they called Navient to have him removed I forget the exact claims Navient made, but I believe it was that my loan type was not eligible to have the cosigner removed at all, ever. I began attempting to pay the loan myself again and still struggled to pay it every month and on time, and forbearances were very difficult to get, at most once or twice a year, and when I did get them they were never for more than 1-3 months, so the nonstop harassment calls from Navient continued and my grandparents credit suffered more as well. In early XXXX I wasn't in a position to be able to pay my loan so my grandparents began paying it for what was supposed to be a few months, just long enough for me to get back on my feet. I was with Navient for several years until recently now I'm with XXXX XXXX XXXX.

I believed that I would qualify for this. When I tried to get information on whether or not I qualified, I found out that Navient misled me and pushed me into a XXXX standard repayment plan. Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX I emailed Navient to request a School Misconduct Discharge application for a Signature Student private loan that was dispersed to my school XX/XX/XXXX. 

On XX/XX/XXXX I received an email response from Navient 's Office of the Customer Advocate stating my loan is not eligible for its School Misconduct discharge program because the school that certified my loan was a nonprofit institution. 

On XX/XX/XXXX I responded to Navient 's email asking : ( 1 ) why nonprofit schools are not eligible for its School Misconduct Discharge ; and ( 2 ) if it was true that Navient 's application was changed in XX/XX/XXXX to stipulate nonprofit schools are ( now ) ineligible. 

Prior to XX/XX/XXXX, Navient did not stipulate that eligibility for the School Misconduct Discharge was only applicable to loans dispersed to for-profit schools. Navient changed its School Misconduct application XX/XX/XXXX, confirmed by Project on Predatory Student Lending ( PPSL ). This change in criteria is both recent and significant, and was not a consideration when my loan was initially certified. 

On XX/XX/XXXX a notice was uploaded to my inbox on Navient 's internet platform, signed by XXXX XXXX with the Office of the Customer Advocate. It stated the denial was solely based on the claim that the Holder Rule it employs only applies to private loans distributed to for-profit schools. My question : why were nonprofit schools eligible prior to XX/XX/XXXX? Navient failed to answer or address this question. 

DETAILS OF SCHOOL MISCONDUCT : 1. Misrepresentations and Misleading Information : My school made several misrepresentations regarding its education quality, graduate designation, graduate employability, and program offerings. 
My school mislead me, and possibly others, about the availability of federal student loans. 

2. Financial Aid Information : In XXXX the Financial Aid Department at my school informed me I had reached the aggregate limit for federal loans, which was false. 
My school failed to inform me about the availability of the Grad PLUS Loan, which I was eligible for. Instead, my school only offered to certify the Signature Student Loan through Navient ( then Sallie Mae ). 

I question the relationship between Navient and my school, regardless of its nonprofit status, based on information like : Navient allegedly made loans as an inducement to get schools to use Navient as a preferred lender for highly-profitable... private loans, without regard for borrowers and their families, many of whom were unknowingly ensnared in debts they could never repay. ( XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ) And : " ... an investigation into student lending practices found that lenders paid kickbacks to colleges and their employees for steering business their way ... '' ( XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ) FINANCIAL HARDSHIP : My school certified the Signature Student Loan for {$24000.00} . To date, I have paid {$27000.00} towards this loan, yet the current balance is {$37000.00}. 
My monthly payments of {$520.00} cover only interest, and I am unable to afford higher payments. 
My debt-to-earnings ratio is 865 %, and I have no other debt aside from student loans.

XX/XX/XXXX, I paid a total of {$750.00} to loans XXXX Consolidation ( {$350.00} ), XXXXXXXX XXXX Subsidized ( {$200.00} ), and XXXX XXXX Unsubsidized ( {$200.00} ) online on Navient.com. Once the payment was processed, the updated balances for these loans reflected updated payments for XXXX ( {$8800.00} ), XXXX ( {$2200.00} ), and XXXX ( {$4600.00} ). 
However, XXXX weeks later, XXXX, my newly acquired loan servicer, said that loans XXXX Consolidation and XXXX XXXX Unsubsidized had successfully transferred with balance on loans XXXX ( {$9100.00} ) and XXXX ( {$4800.00} ). The balances did not reflect XXXX 's payment and were the same as the XX/XX/XXXX balance on loans XXXX ( {$9100.00} ) and XXXX ( {$4800.00} ). XX/XX/XXXX was the last time Navient applied my payment to loans despite Navient updating the loan balances in XX/XX/XXXX. 
I have contacted Navient by phone and email to get the payment/adjustment returned. I have copies of email correspondence telling me to wait 20 days, approximately in XXXX XXXX. Between XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, I received instructions on uploading proof of payment, which I did twice. My documents were successfully uploaded and then deleted. I called and emailed Navient 's customer service team and was to contact XXXX because payment was sent to them. I did contact by phone and through the website. Customer service sent me a letter stating that they received no payments directly from me or through Navient. I have continued to contact Navient and the customer service team through email. All responses from Navient including from Office of the Customer Advocate, Sr. Customer Advocate XXXX XXXX state this matter has been resolved. 
Time and time this company has been allowed to commit financial robbery by changing loan terms for their profit and then refusing to adjust same terms.

Consumer complaint narrative: My student loan is being serviced by Navient. Since XXXX, when I lost my job with XXXX XXXX, I was attempting to get an Income Based Repayment plan. I was able to get my mortgage modified to a lower interest rate through the Making Home Affordable - Modification program. However, I repeatedly requested that Navient move me into an income based repayment plan. They would not, instead they pushed me over in a forbearance. I did not need a forbearance and was not alerted as to the exact date that the forbearance began or ended. Once I was aware that I was in a forbearance, I continuously requested a income based repayment but was told I did not qualify for one. In conclusion, the forbearance ended without my knowledge, I was not making payments because I could not ascertain the amount I needed to pay and now my credit is destroyed because the record shows I have non-payment dates on my student loan accounts. Although I have sent numerous request via the credit bureaus to remove the non-payment and slow payment credit information, Navient has not. I explained to them that I was told that I was in a forbearance and did not have to make payments. At this point I do not know what to do to get this negative information removed from my credit file. Additionally, I believe this debt should have been forgiven as part of the school loan forgiveness program. Please assist me in dealing with Navient. I am an XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX vet and have been paying these school loans since early XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Concerned Parties, I write to bring to light a matter of grave concern affecting thousands of students ensnared in the predatory lending practices of Navient, particularly those who, like myself, attended for-profit online institutions such as the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

It is a stark reality that the XXXX XXXX, along with their parent company, XXXX, have been subjected to investigations by numerous state attorneys general, resulting in damning findings of fraudulent activities. 

Recently, in response to the egregious actions of institutions like the XXXX XXXX, the XXXX  administration has taken a commendable step by announcing a sweeping discharge of loans for individuals enrolled at these institutions between XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX. This move offers a glimmer of hope for those burdened by the weight of unjust debt. 

As I await the impending discharge of my federal loans and the subsequent repair of my credit, I am compelled to address the insidious practices of Navient. Not only have I dutifully repaid a significant portion of my original loans, including interest in the amount of {$41000.00} in Federal loans and {$31000.00} in Private loans, but I also demand restitution for the predatory behavior exhibited by Navient. 

The symbiotic relationship between Navient and for-profit online schools, facilitated by preferential lending arrangements, is a stain on the integrity of the education finance system. It is evident that these loans, fraught with a high risk of default, were designed to exploit vulnerable students, leaving many in financial ruin. 

Navient 's track record of malfeasance extends beyond its collusion with for-profit institutions. The company has faced legal action from state attorneys general, allegations of deceptive loan practices, and accusations of illegal collection methods. Their recent attempts to absolve themselves of responsibility through superficial " pilot programs '' are a slap in the face to those who have suffered at their hands. 

Under the FTC " Holder Rule, '' Navient bears accountability for its role in perpetuating predatory lending practices, particularly in conjunction with online for-profit schools. Time is of the essence for Navient to rectify the injustices inflicted upon students who were lured into a web of deceit and financial exploitation. 

The call to action has been sounded by esteemed voices such as XXXX XXXX XXXX, who rightfully demands immediate discharge of these predatory loans. It is incumbent upon Navient to heed this clarion call and take swift and decisive action to alleviate the burdens of those they have wronged. This should also include refunds for payments made on these predatory loans. 

In conclusion, I implore all stakeholders to recognize the urgency of this matter and to stand in solidarity with those seeking redress. The time for accountability and restitution is now. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

I communicated to them multiple times that this is my work number every two weeks, and provided to them my specific schedule for when this is not my work phone number. I also told them during weekdays, this is my work number until XXXX. 

From what I understand, debt collectors can call you up to 7 times per week, not 7 times a day. I called them to submit a complaint, and to ask them to stop calling me and to stop the disruption the XXXX of the patients at the XXXX  I am employed at during these hours. They have not complied. 

The person I spoke to said they are legally allowed to call me up to 7 times per day. I spoke with a supervisor there and she kept talking over me and not letting me speak, and kept reinforcing that they are allowed to repeatedly call me on my work phone number.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/XXXX I enrolled at XXXX XXXX for XXXX XXXX in XXXX, CA. During the admissions process, it was determined that I did not qualify for federal student loans due to family income levels. The school recommended that I take out private student loans with a company they had a relationship with which would cease servicing XXXX students soon. I learned in XXXX that the reason for this is that XXXX had legal and financial troubles that threatened its accreditation. In my sophomore, junior and senior years XXXX recommended that I and a co-signer apply for private student loans through Sallie Mae which later were transferred to Navient. I was warned during these periods that if I failed to promptly get a private loan or find some other way to pay for enrollment, that I would be kicked out of classes and my credits would not be able to transfer to other colleges including credits for XXXX courses I had already completed. During every enrollment period I was strongly encouraged by the school to take out private student loans to attend either directly or by being threatened that I would be removed and my credits would not be transferrable to continue my education elsewhere. 

When I began attending in XXXX, the school promised job placement assistance via an organized externship program. Prior to my graduation in XX/XX/XXXX the externship program was suspended. When I attempted to use the job placement assistance programs, the information provided was almost universally out of date, incorrect, or pointed students to the wrong points of contact. Myself and the majority of other graduating students in my class had extreme difficulty finding employment within our fields, and nearly all graduating students in my class did not find stable permanent employment until we stopped searching for jobs relevant to our specific degrees such as public service sector and retail work. 

The records I have show that between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX I paid approximately {$45000.00} to Navient and Sallie Mae to attend a school that used high pressure tactics, deceptive advertising, and changed service expectations to deceive students into overpaying for limited services. I refinanced my student loans in XXXX and still owed over {$65000.00} in principal. My original tuition was calculated as {$49000.00} plus stipends worth {$21000.00} for a total of {$70000.00} for my sophomore, junior, and senior years. 

I believe that under the Holder Rule, my payments made between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX were made for a deceptive or fraudulent service. On XX/XX/XXXX I submitted a request for a School Misconduct Discharge Application. I received a rejection later that morning stating that my loans were closed at Navient and are not eligible for the School Misconduct Discharge Application. Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been paying on this loan for what seems like forever and I decided to perform research to see what the issue is and why my balance doesnt seem to be reducing. I began repaying this loan on XX/XX/XXXX and then took several iterations of forbearance periods due to school enrollments. 

Recently, I noticed that sometimes more than half of my payment is used to pay interest, which is REDICULOUS! After searching for payment allocations for Navients private student loans, I stumbled upon the Navient AG Multi-State Settlement of XXXX. To my surprise, I actually believe my loan was eligible for debt cancellation and I never received any notification or the actual cancellation!

Heres the criteria for the private student loan debt cancellation and restitution and my loan details are in parenthesis : The private loan debt relief will primarily go to borrowers who took out private subprime student loans ( made to borrowers with low credit scores ) through Navients predecessor, Sallie Mae, between XXXX and XXXX, and then had more than seven consecutive months of delinquent payments prior to XX/XX/XXXX. 

( this is me ; loan disbursement says XXXX in the system but I see disbursements from XXXX and there have been XXXX consecutive late payments- XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX ) The debt relief also includes certain other, non-subprime private student loans made by Sallie Mae Bank and certain other lenders between XXXX and XXXX for borrowers to attend specific for-profit schools that have been subject to state or federal law enforcement actions. A list of these for-profit schools is shown in the table below. 
o In many cases, large numbers of federal borrowers who attended these schools have sought cancellation of their federal student loans by filing Borrower Defense to Loan Repayment Applications alleging school misconduct. 

( My school was on this list XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ; my Borrower Defense to Loan Repayment Application was approved for my federal loans and they were discharged ) Generally, to be eligible for private loan debt relief, the borrower must have fallen behind on payments by more than seven months at some point before XX/XX/XXXX ( again, my XXXX consecutive late payments were assessed on XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX. ) Generally, only loans that were within a statute of limitations period or still credit-reporting as of XX/XX/XXXX are within the scope of the debt relief ( XXXX STILL paying on this loan and it is still reporting ) To qualify for the Navient settlement, your mailing address on file with Navient as XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, must have been in XXXX of these states : Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, District of Columbia XXXX Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, Nevada, New Jersey XXXX New Mexico XXXX New York XXXX North Carolina XXXX Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island XXXX South Carolina XXXX Tennessee, Vermont, Virginia, West Virginia XXXX Washington, and Wisconsin. 

( I live in XXXX  and I have my whole life ) Now, Im not sure if I was inadvertently left out of the private loan discharge and restitution group, but I believe my case warrants a further look into what has been going on with my account. I have called multiple times over the last few years and I am tiredtired of the run around, the lack of sufficient documentation being sent after I request it and the lack of knowledge around what has happened with my account. 

I recently submitted the application for private student loan forgiveness for school misconduct on XX/XX/XXXX ; it was denied but I wasnt given a reason. Navient simply stated that they dont give reasons for denials but I can reapply using their archaic process. 

Long story short : I have paid a total of {$9900.00} on what seems to be a {$3100.00} loan that STILL has a {$2500.00} balance on it and isnt scheduled to be paid off until XX/XX/XXXX ( and I make more than the minimum payment as well ). This would almost be laughable if it were happening in a movie or some TV show but this is my life and I have been ( and Im still being ) robbed. Im sure there are LOAN SHARKS that would service my account better than Navient.

Consumer complaint narrative: I have experienced resistance to receive information on the school misconduct loan discharge as well as the application from Navient. After much persistence on my behalf, Navient forwarded me application, but informed me that my application would be automatically denied. In XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted the application & received an email from Navient on XX/XX/XXXX, stating that my student loan did not qualify for discharge because the funds were sent directly to me & not the XXXX & also because XXXX XXXX XXXX was a non-profit school. I responded to Navient to provide with me with their eligibility criteria in which they are basing their school misconduct discharge decisions on, & also for the loan origination documents. I received my loan origination documents, however did not receive any information in regards to how Navient was basing their decisions. Upon reviewing the loan origination documents, the documents confirm that the funds were sent directly to XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX not directly to me as Navient is claiming. On XXXX XXXX, I received an official denial letter from Navient, once again stating that my loan did not qualify for discharge due to my loan being a private loan, & also the school being non-profit, referencing the Holder Rule federal regulation & siting XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  as the basis of their decision. I contacted the FTC for further information regarding their Holder Rule & upon researching the FTCs & The Project on Predatory Student Lending Holder Rule articles, the Holder Rule qualifies private student loans as part of the school misconduct loan discharge. Additionally, the federal case XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX that Navient is citing, the Memorandum Opinion applies to Truth-in-Lending Disclosure, Bankruptcy, & Unreasonable Credit & Appraisal fees as it pertains to Mortages, & is not an applicable motion pertaining to student loan misconduct discharge consumer protective rights.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I was contacted by the Department of education on XX/XX/year>, regarding my federal debt with the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX regarding that my federal debt was forgiven due to finding of fradulent practices and engaging in unlawful conduct. In the weeks following. I became aware, through the PPSL, that Navient had quietly offered a School Misconduct forgivness application. 

On XX/XX/year> I reached out to Navient 's consumer advocate email after receiving the above notice and requested documentation to allow me to apply for forgiveness for my Private loans due to the unlawful conduct. Navient responded within 3 days and I received my School Misconduct application from Navient and started gathering information from various groups organizing for forgiveness from XXXXXXXX XXXX misconduct XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. There was very little guidance on how to properly fill out the form so I applied several documents regarding the fraud perpetuated by XXXX, my personal circumstances and whatever evidence I could find. 

I completed the form on XXXX XXXX and submitted it to Navient on XX/XX/XXXX. Navient received my completed form on XX/XX/XXXX and notified me of a forbearance on my account stating that it was needed to process the review for my forgiveness. I didn't receive any additional correspondence from Navient following the submission. 

I submitted additional evidence to the same email account with the hopes of improving the documentation on XX/XX/XXXX. This email was not responded to either automatically or otherwise. 

On XX/XX/year>, I received documentation from Navient stating that my application for school misconduct discharge was DENIED for the following reasons " Navient carefully considers a variety of factors in determining whether a private loan should be discharged based on school misconduct and you do not meet the requirements for discharge based on misconduct by your school. '' I am currently attempting to gather more information and attempting to contact the advocate 's office to figure out whether or not I can appeal the decision, or if I can resubmit with evidence, but I haven't been able to find much more evidence. 

I submitted several letters from XXXX XXXX. Several documented cases, from the ED and the DOJ and submitted the case pertaining to the federal government forgiving my debt due to misconduct, and several personal unredacted documents. Without more insight into why Navient denied me. I've been placed back into repayment without any means of recourse. Frankly, if Navient can deny the federal government 's findings, the whole process seems to be arbitrary and biased. 

Since my application XXXX and several other senators have reached out to Navient, telling them that they had improperly denied several school misconduct discharge applications, but I'm currently waiting in the lurch to figure out what I need to do now.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX requested to consider my loans for a reduced rate in XX/XX/XXXX, the rep advised she would put the information in to have some payment relief for the remaining 4 months of interest only. Which I didnt know at the time that the agent didnt add all the loans to this program. This is where Navinet makes a lot of its money ( purposely misallocating payments, and leaving out loans to attach late fees ) Obscured information consumers need to maintain their lower payments. 

XX/XX/XXXX My cosigner then received a letter advising that my loans were in default and advised me. I promptly called and the agent XXXX advised that not all my loans were added, and some were in default. I then advised rep that I didnt realize that the previous agent left some of the loans out of the program for reduced payments, as doing some research online this is a common practice with Navinet . Each month a payment was auto deducted, yet they leave out loans purposely. Rep advised to make a payment of {$150.00} to keep my account out of collections and in the interim to complete my documents for my in-school deferment ( which I requested on this call ). 

XX/XX/XXXX I received a collections call advising that my account was in default and that I would need to make another payment of {$150.00}, however, I tried to explain to Navinet agent and urged her to read the call notes from the previous call to confirm payment to this week. She advised I needed to make another payment that would keep me out of collections and to submit my in-school deferment letter. She then pressured me to get that letter in, I advised rep that I just received the letter on XXXX and it was a holiday and to allow some time with the holiday. Navinet then proceeded to call and harass my cosigner with collection letters and calls. I tried to have my mother removed from my account, however, they deceived me about the requirements to release my mother as a co-signer. 

I have made payments to Navinet every month, yet Navinet practiced fraudulent tactics of leaving accounts out to incur late fees along with payment misallocation. I expect some level of competency with this business. I am fed up with the illegal tactics Navinet uses to drain money out of borrowers. I want a full audit of my account to possibly move forward with some legal recourse. This is ridiculous for these types of predatory lenders getting away with. Ive been paying my student loans for the past 20 years or so, however, I can not get ahead with the fraudulent tactics they do. Ive been told putting myself on auto pay would reduce my loan interest, each time Ive inquired about that, no agent can tell me anything. Ive been on autopay even through the pandemic trying to maintain a good credit score even as tough as that was. Im just disgusted with the practices/tactics Navinet has been doing for the past couple decades.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I'm filing this complaint against Navient, a previous student loan servicer. The account is now closed due to loan consolidation. In XX/XX/year>, Navient submitted a 90-day late payment notice to all three credit reporting bureaus. To the best of my knowledge, the loan was on deferment for years because of difficulty paying. Yearly, I would call to request a deferment. To the best of my knowledge, the deferment was good for a year. So, it was a surprise when XXXX notified me of negative information on my credit file. I had no information from Navient that the deferment had expired. 

Upon learning of the negative information reported on my credit file, first, I reached out to Navient about the negative information they had reported and requested they remove it. Customer service informed me they couldn't remove the information, only the credit bureaus could do so. I argued that was incorrect. Navient provided the information, therefore, Navient could contact the credit bureaus to have it removed. She refused to honor my request. 

Then, I contacted XXXX on XXXX occasions to dispute the negative information. Each time, XXXX simply forwarded my dispute to Navient and that was it. It did not show how it conducted its investigation. I even submitted an email showing the account was on deferment, to no avail. I have not had any success dealing with either institution. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I contacted them about the loan since Navient sent me an email regarding the change of status of the account. Of course, they had no information to provide and told me to call back in XXXX. I followed up again in XXXX just to be told that the account was closed due to consolidation, there was no information to provide. So confusing responses.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to file a formal complaint against Navient concerning the handling of my private student loans obtained to finance my education at a for-profit predatory school involved in the XXXX XXXX XXXX lawsuit. My details are as follows : I enrolled in XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) and transferred to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX and financed my education through private student loans serviced by Navient. Since completing my education, I have encountered numerous issues and concerns related to the loans and Navient 's practices, which I believe warrant investigation and action by your office. 

Specifically, my complaints against Navient include : 1. **Predatory Lending Practices** : The school misled students about the quality of education, career prospects upon graduation, and the true cost of attendance. The loans were granted without proper assessment of my ability to repay, and the interest rates were exorbitant. 

2. **Misleading Information** : Throughout my interactions with Navient, I have experienced instances of misleading or incomplete information regarding repayment options, interest rates, and eligibility for loan forgiveness programs.

3. **Servicing Issues** : Difficulty in accessing accurate loan information, frequent errors in billing statements, and challenges in receiving timely and accurate responses to inquiries or requests for assistance. 

4. **Lack of Support** : Despite attempting to work with Navient to explore repayment options or seek relief, I have encountered obstacles and a lack of proactive support in managing my student loan debt.

5. **Impact on Financial Well-being** : The financial burden imposed by these loans has had a significant and detrimental impact on my financial stability and overall well-being. 

Given the significant issues outlined above and the ongoing legal concerns related to the XXXX XXXX XXXX lawsuit involving similar predatory practices, I am requesting that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau thoroughly investigate Navient 's handling of private student loans associated with for-profit predatory schools. I also request that appropriate actions be taken to protect consumers like myself who have been adversely affected by these practices. 

I started my started my college education at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ), a predatory for-profit school in XX/XX/XXXX. I then transferred to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, another predatory for-profit school, in XX/XX/XXXX. Both of these schools are on the list of schools in the XXXX XXXX XXXX lawsuit. 

This is an explanation of all loans financed/owned by Navient ( Sallie Mae ) that I received to completed my college journey : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Signature Student - XX/XX/XXXX - {$13000.00} XXXX XXXX - Subsidized - XX/XX/XXXX - {$2600.00} XXXX Signature Student - XX/XX/XXXX - {$15000.00} XXXX XXXX XXXX Subsidized - XX/XX/XXXX - {$2300.00} Total : XXXX Student = {$29000.00} / XXXX  Subsidized = {$4900.00} Transferred to XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Technology XX/XX/XXXX : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX {$1300.00} XXXX XXXX - Subsidized - XX/XX/XXXX - {$3500.00} XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX - {$5300.00} Navient ( Sallie Mae ) consolidated all XXXX - Subsidized loans into the loan below : XXXX XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX - {$7900.00} Navient ( Sallie Mae ) also consolidated all my private Signature Student loans from XXXX XXXX XXXX with XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX to get the below loan : XXXX XXXX XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX XXXX {$34000.00} Once I started paying on all my loans after the grace period ended after my graduation from XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX these are the amounts paid : XXXX Career Training XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX {$5300.00} - paid {$8200.00} ( fully paid off on XX/XX/XXXX ) XXXX Consolidation - XX/XX/XXXX - {$7900.00} - paid {$9000.00} ( XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX ) still owed - {$4900.00} XXXX Private Consolidation - XX/XX/XXXX - {$34000.00} - paid {$27000.00} ( XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX ) still owed - {$19000.00} I paid a total of {$44000.00} on all loans serviced and owned by Navient ( Sallie Mae ) from XXXX through XXXX. I still owed Navient a total of {$24000.00} On XX/XX/XXXX Navient ( Sallie Mae ) convinced me to refinance that {$24000.00} amount through Navient using their own company called NaviXXXX so that I could lower my interest rate. I agreed to this as a lower interest rate sounded good to me. Since XX/XX/XXXX, I have given an additional total payment amount of {$14000.00} as of today. I still owe Navient {$15000.00}. 

The total amount of all loans financed and owned by Navient for schooling was {$47000.00} and have paid from XXXX, to the current day, a total of {$59000.00} and still owe Navient {$15000.00} for a grand total of {$74000.00} when my last payment is due in XXXX. 


I have attached every loan from Navient ( Sallie Mae ) and the payment history for each one of those loans.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/XXXX, I saw an advertisement for the " Earn While You Learn '' school. I called the school it was XXXX XXXX XXXX. They had a XXXX XXXX training program they claimed would help individuals like me get a good job. However, there was XXXX concern of mine : I didn't have a high school diploma and I didn't speak XXXX. They told me that it wasn't a problem that I would take a test and they would go from there. I " passed '' which is strange because I did not speak XXXX I had to take their XXXX as a Second Language classes, and to this day I require a translator. According to my California XXXX XXXX XXXX paperwork, my loan was to cover XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. I have paperwork showing that I was enrolled in classes as of XX/XX/XXXX. To the best of my recollection, I remember going to classes in XX/XX/XXXX ; the instructor told us to come back in a few days. However, when we came back to the school everything was gone! The classrooms were locked and the few rooms that were opened were empty. We were told nothing, we didn't know where to get any information. At this point, I had to start working and without my diploma, I could not get paid for the " training '' that I had studied for. Then I started getting the calls and letters to start making payments for the student loan that I had signed. I told them that I couldn't pay for services that were not rendered, I never received my diploma and then I was told that once I started making my payments I would receive my diploma so I started making payments. I never received the diploma and without that diploma, I couldn't get the higher money that I would receive if I had it. I have never been able to afford the payments. I even attempted bankruptcy and received a decision on XX/XX/XXXX to remove the student loan. It was only recently that I found the news article in the LA XXXX published on XX/XX/XXXX ( https : XXXX ). The school was already warned against getting student loans for students because the school had a high amount of students who were defaulting! The XXXX already knew that students could not pay back the loans that the school was pulling for these students. Other individuals had been going to the XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX attempting to get school records or start their classes and the campus was already closed. The same story, people trying to get information, and the school was already gone. Navient has claimed that the school officially closed on XX/XX/XXXX but that's just not true as proven by the LA XXXX XXXX. Navient has been the servicer for this loan for at least a decade now and they did not approve any type of low payment due to finances even when I was on XXXX due to a work injury twice. 
When the XXXX administration was trying to remove Student Loan Debt, I tried to apply for Student Loan forgiveness but was told that because my loans were under Navient I did not qualify for either the XXXX or XXXX plans because my plans were private. These days if a XXXX school closes on students within XXXX months of that student 's last date of attendance the loan is made null and void.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my concerns regarding the student loan [ predatory ] practices at the XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington XXXX XXXX ), a branch of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which have led to significant financial difficulties for my family and I. The servicer they used for XXXX XXXX XXXX was XXXX XXXX. 

Since my initial enrollment in XX/XX/XXXX, I was consistently compelled rather than encouraged to pursue private student loans to finance my education at XXXX. This sense of coercion has led to profound financial ramifications, significantly impacting my financial stability and future prospects. These private loans have been the source of considerable financial strain and has had an exceedingly negative impact on my financial well-being. 

Throughout my tenure at the XXXX XXXX of Washington, interactions with counselors were infrequent, and when they occurred, it was near the conclusion of each academic term. During which the focus was predominantly on securing additional student loans, including private student loans, specifically from XXXX XXXX ( now with Navient ). In retrospect, the emphasis of the XXXX counselors seemed to be on facilitating the acquisition of funds rather than providing comprehensive guidance on the implications and long-term consequences of such financial commitments. 

The XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington guaranteed help and placement of/for XXXX XXXX or XXXX related jobs after graduation in XXXX. I was not helped by XXXX XXXX. I was sent links to XXXX positions that I did not have experience to qualify for. 

The XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington brought in artists that had no degree at all during my years there from XXXX to XXXX, which clearly demonstrated to students in attendance, that a degree would not be necessarily required to succeed in our respective industries. 

The XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington guaranteed help and placement of/for XXXX XXXX or XXXX related jobs. I was not helped by XXXX XXXX. Upon graduation in XXXX, I was emailed links to XXXX positions that I did not have experience to qualify for. 

I was not able to obtain a job in a related field until 4 years after graduation on XXXX XXXX  and had already began paying back loans not using the degree that was given, as well as The XXXX XXXX closing down and not being able to have transcripts to show employers The XXXX XXXX was sued by the federal government and lost, in the amount of {$95.00} XXXX, for fraud with student tuition. 

I had already graduated, but I did not have anything valid to show employers there after. 


I was not able to obtain a job in my respective field of study for 4 years after graduating. I had to take alternative routes to get into the industry that I studied, and was not able to pay back anything above interest on student loans. My credit has suffered due to late payments, forbearances, etc. 

I never transferred, so that does not apply, but, I was not able to obtain official transcripts for the classes I did take. 

The Art Institutes have been deemed irresponsible by the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, and hereby forgiven loans of all students that attended any of The Art Institutes during the years of XXXX thru XXXX, In which I did attend. I have received documentation for that forgiveness and need private loans to reflect that forgiveness.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
As a matter of fact, XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX and their Parent company, XXXX were investigated by the attorneys general of several states and have been found to have acted in a fraudulent manner. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX, the Biden administration has just announced a blanket discharge for anyone enrolled at XXXX XXXX XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. 
My Federal loans in the amount of estimated at around {$11000.00} including interest, were paid of years ago by myself. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. 
These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit schools '', but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. 
I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. 
After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? 
Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? 
Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. 
This application is a sham. 
Why do we need to prove anything? 
Navient knows who we are. 
Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. 
Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!

Consumer complaint narrative:
Request for Refund : NAVIENT STUDENT LOAN # XXXX. 
Violation of US Bankruptcy Court Discharge OrdeXXXX # XXXX. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX applied to Sallie Mae for a student loan which was granted. 
XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX filed for bankruptcy protection in the XXXX XXXX XXXX Ohio [ Petition Number XXXX ]. naming Sallie Mae/ Navient as a creditor with a balance owed in the amount of XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX and XXXX ( {$41000.00} ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

XXXX XXXX /Navient was served notice of the bankruptcy proceedings [ as a certified unsecured creditor ]. 

XX/XX/XXXX, the bankruptcy was discharged. 
Bankruptcy Court records indicated that Sallie Mae/Navient received a total distribution of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ( {$160.00} ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

Sallie Mae/Navient continues to bill XXXX XXXX and collect principal and interest through the current date of [ XX/XX/XXXX ] XX/XX/XXXX. 

The Second Circuit Court of Appeals [ New York ] [ Case # XXXX, [ XXXX ] filed XX/XX/XXXX ] upheld U.S. Bankruptcy Judge XXXX XXXX refusal to dismiss the lawsuit against student loan servicer Navient Solution LLC for violating the courts prior order discharging a borrowers loan after bankruptcy. 
The court ordered that Sallie Mae/Navient student loans whose borrowers had filed and received a bankruptcy discharge after XXXX, and who had listed Sallie Mae /Navient as creditors XXXX Loans must be discharged as stated in the bankruptcy order. 

XXXX XXXX filed for bankruptcy protection in XXXX and listed Sallie Mae/Navient as a creditor owning a total of {$41000.00}. 

XX/XX/XXXX, the U.S Bankruptcy Court of XXXX Ohio granted and discharged the petition. 

Although Navient/Sallie Mae received a portion of the distribution from the Trustee, as a final settlement, Navient continues to bill XXXX XXXX for Principal and Interest. 

The 2nd, Circuit [ NY ] stated that in the decision, penned by Circuit Judge XXXX XXXX and joined by Judges XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX, the court agreed with the bankruptcy courts finding that the language of the " educational benefit '' provision is an unconventional way to discuss a loan. The court said that if Congress intended to protect all educational loans from discharge, it would not have done so in such stilted terms. 

Therefore, XXXX XXXX is requesting a full refund of the total amount of {$41.00}, XXXX that was owed on XX/XX/XXXX, the time of his bankruptcy discharge. 

A response is required within Twenty ( 20 ) days of this date. 

Respectfully Requested and Submitted. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Office ) XXXX ( direct )

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX, I could not afford to repay my student loans. So they doubled. And then they doubled again. And again. Eventually the debt soared to an amount over $ XXXX. 
Our credit was completely devastated and we never recovered. 
Since, we cashed out my husband 's XXXX to pay student loans down, we have no retirement, and because I work ALL the time, I do not qualify for any of the Biden loan forgiveness. Frankly, we're disgusted. 
Eventually we negotiated with Navient to repay the only amount they would come down to. It was brutal. But! Navient told me that before I could resume paying my student loan debt, I would have to pay a company called Pioneer Credit Recovery Services over $ XXXX, that none of the payments to Pioneer would be applied toward the debt I owed, and that only after completing 6 consecutive payments ( for nothing ) could I begin repaying the debt I owed. We had so little money. Sometimes we sold things on XXXX, I babysat ( in my XXXX XXXX )  and worked a retail job to make these payments. We finally completed those 6 payments that were punishment for not being able to pay the astronomical payments to Navient. 
Now? I would like that money to be applied to repay what remains of my student loans. I pay just under {$1800.00} month, still. But that money went to nothing. Absolutely nothing. If I can not qualify for any other loan forgiveness ( even though I meet all the criteria with the exception of entering into the new repayment program that would add another 10 years onto the debt ), I would like that money they extorted from me to be applied toward my debt. Please help.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My " School Misconduct '' application was Approved by Navient XX/XX/year> for attending the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX. 
The School Misconduct application was brought forth XX/XX/year>, by United States Senators : XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX. These Senators found Sallie Mae/Navient and For-Profit schools conspiring with one another to offer risky and expensive loans to hundreds of thousands of borrowers, knowing these borrowers; such as myself would never be able to repay these loans back. These loans were designed to profit from students with low graduation rates, poor job-placement records, and otherwise misled students, all of which was known to XXXX XXXX Navient XXXX Under the Holder Rule and due to Navient and XXXX XXXX misconduct, Navient is liable for these predatory loans. 
Holder Rule : This rule is designed to protect consumers by ensuring that their rights are preserved even if their contract is transferred to someone else. It does not create new rights or claims for the consumer but ensures that any existing rights or defenses ( such as a claim for breach of contract or warranty issues ) can still be asserted against the new holder of the contract. 
Limitation on Recovery : The rule specifies a limit on how much a consumer can recover. Specifically, the consumer 's recovery for claims and defenses can not exceed the total amount they have paid under the contract. This means that if you have paid {$500.00} under the contract and have a valid claim or defense, you can not recover more than {$500.00} from the creditor or assignee. 
The Holder Rule applies to all consumer credit contracts, including those for the sale of goods and services, but it is particularly relevant in transactions involving installment credit and loans for consumer purchases. 
I have paid XXXX XXXX Navient {$47000.00} from XXXX XX/XX/year>. My APR ranged from 7 % to now 17 %. My Total loan balance before my discharge was {$85000.00}. I was held liable to pay this balance off from Predatory Institutions and its Predatory Lenders that worked together to profit from myself and I believe XXXX XXXX Navient XXXX obtained payments from myself and should be held liable to repay me. I am protected under the " Holder Rule '' enforced by the FTC, that I am to be made Whole, and reimbursed what I paid to XXXX XXXX Navient XXXX the amount of {$47000.00}. Everything I stated is true and my submitted documents substantiates my proof.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Between XXXX and XXXX, my student loans experienced multiple periods of forbearance and repayment without significant payments being made. Despite these extended periods of financial difficulty, I was not offered adequate repayment options such as income-driven repayment plans ( IDR ), which could have helped me avoid further financial hardship and loan default. 

Timeline and Details Forbearance Periods : Over several years, my loans were placed in forbearance multiple times. 
Each forbearance period lasted several months to over a year. 

Repayment Periods : During certain periods, my loans were in repayment status without payments being made, leading to confusion and financial hardship. 

Default Period : Eventually, my loans entered default status and remained in default until they were consolidated and brought back into repayment status. 

Actions by the Company : The company repeatedly placed my loans in forbearance without adequately informing me of alternative repayment options such as IDR. 
The company allowed extended periods in repayment status without payments being made. 

Impact : The frequent forbearance periods led to significant interest accrual and an increase in my loan balance. 
The lack of proper communication regarding repayment options contributed to my loans entering default, further complicating my financial situation. 

Requested Resolution : Retroactive Application of IDR : Apply IDR plans retroactively to the periods when my loans were in forbearance or default. 

Adjustment of Loan Forgiveness Timeline : Correct the forgiveness timeline to account for the periods that would have been covered under an IDR plan. 

Compensation for Financial Hardship : Provide compensation for the financial hardship caused by the mismanagement of my loan status, including excessive interest and fees accrued. 

Punitive Damages : Consider punitive damages for the undue stress and financial strain caused by improper handling and lack of communication regarding repayment options.

My balance appears more than it should be given my payment history - due to interest. There are no running balance accounting available on the website. 

It appears given this excerpt from the letter that the money I paid every month was NOT applied to the principle and interest as requested on the website while my loan balance increased. I did NOT request to pay ahead- I expected to reduce the balance. " Your private loan is paid ahead by approximately 15 months based on the additional funds received and the current Monthly Payment for this loan. '' Here is how the records show they applied the monthly payment but apparently this is not true : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX There can not be a prepayment and a reduction at the same time. I was expecting a reduction. 
The letter stating that I was going back into repayment indicates that overpayments ( if my amount due was XXXX then this should have been considered this category ) would reduce my loan. 
" When you pay more than your Current Amount Due, Overpayments will be applied to your Current Balance. Unless you make your payments through Auto Pay or instruct us to do otherwise, Overpayments will reduce the amount of any future payments. For example, if you pay an extra {$50.00} and your regular Monthly Payment Amount is {$100.00}, your next payment due will be {$50.00}. If the extra funds are more than the next Monthly Payment Amount, your billing statements will show XXXX due. Interest continues to accrue on any loan until the loan has been paid in full, including loans with XXXX due. Even if you have a XXXXamount due on your billing statement, continuing to make payments will reduce your total costs of borrowing. '' If I don't continue to pay every month then the interest will continue to accrue. I might be willing to pay the principle ( maximum ) as a settlement but there is no place on the website see running balances to verify and validate what is happening with the money. Customer service will not discuss that option with me. 

My current payoff date is XXXX and that doesn't add up with the way money is allocated and my payment requirement. I would like this loan forgiven or the ability to pay off a nominal amount and the rest written off. I was able to do that 15 years ago on the other loan but didn't have the financial resources at the time to do both. 

Thank you for your consideration.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students, including myself, were scammed by Sallie Mae/Navient XXXXnto taking out predatory private student loans to attend for-profit schools such as the one I attended, The XXXX XXXX of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX IL ) XXXX As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and its parent company, XXXX XXXX XXXX, were investigated by multiple agencies and attorney generals and determined to be fraudulent. I transferred to XXXX from XXXX  XXXX XXXX and attended XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. I had to take out student loans in order to attend, and the only option I was given by the school 's financial aid reps, other than the federal loans that I qualified for, was to take out private loans from Sallie Mae. Not only was I told that there were no other options for private student loans, but scare tactics were used by the financial aid reps to get me to borrow more money than I actually needed. They said I needed more money for the specific class supplies because I could only use the supplies that the school 's bookstore sold, and those were inevitably more expensive than other places. They told me that with my class schedule and projects that would be required I wouldn't be able to work enough to pay my rent, bills, food, etc. I had attended XXXX for about a year and a half when, in XX/XX/XXXX, I was told by school personnel that XXXXXXXX XXXX accreditation was changing, and that I would have to start the fashion design program over if I wanted to graduate because the classes that I had already taken would not apply toward a degree with the new accreditation. I immediately chose to withdraw from XXXX, and since it was within the first week of the new quarter, I was able to cancel my loans for that particular quarter. However, I had thousands of dollars in federal and private student loans from the XXXX years that I was enrolled. At the time there were numerous students that were told the same thing about the accreditation changes, and they also withdrew from the school. I ultimately decided to re-enroll at XXXX XXXX XXXX in the fall of XXXX and despite XXXX 's promise that my credits would transfer, they did not. However, because I had been at XXXX XXXXXXXX before XXXX, and my advisor felt bad for what I had been through, she was willing to help me graduate as soon as I could. I graduated from XXXX with my XXXX XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX. Unfortunately, almost 20 years later, I am STILL paying for the loans from my time at XXXX, and even though I have paid XXXX more than the original loan amounts, I somehow still owe them over {$42000.00}. I have asked Navient for my payment records from the time the loans originated to the present date, but they told me they can only provide limited information prior to the date that they took the loans over from Sallie Mae. They are only able to provide me with dates of transactions and the loan balances at the time of those transactions, but they are not able to provide me with the dollar amount of the transactions, or how my payments were applied to my balances ( how much went toward interest or principal ). I have spoken with several Navient reps who told me that they do not have that information, but Sallie Mae does. They advised me to call Sallie Mae. Unfortunately, when I called Sallie Mae I was told by numerous reps that they do not have a single record of my loans because Navient took ALL of the records when they took my loans over. I have heard about " relief '' programs that Navient supposedly has for people whose loans were for schools that ended up being determined as fraudulent, but every time I have called Navient to ask about this I am given a different answer. I was laughed at by a rep who told me I " don't have any options so just pay it. '' I called another day to ask about relief options and spoke with a woman who said that relief options are only available for people who were in school at the time the school closed due to fraud. I called and spoke with a rep very recently and asked how my payments were being applied, because my regular monthly payment was about {$590.00}, and I had paid almost {$2000.00} over the past 6 weeks but NONE of it was applied to my balance. The rep simply said that " interest accrues daily. '' I assured her that I am aware of that, but if my {$2000.00} in payments over a 6 week period was all applied toward daily interest, then something is seriously wrong. She kept saying that she didn't know what to tell me other than " interest accrues daily. '' I told the rep that I was looking at my account on Navient 's website, and it showed that I was on an extended repayment plan. I asked when I was put on that, and what would my payment be if I were on the standard repayment plan. She placed me on hold, then came back on and told me that I am not currently on ANY payment plan. I asked how I could possibly not be on ANY payment plan, when they require me to pay a minimum of {$590.00} per month. She said that she would have to talk to a manager and placed me on hold again. When she got back on she told me that I WAS on the standard repayment plan. I asked her why then, did my account on their website show that I was on an extended repayment plan. She said that I had apparently requested that payment plan when I had first entered into repayment, and the website never updates that. I told her that doesn't make any sense, and that if I AM on the standard repayment plan, and my standard payment is {$590.00}, then why would that entire amount be going toward interest. The principal balance is not decreasing at all, despite her claim that I am on the standard repayment plan, which is supposed to be the least amount of months to pay the balance. The rep sounded like she had no idea why, but just kept repeating that interest accrues daily. I was getting nowhere, and I didn't have time to keep going round and round with her, so I ended the call. To this day, I still have no answers as to why I have to pay {$590.00} a month, but my balance is not decreasing. I also still have no answers as to what relief options are available for former students of fraudulent schools. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these for-profit schools, such as XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX , I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against XXXX, and my federal loans are being reviewed for discharge, as I am a post-class member of the XXXX XXXX XXXX lawsuit settlement. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for-profit schools ''. I would have qualified to be part of the very limited settlement agreement, but those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. This was like a punch in the gut! There were times over the years that I was 5-6 months past due, but I did absolutely everything I could to prevent them from going into default. The hardships that it caused nearly cost me my marriage and my mental health! And then to find out that if I had just let them go into default, they would've not only been discharged but I could've possibly been paid back some of what I had paid in?! Infuriating! I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but it was a SHAM of a settlement deal for the rest of us borrowers who were scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time for Navient do the right thing and discharge ALL of these predatory private loans made to attend for profit schools NOW!
