Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Old information reappears or never goes away
Consumer complaint narrative: I am writing to formally dispute the reporting of referenced accounts ( # XXXX ) on my credit report under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681. Upon reviewing my credit reports, I have identified inaccuracies in the information being furnished and incompleteness by your company to the credit reporting agencies. Legal Basis : The FCRA mandates that furnishers of credit information provide only accurate and complete information to credit reporting agencies. Specifically, 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) states that a furnisher must not report information if it knows, or has reasonable cause to believe, that the information is inaccurate. I would like to reference the case XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ), which highlights the furnisher 's duty to investigate and correct any inaccuracies once notified by the consumer. Continuing to report inaccurate information after receiving notice of a dispute is a violation of the FCRA. Furthermore, I would like to highlight the fact that Navient was recently sued by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau filed XX/XX/XXXX for a whopping {$120.00} XXXX and is " Banned '' from student loan servicing for unethical business practices and is in fact a " repeat offender with a long history of regulatory violations. '' according to Consumer Financial Protection Bureau v. Navient Corporation et al, Case No. XXXX. I have disputed against Navient several times for furnishing inaccurate and incomplete account information to my credit reports. They are damaging my credit reputation by reporting false and materially misleading information. Dispute Details : The information reported by Navient on these accounts are inaccurate for the following reasons : Inaccurate Payment History : The payment history reflected on my credit report contains errors, such as misreported late payments that have duplicated by more than 8 times with random misleading late payments starting at " 90 days late '' and multiple transactions that I made on the tradelines that are not being reported showing as " No Data '' : The date of first delinquency reported on this account is incorrect and does not reflect the true timeline of the account 's history. The date of last payment is missing from this tradelines. I recently disputed both account by Navient and they again verified the errors in the accounts with no corrections made even after being sued. Requested Action : I respectfully request that Navient : Conduct a thorough investigation into the disputed account and correct the inaccurate information regarding the payment history and date of first delinquency. Cease reporting any incorrect information to the credit reporting agencies ( XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX ). Provide written confirmation of the investigations outcome, including details of any corrections made to my account. If the inaccurate information is not corrected in a timely manner, I reserve the right to escalate this matter, including filing an additional complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) or pursuing legal action as permitted under the FCRA. Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your response and confirmation of the necessary corrections.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended graduate school XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX. I did not request for Navient to change my student loan account from repayment to in-school deferment. I paid half my payment every XXXX weeks which means I made an additional payment each year for a total of 13 monthly payments/year. In XX/XX/XXXX, prior to my consolidation, I saw that these months were documented as in-school deferment and requested the in-school deferment be removed so these months counted as active payment months. Navient replied XX/XX/XXXX that they could not remove the in-school deferment since it would put my loans severely past due and the payment for XXXX XXXX was due XX/XX/XXXX ( 4 months away ) and XXXX XXXX was due XX/XX/XXXX ( the next month ). Since I had made the same monthly payments plus XXXX additional monthly payment each year, this did not make sense to me. I called Navient and asked again if they would remove the in-school deferment. The individual who answered the phone said yes, she could remove the in-school deferment for both XX/XX/XXXX ( when I was not in school and did not request a deferment ) and XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX. I then requested to consolidate my student loans to XXXX to access the temporary waiver program. 

I had no idea that my second request was denied until XX/XX/XXXX. I never received additional communication that my phone request was denied. I do not understand why it was denied in XXXX, and why I was not offered a way to remove the in-school deferment and come current with any interest that XXXX have been owed. I also do not understand how there could be any delinquency by removing the in-school deferment when I made the same monthly payment since XXXX plus XXXX additional monthly payment each year. I called Navient again on XX/XX/XXXX and requested they remove the in-school deferment and allow a way to come current with any past interest due during that time and was told they would resubmit the request, but most likely it would be denied. 

This feels incredibly unfair and like Navient is continuing to misguide/scam student loan borrowers. I have been paying on these student loans for decades and even when my kids were little and I could not afford full-time daycare, I worked PT ( just under the XXXX hours/week ) for a non-for-profit organization, I continued to make my monthly payments.

" What to expect next We'll send you notification advising you of your new payment amount after your current plan expires on XX/XX/XXXX. '' XX/XX/XXXX received email Subject : Your XXXX plan has been approved Correspondence : What to expect next with your XXXX plan " your XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) XXXX has been approved on your eligible loans. Your calculated XXXX plan repayment amount : {$0.00} Plan begin date : XX/XX/XXXX Plan end date : XX/XX/XXXX '' XX/XX/XXXX received email Subject : Your monthly statement is ready Correspondence : Monthly Bill " Statement Date XX/XX/XXXX Billing Period XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX '' ... '' Past Due Amount {$93.00} Pay Past Due Amount By XX/XX/XXXX to avoid Late Fee of {$5.00} Current Amount Due {$93.00} Current Amount Due Date XX/XX/XXXX '' ... I was told my previous repayment plan expired before my new plan started, which according to the information I received isn't accurate. She didn't explain why I had another payment due for next month. I was told the information on StudentAid.gov isn't accurate since it's not Navient 's website, which is what I should have looked at. I don't know if I'm getting charged a late fee, if there's something I need to submit that I'm not aware of. Mostly I'm confused, but also, if I hadn't caught that, were they just planning on ignoring the XXXX repayment plan and charging me the regular amount for the entire year? Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX and their Parent company, XXXX were investigated by the attorneys general of several states and have been found to have acted in a fraudulent manner. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by The XXXX XXXX, the Biden administration has just announced a blanket discharge for anyone enrolled at XXXX XXXX XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. 
My Federal loans in the amount of {$57000.00} were discharged and my credit repaired.

I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. 
These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools '', but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. 
I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit online schools.

After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates?

Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? 
Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. 
This application is a sham. 
Why do we need to prove anything? 
Navient knows who we are. 
Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools.

Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: Confusing or misleading advertising
Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended an XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX school beginning in XXXX, deceived by false advertising and inflated success metrics. In order to cover the absurd cost of attendance, I was pressured by school counselors to take out private loans, in addition to federal ones. 

The outright fraud and misconduct perpetrated by the XXXX XXXX and its owners, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) and then XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ), are well documented and reported ( see the attachments in this filing ). However, the coordination of Navient Corporation ( previously known as Sallie Mae ) and for-XXXX XXXX XXXX, like the XXXX XXXX , to entrap students in insurmountable private student loan debt has only recently received serious attention. ( The CFPB itself was aware of Navients misconduct at least as far back as XXXXXXXX of XXXX, when it sued Navient for failing borrowers at every stage of repayment ; see attached article. ) In  XXXX of XXXX, Navient settled with XXXX state attorneys general to provide relief totaling {$1.00} XXXX, to resolve allegations of rampant deceptive student loan servicing practices, as well as abuses in originating predatory loans. The summary of the settlement states, Navient also allegedly originated predatory subprime private loans to students attending for-profit schools and colleges with low graduation rates, even though it knew that a very high percentage of such borrowers would be unable to repay the loans. Navient allegedly made these risky subprime loans as an inducement to get schools to use Navient as a preferred lender for highly-profitable federal and prime private loans, without regard for borrowers and their families, many of whom were unknowingly ensnared in debts they could never repay. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, Senator XXXX XXXX, along with XXXX other senators, wrote to Navient, urging it to cancel its fraudulent private student loans, under the FTCs Holder Rule. The letter lists the various abusive and deceptive activities committed by Navient and its partner schools, and it would do the letter injustice to offer a summary -- the letter is included with this filing. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, after the Biden Administration approved {$6.00} XXXX in student debt cancellation for XXXX borrowers who attended the XXXX XXXX, the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX issued a statement, saying, XXXX also partnered with Sallie Mae ( now known as Navient ), to convince XXXX borrowers to take out private student loans to augment their federal student loans. These private loans enabled XXXX to maintain access to federal student aid dollars, and Navient benefited by being a preferred lender of federally-guaranteed student loans for XXXX students. Both XXXX and Navient knew students would not be able to repay these subprime loans and had a side agreement that protected Navient against losses. These private loans are not resolved by todays federal action and will need to be addressed separately with Navient to ensure XXXX  students get full relief. 

XXXX XXXX, the President and Executive Director of XXXX, reiterated, We also urge Navient to recognize that the private student loans it made to XXXX students are also not enforceable and should be cancelled immediately. 

During its XXXX XXXX earnings call, Navient stated that it reserved {$35.00} XXXX due to internal policy changes [ ] made to meet new regulatory expectations related to school misconduct discharges on certain legacy private loans. In addition, Navient plans to transfer these loans to XXXX ( this is also addressed in Senator XXXX  letter ). These are most likely responses not only to the Biden Administrations actions to provide relief to defrauded borrowers, but also to the recent victory of borrowers in the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ( aided by XXXX  ), in which students who attended certain predatory schools ultimately won federal student loan debt relief, including refunds. Navients portfolio contains many private loans taken out by borrowers who attended these schools ; its only reasonable that Navient should anticipate and prepare for adverse action, especially given XXXX involvement and the mounting scrutiny from Senator XXXX and her colleagues, as well as various state attorneys general.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I initially took out a private loan through my school. It appears as though my school had an arrangement with Sallie Mae and so that is the lender I had. The paperwork was signed at the school for the loan. I was notified that there was a mistake in the paperwork and I needed to resign I was told.

This new document had different interests rates on it. I make this allegation going years back. Fast forward and Sallie Mae has now created a new company called Navient so Sallie Mae can now pretend to have no knowledge of my loan. Sallie Mae engaged in predatory lending. Had a deal with my school and knew a majority of students like myself wouldnt be able to pay. 

The harassing phone calls began in XXXX or so and continued for years. Navient has already been made to pay for accounts held under Sallie Mae. State Attorney Generals sued Navient for actions and behaviors under the name Sallie Mae.

I attended school in XXXX, one of the states that qualified for settlement. I moved to XXXX and so I was not notified. However, the damage is the same and the alleged behavior of private predatory lending is the same. Navient currently holds my private loan. Sallie Mae engaged in illegal behavior and Navient wants to benefit. When Navient benefits then so does Sallie Mae.

I should be extended the same relief as those students who were part of the settlement. Sallie Mae had a partnership with my school. This compromised my loan and caused my financial aid office to work on the behalf of Sallie Mae and not me!

Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted a complaint to you ( CFPB ) on XX/XX/XXXX asking for a school misconduct form for my almost 20-year loans with Navient for an art institute school. On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a rejection of my school discharge application form Navient. When I requested more information and criteria as to why it was rejected, I received an even vaguer response about " holistic viewing '' of the entire app as the reason ( received XXXX ) My 34 page application provided evidence of the school intentionally distorting job placement stats, pressure from the recruiter due to my older age, and career placement assistance that was touted as top-notch. I only received job " leads '' for minimum wage restaurant positions, not in graphic design. I provided screenshots from the website in XXXX, when I attended, that showed great career placement stats and also provided the sworn XXXX testimony confirming the intentional fraud. 

The US Government has even identified these loans as predatory. 
I have never been in default and I believe this is why they refuse to release my loans. Navient increased my interest to 10 %, guaranteeing I will never be able to catch up and pay them off even though my previous interest was 3.5 % and I also have near-perfect credit. 

Responding that they look at the loans " holistically '' is not an answer to why I was denied.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been diligently paying off my private student loans for several years, despite attending a school that has been embroiled in misconduct. The interest rates on these loans are exorbitantly high, ranging from the mid to high teens. It's disheartening to witness others receive forgiveness for similar loans due to default, while I, who have remained current on my payments, continue to struggle financially and suffer negative impacts on my credit. 

Attempting to refinance these loans into more favorable terms has proven to be a daunting task. Navient, my current loan servicer, shows reluctance to negotiate lower interest rates. Moreover, my association with a school involved in misconduct severely limits my options for refinancing with other lenders. Repeated denials for refinancing stem from the longstanding nature of my private loans and the minimal reduction in the principal amount owed. 

These loans are a product of a deceitful institution that has defrauded its students. Therefore, I firmly believe that such loans should be deemed null and void due to the school 's fraudulent activities.

Consumer complaint narrative: This is a formal complaint against Navient, LLC. My current private loan servicer is Navient formerly Sallie Mae. I will reach 20 years of repayment in 4 years. The original disbursement amount was {$39000.00} dating back to 2005 and present day, the balance totals {$66000.00}. While granted more options and relief for my federal loans, the private loans have reached substantial interest and fees. During repayment I have inquired about releasing of co signer and told I qualify to then be told upon asking for the application to then being told is not an option because I can not be in any repayment plan like rate reduction. I was previously placed in forbearance as the only available option when requesting assistance with trouble with repayment. To years later be granted a rate reduction, which is only extending the life of the loans, interest continuing to accrue, resulting in more debt as any payments made are only being made on the variable interest. Moreover, I was encouraged to take out student loans without being fully informed of the unfavorable terms, leading to significant financial hardship. These deceptive practices have caused me considerable distress, both financially and emotionally. I have always struggled with loan repayments there is zero outlook that any substantial dent will be made on the balance of the loans and foresee a lifetime of being in repayment. I am seeking discharge of all loans due to misconduct from responsible parties

Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted my XXXX XXXX application on XX/XX/XXXX and received a denial letter without any information as to why or an option for appeal on XX/XX/XXXX. 
On XX/XX/XXXX I received an email from Navient that my loans are moving to XXXX. I provided more than enough information on my XXXX XXXX including both judgements against the school for misleading its students in the profession and opportunities they would be given had they completed the program and received an XXXX XXXX instead of getting a XXXX that was a less expensive option. 
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans with co signers to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX. As a matter of fact, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX was investigated Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct it was a part of the consumer fraud class action schools. I was able to file a XXXX XXXX claim with the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and my Fed. loans of {$23000.00} were XXXX and my credit repaired. My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX settlement for which I was a full class member. I am aware that Navient was sued by XXXX state XXXX regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that XXXX XXXX/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXXXXXX XXXX. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. After the XXXX settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of XXXX payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX XXXX XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX where I received a " degree '' and was promised that I would be able to find a job after completing school. I found a job on my own that paid {$14.00} an hour. My monthly student loan payments were $ XXXX {$500.00} a month. I knew this couldn't be sustained so I got a new job and worked a lot of overtime to pay these loans down. 

I'm proud of myself for being able to do that, however it would appear that if I didn't pay those loans I would just be forgiven today? 

How is that fair? I did what I was supposed to do and then some. I worked my XXXX off to do it. This whole process has kept me back financially for most of my adult life and I would just appreciate the same kind of help that is being provided to people who have not paid off their loans or not paid their loans at all. 

This is a breakdown of my XXXXXXXX XXXX loans with Navient : Principal- {$6700.00} ( Interest {$4600.00} ) Principal- {$9100.00} ( Interest {$8100.00} ) Principal- {$14000.00} ( Interest - {$16000.00} ) Navient 's response was this when I inquired about receiving some form of refund : " Thank you for contacting us regarding school XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
In order to be eligible for XXXX XXXX XXXX, your loans must still be active with a balance. Refunds for private loans are only issued from the date the application is received on active private loans to the date the application review is completed. 
We appreciate the opportunity to serve you. '' Understandably, issuing a refund for the principal OR the interest accrued would be huge for my family and I. I'm not asking for the whole amount to be refunded. I just feel XXXX  because I took the initiative to pay off my student loans and now Navient is issuing refunds to people, but only if they have active loans. My loans would still be active today if I did not make large payments to pay them off. 

XXXX XXXX was shut down on XX/XX/XXXX. When I inquired about it back then Navient shut me down because they were private loans. Obviously, now things have changed. 

From XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX I paid Navient {$24000.00} for a student loan that got me a a degree that is completely useless. Navient wouldn't help me back in XXXX and they won't help me now.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I completed and submitted XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. The application was denied with a generic explanation. 
I disputed the explanation as it was without sufficient reasoning. I re-submitted additional documents to back up my request on XX/XX/XXXX. With no response as todays date I reached out to Navient customer of advocate, gave them details and was told they had no response at this time and was still looking into this. Several weeks have passed with no response. 


I am challenging the loan as the school ( XXXX ) was found to be a predatory school. The loan is thru Navient ( private loan ). 

I am contesting the loan based on 'Holder Rule ' The Federal Trade Commissions 1976 rule concerning the Preservation of Consumers Claims and Defenses ( or Holder Rule ) ensures that consumers are not held to a loan or credit obligation related to the purchase of goods or services that they did not actually receive as promised. Under the Rule, schools and colleges under the FTCs jurisdiction can not accept the proceeds of a student loan unless the loan contract contains a specific term that allows the student to raise school misconduct as a defense to repayment of the loan.

I have argued numerous times that my Tuition Answer Loan was discharged as part of my XXXX  XXXX bankruptcy AND XXXX  XXXX bankruptcy ( see attached ). They have continued to collect monthly payments since then both discharges were filed by the court. As per a number of recent cases, it has been determined that in fact the Tuition Answer Loans are dischargeable. 

See XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, Navient Solutions , LLC, Navient Credit Finance Corporation XXXX XXXX No. XXXX Decided : XX/XX/XXXX Before : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX  XXXX 

There are three student loans that I took out with Sallie Mae ( now Navient ) while I was in college XXXX. The Navient student loans were discharged in Bankruptcy. I have attached the discharge papers that include other " student loan '' companies as well as the courts sentence stating that the unpaid amounts have been discharged. The other " student loan '' companies have realized the loans were discharged in Bankruptcy ( see additional attachments. ) These are all non-qualified private student loans, so they are not exempt from discharge under the bankruptcy code. They were taken out as direct consumer student loans, not certified by the school, and they were in excess of any scholarship and the federal student loans that covered by tuition. No further petition needs to be filed with the court for the discharge, according to the bankruptcy code any non-qualified private student loans are automatically discharged. I've told Navient this multiple times, but they just say that student loans can't be discharged in bankruptcy, which is only accurate for federal and private qualified student loans.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Navient violated consumer protection laws by engaging in unfair and deceptive servicing and collection practices as Sallie Mae. My loans originated with Sallie Mae and were eventually transferred to Navient. Navient originated predatory subprime private student loans for XXXX XXXX XXXX. The now defunct, XXXX XXXX XXXX had low graduation rates and knew I had low credit scores and lacked sufficient income to repay the loans. Navient made the risky subprime loans anyway. XXXX XXXX XXXX claimed it would be easy to transfer credits to other schools, and I would experience a valuable academic experience. I went into debt to attend XXXX XXXX XXXX, believing that its programs would lead to a promising career with a high salary, but these promises were outright lies. Recruiters preyed on my vulnerable situation, saying whatever was necessary to sell XXXX XXXX XXXX. As a result, I am saddled me with a lifetime of devastating debt. When I could not pay my student loans, Navient steered me into costly long-term forbearances, to bring my account out of default and maxed out my forbearance which forced me into repayment which any chance to take future forbearances or deferments for the remaining life of the loans. Navient did not counseling me about the benefits of more affordable income-driven repayment plans. The interest that accrued because of XXXX forbearance steering practices added to my loan balances, pushing me further in debt. 

The Original Private Loan Principal amount was {$6000.00}. Over the life of this loan, I have paid over {$28000.00}. As of XX/XX/XXXX, the Current Principal {$7500.00} with a current Variable Interest Rate of 18.50 %. In XXXX, I was granted federal loan cancellation of XXXX federal student loans by the Department of Education loans by filing Borrower Defense to Loan Repayment Applications alleging school misconduct. The Department of Education discharged my federal loans because of the pervasive and widespread nature of ITTs school conduct. 

There was private loan debt relief for private subprime student loans ( made to borrowers with low credit scores ) through Navients predecessor, Sallie Mae, between XXXX and XXXX, for borrowers that attended for-profit school XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX as it had been subject to state or federal law enforcement actions but I was not included in that relief. There was also private loan debt relief for private subprime student loans relief for Navient borrowers that filed bankruptcy and did not recertify their debt. I filed Navient private loan debt in a Tennessee XXXX XXXX bankruptcy court and did not recertify this debt. However, I was not included in that relief. I filed a couple of school closure discharge forms with Navient but they were denied with a reason given. 

I contacted Navient requesting an application for school misconduct discharge but was told if I qualify, they will mail out a form in the future. I am aware they are currently sending out school misconduct applications to other borrowers, I have not received one. I should be given a fair chance to file a school misconduct application for these XXXX XXXX XXXX private loans and given relief as there is plenty of known data and settlement relief info about XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX misconduct.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative:
Sure, here 's a sample letter to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) regarding the unauthorized reporting of a negative item on your credit report : -- - [ Your Name ] [ Your Address ] [ City, State, ZIP Code ] [ Email Address ] [ Phone Number ] [ Date ] Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, IA XXXX Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding an unauthorized negative item reported on my credit report. I have discovered that [ Name of Creditor ] has reported [ describe the negative item, such as a late payment, charge-off, etc. ] to my credit report without my written consent or authorization. This action has negatively impacted my credit score and financial standing.

I have taken the following steps to resolve this issue : 1. Reviewed my credit reports from XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX, and confirmed the inaccurate information. 
2. Filed a dispute with each of the three major credit bureaus regarding the incorrect item.

3. Contacted [ Name of Creditor ] directly to request the removal of the inaccurate information, providing evidence to support my claim.

4. Filed a police report regarding the unauthorized activity and identity theft.

5. Submitted an Identity Theft Report to the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ).

Despite my efforts, the negative item remains on my credit report. I believe this constitutes a violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and potentially constitutes identity theft and fraud. I am requesting the CFPB 's assistance in investigating this matter and ensuring the prompt removal of this unauthorized negative item from my credit report.

Please find enclosed copies of my credit reports, dispute letters, police report, FTC Identity Theft Report, and any correspondence with [ Name of Creditor ].

I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you require any further information or documentation.

Thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely, [ Your Name ] -- - Make sure to include all relevant documentation and adjust the details to fit your specific situation before sending the letter.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX MN. 
As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX and their Parent company, XXXX were investigated by the attorneys general of several states and have been found to have acted in a fraudulent manner. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by The XXXX XXXX, the XXXX XXXX has just announced a blanket discharge for anyone enrolled at The Art Institutes from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. 
My Federal loans in the amount of {$100000.00} were XXXX and my credit repaired. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. 
These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools '', but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. 
I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers and their parents scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. 
After the XXXX settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the XXXX student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? 
Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the XXXX student loan borrowers for not informing students of XXXX XXXX XXXX could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? 
Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who XXXX have filed XXXX XXXX claims against their schools and were approved. 
This application is a sham. 
Why do we need to prove anything? 
Navient knows who we are. 
Under the FTC " XXXX XXXX '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. 
XXXX is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW! 

Link to Senator Warrens Letter : https : XXXX % XXXX % XXXX % XXXX % XXXX % XXXX % XXXX % XXXX % XXXX % XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: I am a XXXX XXXX  of XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX, MO. I attended from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. In XX/XX/XXXX I received notice from the department of education that my Federal Student loans are being discharged for misconduct associated with XXXX XXXX XXXX. In XXXX I defaulted on XXXX private student loans associated with XXXX XXXX XXXX and serviced through Navient. Navient and subsequently through their associated collector XXXX XXXX, XXXX then proceeded to put me through what I believe were illegal collection activities. They called my phone nonstop, they called my parents phones nonstop, and they called my place of business nonstop ( this number was never provided to them for contact ), and they called extended family members nonstop. On top of this they also threatened legal action on these loans. Considering what has come to light about XXXX XXXX XXXX and their activities, and the fact that the Federal Loans associated with this institution are being discharged. I believe that these loans were settled in error and the situation should be rectified. If these loans were currently open, they would be subject to the current Navient Borrower Defense Discharge program for private loans. The full amount of these loans should be discharged, the full settlement amount of {$8100.00} should be refunded, and any payments made before default should be refunded ( as of this time Navient does not show what the payments before default are ). Also, I had a XXXX XXXX loan with Navient that was paid in full XX/XX/XXXX. This loan was subject to collection activities many times but never reached the level of default. Considering the above information, I believe this loan should also be subject to discharge and refund as well. The history of payments on these loans totals up to roughly {$18000.00}.

Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Sub-issue: Debt was paid
Consumer complaint narrative:
See attached documents for exact dates and times of communication between myself and XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, and Pioneer Credit Recovery. 
12 CFR 1006.18 prohibits debt collectors from engaging in false, deceptive, or misleading representations, which includes reporting inaccurate information to consumer reporting agencies. 
The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) govern the reporting of consumer debt to credit reporting agencies. The FCRA, under Title VI of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, regulates consumer reporting agencies and aims to ensure accuracy, fairness, and privacy of consumer information. The FDCPA prohibits debt collectors from using deceptive or abusive practices in the collection of debts, which includes reporting inaccurate information to consumer reporting agencies. 
Additionally, all of this has caused me massive emotional distress and suffering due to these companies abusing their position and violating me. My life has been a nightmare and I have suffered great hard ship and because of the violation of FCRA and the FDCPA I've been forced to targeted lending systems, including predatory practices and barriers to accessing fair credit.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem lowering your monthly payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
Between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX I borrowed {$78000.00} in Private Student Loans from Sally Mae. These loans were assumed by Navient. 
I have, to date, paid back over {$86000.00} - paying more than the original principle. 

I am currently dealing with an identity theft case where someone took out {$48000.00} in student loans in my name in California ( I live and have been living in Tennessee during this time period ). These were XXXX Federal Loans and I am working with police and the government to prove this fraud. It has nothing to do with Navient or private loans. 

But Navient, without my permission, capitalized interest on my loans. 
They now show that I owe them ( the principle amount ) {>= $1,000,000} This has created an undue burden on my ability to pay my bills. And they are now wanting to place me into default. 

Yet they claim that if I wanted to pay these loans off today, my principle is {$140000.00}. 
This is clearly abusive and has created undue financial strain as they have increased interest payments to 17 %, and now require a monthly payment on par with a home mortgage. 

How can I, after having paid them for 14 years, having paid over {$86000.00} to them, owe them TWICE as much as when I began? 

Add that the school was closed and they were sued for misleading students. 
I was told they were accredited and they WERE NOT. I have a degree that has been USELESS in assisting me in finding meaningful, steady employment. That I can not use to continue my education should I seek. And I have ALREADY paid back and then some. 

And Navient is harassing me. I get 6-8 phone calls a day. My co-signer gets 6-8 phone calls a day. And the come from in-state numbers with no identification. 

I want the harassment to stop! I want them to dismiss my loans as I have ALREADY paid them {$7100.00} more than original principle. I want them to remove the negative credit reporting from my credit bureau and my co-signer 's credit bureau. 

I have all of the documentation ( statements, tax documents, etc... ) and am more than happy to share them with any agent ( s ) you assign to investigate my case. I believe this to be a clear case of predatory lending, harassment, and clear misuse of their authority to manage my loans. 

Thank you for any assistance you can provide.

Consumer complaint narrative:
These loans from XXXX University are in violation of the Consumer Protection Laws and the holder rule. 
These private loans should have been included in my U.S. Department of Education Borrowers Discharge. I have a full discharge for all loans with XXXX University and these loans are from there. The discharge should include all loans, including the private loans that were taken out with XXXX University. Currently NaviRefi has {$73000.00} in loans that are being repaid by me and should be included in this discharge. There was over $ XXXX that should be included in my Borrower Discharge. I requested NaviRefi discharge my loans and refund me all payments that have been made. XX/XX/XXXX Borrower Defense Application # : XXXX Borrower Defense Application School : XXXX University Approval of Your Borrower Defense Case Under Exhibit C of the XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX Dear XXXX : You are receiving this letter because you are a member of the class of federal student loan borrowers covered by the recent settlement of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ( XXXX XXXX '' ) lawsuit. You submitted a Borrower Defense to Repayment discharge application relating to your federal student loan ( s ) on or before XX/XX/XXXX, and you attended a school listed on Exhibit C ( " School '' ) of the settlement agreement. Pursuant to the Sweet settlement, the Department of Education will do the following : discharge your federal student loan ( XXXX ) taken out for your enrollment in the XXXX University ( " Relevant Federal Student Loan ( XXXX ) '' ) ; provide a refund for any payments made to the Department of Education on your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( XXXX ), including Relevant Federal Student Loan debt that you previously paid off ; and delete the credit report tradeline associated with the discharged loan ( s ). The benefits described in this message apply to your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( XXXX ). The benefits do not apply to private loans. The discharge of your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( XXXX ) means that you will no longer owe the debt. You also may receive a refund for prior payments made to the Department on your discharged loan ( XXXX ) related to XXXX University. Your loan servicer will let you know if you are eligible for a payment refund, which would be mailed to you. Please check your online account with your loan servicer to ensure your address is correct so you can receive any refund. Other than confirming your address, you do not have to take any further action to receive your discharge. Your servicer will send you more details about the discharge, including which loans will be forgiven. Your Relevant Federal Student Loan debt will remain in forbearance and collections will be stopped until you receive relief. Your credit report will also be updated to reflect this discharge when it is complete. If you have questions about this notice, please call our borrower defense hotline at XXXX from XXXX ET on Monday-Friday or from XXXX ET on Saturday or Sunday. Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Chief Operating Officer Federal Student Aid XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, Washington, XXXX XXXX StudentAid.gov/XXXX

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have private student loans through Navient, for when XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX, now known as XXXX XXXX and owned by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I have had my federal student loans discharged through the Borrower Defense program, as a full class member of the XXXX XXXX XXXX class action lawsuit. I am now seeking discharge of my private loans.

I have two Signature Student Loans through Navient, with a current balance totaling {$25000.00}. At the time I took the loans out, it was through XXXX XXXX, but they were converted to Navient without me doing any sort of refinancing. 

It has been well documented by a series of investigations ( US Senate ), lawsuits, and settlements that the school and other for-profit colleges were engaged in a number of predatory practices. In addition to the false advertising, high pressure sales tactics, and lies about school accreditation, XXXX was also involved with selling private loans to me in a way that seems predatory. I was told I could not enroll in the program without taking on private student loans. I was only given one company to choose from, when in reality there were many options available. I was told that I had to have a cosigner and my dad completed the application in a hasty manner so I could get enrolled. The original documentation was lost by XXXX XXXX, and we had to do it again. 

In retrospect, I see that the tuition amounts for the school was set to the exact dollar amount that federal loans would cover for junior and senior level students. Freshman and sophomore students had lower federal student loan limits, so we were basically forced to take on private student loans if we wanted to complete this program and did not have the cash up front. The school was eeking out every XXXX they could get away with, while providing us with an " educaton '' that has proven to not be transferrable to other schools. I have been denied entry to state schools for masters programs because XXXX doesn't have the right accreditation. 

At the time I just thought this was how it worked. But after talking to other students and seeing multiple lawsuits come to light, it is clear to me this was a scam. 

I did not qualify for discharge under the Navient settlement with XXXX attorneys general because my payments were never more than 7 months behind, despite my school being on their list of schools. Had I ever defaulted, my private loans would have been discharged. 

Furthermore, Navient has also been unreliable and predatory in its collection efforts. 

When I was having financial difficulties during the 2008 recession and again after a divorce in the XXXX time period, I would call to request forbearance or any help. They often did not tell me about programs that would have helped me, only giving me the options to continue a high minimum payment. Sometimes this was with my federal loans, when an income driven repayment would have been available to me with XXXX XXXX  monthly payments ; other times it was with private loans. Often both types of loans were discussed on the same call. I kept minimal records because I was trusting the process at the time. 

On the strictly private loan side, I did a few interest rate reduction programs where I was only paying interest. I would have to sign up for an automatic payment withdrawal and continue for XXXX  months with no missed payments, and that would make me eligible for a cosigner release. Or at least that's what they told me. A payment or two would be withdrawn, and then no more withdrawals would happen despite money being in my account. This would put my loan account in delinquency and I would receive a ton of harassment ( so would my dad, the cosigner ) and when I would call to make a payment, Navient would somehow claim to have no record of the payment plan. 

I have never been able to make changes to my account online, I always have to call. The call reps rush and then I have to listen to and approve verbal terms of agreement, which does not feel like a scenario where I can do my due diligence on what the actual terms are. Phone calls are not a paper record, and it was all too convenient for them to not have record of arranged payment plans. 

I have spoken to a few friends with similar loans, and they have identical stories. It feels like a systematic failure and generally predatory practice on multiple fronts. The sale of the loans and the collection efforts have not been transparent or ethical.

Navient 's agreement and terms, including all amendments and modifications to the original loan agreement. 
A detailed breakdown of the loan amount, including the principal, interest, fees, and other charges. 
Complete payment history for the loan, including all payments made, dates, amounts, and how they were applied ( interest, principal, fees ).

Evidence that the Navient loan or agreement was not securitized or sold to any entity, including the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. 
The name and address of the true original creditor, Navient is a servicer and not the original creditor. 
Evidence of value or equal consideration provided by Navient in connection with this loan. 
Evidence that the statute of limitations on the loan has not expired. 
Navient s loan servicing records, including any adjustments, fees, interest rate changes, or modifications made to the account.

XXXX XXXX XXXX I have attached an article from Attorney General XXXX XXXX XXXX 

____________________________________________ Thursday, XX/XX/XXXX XXXX -- Attorney General XXXX XXXX announced today that the Arizona Attorney General 's Office, along with 47 other states and the District of Columbia, reached a multimillion-dollar settlement with XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX and its related entities ( collectively, XXXX  ) following a five-year investigation by the attorneys general. As part of the settlement, XXXX is agreeing to forgo any and all efforts to collect amounts owed to XXXX by former students residing in the participating states, including more than {$22.00} XXXX for over XXXX eligible Arizonans who attended specific schools ( including online courses ). 

XXXX has agreed to reform its recruiting and enrollment practices and forgo collecting about {$490.00} XXXX in debts owed by XXXX students nationally. 

XXXX is a for-profit education company that operated schools across the country, including multiple campuses in Arizona that are no longer in business. The state attorneys general allege XXXX engaged in a number of unfair and deceptive practices for years, including misleading prospective students about actual costs, the transferability of credits, accreditation, program offerings, and accurate job placement rates. 

The investigation by the attorneys general revealed evidence demonstrating that XXXX : Deceived students about the total costs of enrollment by instructing its admissions representatives to inform prospective students only about the cost per credit hour without disclosing the total number of required credit hours; Misled students about the transferability of credits into XXXX from other institutions and out of XXXX to other institutions by promising on some occasions that credits would transfer ; Misrepresented the potential for students to obtain employment in their field by failing to adequately disclose the fact that certain programs lacked the necessary programmatic accreditation ; and, Deceived prospective students about the rate that graduates of XXXX programs got a job in their field of study, thereby giving prospective students a distorted and inaccurate impression of XXXX graduates employment outcomes. For instance, XXXX inaccurately claimed that its graduates were placed who actually worked only temporarily or who were working in unrelated jobs. 
The debt relief from the settlement will completely eliminate the existing balances held by XXXX for those consumers in either XXXX of the following categories : Students who attended XXXX XXXX UXXXX  or XXXX XXXX XXXX  AND completed their classes before XX/XX/XXXX, OR Students who attended any XXXX school that was closed prior to XX/XX/XXXX, including XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX - XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX  XXXX, and XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX

Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient ( formerly XXXX XXXX ) into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  - XXXX XXXX. As a matter of fact, XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  - XXXX XXXX was investigated by the California Attorney General XXXX XXXX. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these for profit schools, such as XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  - XXXX XXXX, I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and my Federal student loans of over {$100000.00} are going to be discharged and my credit repaired. When I was enrolled into the program, they told us that our tuition rates would be " locked in '' for the duration of the program, yet I remember at least once, they did implement rate hikes in the middle of my program. After my first year, the school convinced me to ask my XXXX to co-sign for the private loans because my federal loans ran out, and my mother had just passed away so I had no immediate family to turn to. My uncle seemed to feel obligated, I believe, in some way to help me. Not being able to pay these sub-prime loans has put a strain on our relationship due to the credit hit the co-signing has caused. I called and asked to get my uncle released as my cosigner after over 10 years, but Navient said I would have to pay the full amount of the monthly payments, which I could not afford. If the school had not convinced me that my education would come to an end if I did not get these private loans ( which have ballooned to nearly {$80000.00} so far ), my life would be in a much better place. The school also knew that their education would not be sufficient to fetch the salary required to repay the loans, nor job prospects they promised, and I believe Navient also knew this as well. When I was unemployed they refused to work with me to pause my payments or offer any kind of recourse, and while I was barely scraping by with my family they wouldn't even refer me to any type of program to assist me, instead they insisted I nearly make my family homeless paying these impossible amounts, stay indebted forever, and cause unspeakable stress and anguish for years. 
My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXX settlement for which I was a Post-class member. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend for profit schools.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my concerns regarding the student loan [ predatory ] practices at the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ), a branch of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which have led to significant financial difficulties for my family and I. The servicer they used for Private Student Loans was Sallie Mae. 

Important details : Attendance Dates : XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX Initial Loan Disbursement Amount : {$59000.00} Total repaid : {$40000.00} Balance as of XX/XX/XXXX : {$110000.00} Since my initial enrollment in XX/XX/XXXX, I was consistently compelled rather than encouraged to pursue private student loans to finance my education at XXXX. This sense of coercion has led to profound financial ramifications, significantly impacting my financial stability and future prospects. These private loans have been the source of considerable financial strain and has had an exceedingly negative impact on my financial well-being. 

Throughout my tenure at the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX interactions with counselors were infrequent, and when they occurred, it was near the conclusion of each academic term. During which the focus was predominantly on securing additional student loans, including private student loans, specifically from Sallie Mae ( now with Navient ). In retrospect, the emphasis of the XXXX counselors seemed to be on facilitating the acquisition of funds rather than providing comprehensive guidance on the implications and long-term consequences of such financial commitments. 
The student loans I took out were intended to cover both my tuition and what was purported to be " housing '' expenses at XXXX. However, despite this, I was never provided with a lease agreement, a breakdown of utility costs, or an itemized invoice for any housing-related expenses. This lack of transparency left me completely unaware of the true extent of these expenses. Whenever I inquired about these details, I was simply assured that the student loans would cover everything. 
Furthermore, the school operated under an egregious and high-pressure cycle, particularly before the beginning of each quarter. I felt constant pressure to sign student loan documents before classes commenced, and I was consistently urged to take the maximum credit course load and to utilize my private student loan credit and complete my degree " on time. '' Failure to comply with these demands was met with the threat from XXXX counselors of being unable to continue attending school during the following quarter unless I could provide proof of funding at registration or before classes began and maintain full-time student status. 
As a first-generation college student, I was unaware of the unethical and predatory nature of these practices at the time. It wasn't until I was nearing the end of my tenure at XXXX, particularly during the culmination of my studies when I prepared my portfolio for review, that I began to recognize these issues. In the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX students were required to compile and present their XXXX at the XXXX XXXX XXXX during their last quarter, marking the final step toward graduation. During these XXXX XXXX, students presented their work to department chairs and faculty members, who would then review and evaluate our XXXX. Ultimately, deciding whether we would be able to graduate. 
The challenge arose when students received critiques deemed unsatisfactory. While recommendations for improvement were provided by the chair and faculty, no specific rubric was given to clarify what constituted an unsatisfactory XXXX. Instead, it was left to the subjective discretion of the faculty members to determine satisfactory quality. If a XXXX received an unsatisfactory rating, the student would need to update it based on the critique before the following quarter 's XXXX XXXX. 
Herein lies a significant issue : the faculty members responsible for reviewing XXXX changed each quarter. Additionally, due to the lack of clear guidelines and the subjective nature of XXXX XXXX, the updated work was often evaluated by new members with differing opinions from those who originally reviewed it. This inconsistency created a situation where students ' efforts to improve their XXXX were hindered by shifting standards and subjective judgments. 
It's crucial to highlight that the XXXX XXXX occurred during the last quarter before graduation. However, students who did not pass were still strongly encouraged to maintain a full course load to remain in the program and participate in the next quarter 's XXXX XXXX. Failure to do so risked being dropped from the program, preventing attendance at the subsequent XXXX XXXX and graduation. 
In late XXXX, during my last quarter at XXXX, I attempted a second XXXX XXXX  and received an unsatisfactory critique. Realizing that attempting a third review and taking more courses was financially unfeasible for me, I made the difficult decision to withdraw from XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX. Little did I know that my struggles with the loans I was persuaded to take out had only just begun. I chose to work full-time instead of returning to pursue a degree in fear of taking out more student loans. I elected to forego necessities like XXXX XXXX during this time in order to receive more in net pay, and did not make enough to make ends meet. 
After the expiration of my six-month grace period, I began receiving the first of many statements to repay my student loans. The balance for my private loans at the time was over {$60000.00}. With my federal loans adding about another {$30000.00} or so. 
Upon facing this new financial predicament, I sought information about different repayment options from other former students of XXXX. However, when I inquired with Sallie Mae/NAVIENT about options such as income-based repayment, lower interest rates, or adjusting repayment terms, I received conflicting information on different calls. While my federal loans offered the possibility of income-based repayment, my private loans did not provide that option. 
For several years, I found myself unable to make the minimum payment for my private loans despite my efforts. Sallie Mae/NAVIENT offered me no resolution and even threatened default. Eventually, in about XXXX or so, I was informed that I could make interest-only payments, but was warned that the interest rates would rise as they were variable, which indeed happened, reaching double digits. Despite my efforts to make payments and sacrificing basic necessities, I saw my balance continue to grow. 
The financial strain I experienced caused me distress in the years after leaving XXXX. It wasn't until XXXX, on the brink of financial ruin, that I made any progress. It was at this time, I made the decision to enlist in the XXXX XXXX. While I wish I could say it was driven by a personal calling or a desire to make my family proud, my primary motivation was to cap my interest rates through the Service Members Civil Relief Act. 
However, my efforts to enlist were immediately impeded. Before finalizing my enlistment, I needed to obtain official copies of my college transcripts. XXXX students were unable to begin their classes until payment for the classes was secured, however, when I went to obtain my transcripts in XX/XX/XXXX, I was told I needed to pay a final balance before they could provide me with transcripts. When asked for an itemized bill, while they were able to provide one, they were unable to answer my questions regarding why I had the balance, considering I withdrew XX/XX/XXXX, and charges on the bill included charges from XXXX and XXXX and XXXX. Again, when I left XXXX, I had a significant student loan balance, however, my balance at XXXX was {$0.00}. I pressed for reasons why, but was told that there was nothing that could be done, and that fortunately I wasn't sent to collections so XXXX could receive payment directly. As mentioned, I was on the brink of financial ruin and needed desperately to obtain my transcript to enlist in the XXXX. The XXXX employee even had the audacity to suggest to me to take out a personal loan to cover the cost of the bill. Fortunately, I was able to borrow the money from my relatives, and joined the XXXX. 
In XXXX, I officially enlisted in the XXXX. This allowed me to postpone payments on my student loans, without going into default, until I figured out my financial situation. Around this time frame Navient became the new lender for my student loans. It seemed as though after I joined the XXXX the calls from /NAVIENT became less and less. However, I did not want to postpone my student loans too long, as my goal was to pay off my student loans as quickly as possible. But by XXXX I had been making payments for a few years at that point with the balance only getting bigger. Fortunately, my interest rate went from the double digits down to 6 %. Despite joining the XXXX, $ XXXX {$1200.00} minimum monthly payments were not feasible, and I continued to find ways to lower the rate, adjust payment terms, or find some income-based repayment for my private student loans. However, over the next couple years, it seemed as though depending on the representative I would receive different answers for those questions. From one person to the next as far as if a loan could be included in various states of repayment or programs. As far as I was concerned it was obscured on purpose, and the reality was that the Navient representative could not, or would not help. As the years passed after withdrawing from XXXX, I found out that private student loans have minimal repayment options other than standard. I also learned that regardless of the repayment option, balances will continue to grow. Which is what has happened with my account. Over the last 10 years or so I have applied payments towards my private students. And the increase has been significant, with the aggregate balance, as of XX/XX/XXXX, having increased over 90 % no matter how much money I have applied to my loans. I have tried addressing principal, interest, and asked for explanations of how much and how long it would take to pay off my loans in their entirety, I pay more than the minimum payment, and yet my balances continue to increase dramatically. 
In XXXX I found out that the borrower defense to repayment had expanded to include schools that misled students, even those that did not close within 6 months of withdrawal. Unfortunately, I applied and was denied in XXXX, and, until recently, I had over {$160000.00} in student loans from XXXX ( this included my federal loans ). I reapplied in XXXX. And later saw there are several people like me who suffered because of XXXX and other for-profit colleges greed, and the XXXX XXXX XXXX case allowed my federal XXXX loans to be discharged. Specifically, XXXX was one of the schools listed in the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX settlement that would receive automatic discharge. XXXX was guilty for using fraudulent practices, illegal recruitment and enrollment tactics, etc. and preyed upon students for their own financial benefit. Then after withdrawal Sallie Mae and Navient were insensitive, uninformed, and are just as guilty as XXXX in unifying with them to offer private predatory student loans. 

For years after my experience with the XXXX XXXX and my attempted repayment to NAVIENT I have struggled with the burden of deciding, not what was in my best interest or my spouse, but putting every aspect of my future on hold, in order to pay my student loans. 

While I am thankful to be serving in the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, this decision ultimately came after facing the ultimatum of enlisting to take advantage of military deferments and Service Members Civil Relief Act or defaulting on my student loans. 

I do not dwell on what the {$40000.00} in payments could have bought, but how many times I delayed starting a family, or investing towards retirement. Although it is difficult not to, considering I never finished my degree with XXXX nor did I ever work in the field I went to school there for. However, wIthout a doubt, every aspect of my financial position has been adversely affected by the weight of my student loans from my credit score, job opportunities, the APR for any credit ( auto, cards, etc. ).

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: This is in regards to a private student loan ( {$20000.00} ) from Navient. I applied for this loan in XX/XX/XXXX when I was in graduate school for which I had a co-signer. In XX/XX/XXXX, my co-signer filed for bankruptcy and, through the procedures, half of the balance at the time ( appx. {$14000.00} ) was automatically paid off. Since, Navient sent me emails with {$0.00} due and explained that a large payment constituted a payment ahead of the schedule and it was no longer due for a while. I had never ( and have still never ) experienced such a large payment situation and I did not understand what that meant. I figured when payments resume I can just make normal payments ( principal + interest as before ). Because this occurred shortly before the COVID pandemic, I tried to balance out the challenges that came with that and believed their recurrent emails that constantly showed {$0.00} due ( no interest payments required or suggested were every mentioned ). In XX/XX/XXXX, payments restarted and I called to inquire about paying additional every month towards my principal so I can expedite the loan payment. At this time, Navient refused to allow me to make any payments towards the principal until I first paid the interest accrued since XXXX ( appx. {$5000.00} which I am not in a position to pay off ). They provided the original loan documents which state that payments go first towards the interest and then principal. I understand that I signed those documents but I had no power over the payment ahead being made in XXXX and not XXXX time since XXXX did Navient attempt to contact me and explain how this was going to work beyond emailing me that I HAVE NOTHING DUE. I find this to be a very predatory practice as is their refusal to allow me to make partial payments towards my loan principal at this time IN ADDITION to the interest payments they are requiring. My account is current and I reached out to their XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX which only invoked the same documentation and closed the file. Because the interest will continue to grow, I have no way of catching up any time soon in this manner because the balance will continue to grow as the interest keeps adding to the constantly growing amount without being able to pay anything towards the principal. I have also requested them to cancel out my interest since XXXX due to their failure to communicate with me and explain about the implications but they refused that. I have never had a lender not allow me to make additional payments towards the principal and I find this, as stated, highly predatory, especially since it is a student loan not a for-profit business.
