Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I was recently notified of the discharge of my federal loans related to XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX ( attached ), based on findings of gross school misconduct ( attached ), however, the approval seemingly does not cover private loans for the same school and period or make whole the funds paid to the private servicer Navient ( attached ). 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX and all XXXX  schools are now permanently closed as part of XXXX XXXX ongoing litany of accreditation issues and lawsuits, XXXX 's predatory practices and exploitive partnerships with Sallie Mae / Navient and to whom I made all payments from XXXX. The impacts still reverberate and haunt me and my family to this day. My mom XXXX, has delayed retirement for fear of late-life financial harms being that she is the co-signer on ALL of the private loans and has been the payer on as many as were possible over the last 15 years. She carries immense guilt for her trusting the recruiters when we sat down with them in fall XXXX. Their misconducts were known publicly as early as XXXX ( one year after going into repayment ) when uncovered as a result of exhaustive investigations, depositions, and lawsuits and findingd presented in United States Senate HEALTH, EDUCATION, LABOR AND PENSIONS COMMITTEE For Profit Higher Education : The Failure to Safeguard the Federal Investment and Ensure Student Success in XXXX of XXXX. We have to date paid upwards of {$110000.00} on loans that were originally half, if that in the neighborhood of $ XXXX, at the time of borrowing - you can find the payments attached, downloaded directly from Navient 's site on the life of the loans to affirm this fact and .xls spreadsheets that provide greater detail, but XXXX  clarity on the silent killer that is the *capitalized* interest. I have thrown huge sums and even windfalls that would have been circumstance changing at these debts over the years- $ XXXX, $ XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX and XXXX payments where I could to chop at the interest accruing balance. It's all there in the records attached. 

Evidence of all of these acts can be be found in the Senate Committee On Health Education and Labor report on higher education, in the Testimony of XXXX XXXX XXXX. Truly, in reading this report - I was first shocked, then saddened, then angered - because of the time lost, the mental, emotional, and most harmful - financial cost. Worst even, that cost did not just fall on me. As youth hoping to outrun college completion statistics, my family was completely invested in providing the only manner of support they could, which was not liquid cash but more XXXX-pushed loans. 3 generations of my family have poured into XXXX XXXXNavient/Sallie Mae . My grand parents ( grandfather a Korean War veteran and in his latter years a tailor at XXXX XXXX, my grandmother a XXXX XXXX XXXX ), my mother- a XXXX XXXX  who at the time wholly believed in the virtues of higher education and the implied integrity of school staff and officials, and myself- XXXX at the time informed but unaware of the coy and explicit ways in which I was being manipulated into a financial yoke that would haunt me year, after year, after year, after year to follow. That school is now shuttered as listed on their closed school information page - as it should be- though it has taken harm to many people for that to happen. XXXX XXXX XXXX  Much of this was brought to bear primarily due to misrepresentation of cost and transferability of credits and later exacerbated by predatory lending, mismanagement of my account loan accounts, and self-serving allocations of payments made by Sallie Mae and Navient XXXX My original intention when I met with XXXX admissions recruiters in Fall of XXXX was that I would attend my first year or so as a cost-saving measure until I could transfer to my primary choice to which I was accepted w/o financial aid - XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX - where my family is from and most resided at the time- but have incurred out of state tuition fees I couldn't afford due to having applied from XXXX  The recruiter harped repeatedly on their lack of out-of-state costs and the savings available and provided many assurances of transferability of credits both into and out of the institution, which I later uncovered to be an outright lie. She made no mention of the ongoing accreditation issues XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX was facing that would make transfer prohibitive if not remedied. This misrepresentation ultimately resulted in an inability to continue due to mounting costs and inability to transfer ( which would have saved me and my family money after establishing 1 year of residency ). Meaning I would have to stay, pay, and attempt to finish despite cost at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX -- XXXX. It eventually became unsustainable. Once into repayment I was constantly hounded despite the school not making good on its job placement promises and artificially inflated placement numbers. Sallie Mae and Navient representatives called me and my mom, and grandparents tirelessly but failed to provide proper information on my options, leading to non-beneficial amounts being paid by all of us, and at other times when it couldn't be paid, putting me and the loans into extremely costly forbearances that I would later learn had capitalized into principle. Insuring more cost and higher interest. Navient is named as an active and willing participant in practices that were found to be profoundly unethical and predatory and their harm was docuemnted in the Navient AG Multi-State Settlement. 


BELOW ARE A LIST OF DETAILED INTERACTIONS WITH AI AND THE ILLINOIS INSTITUTE OF ART BY PREDATORY TACTIC : Pressured were aggressive and deceptive- recruiter pressured and played on my feelings of failure and stagnation that I had revealed during my initial sit-down- I was consistently pressured to apply for financial aid but never informed that I could decline the acceptance of the awarded aid Misrepresented - cost, employability, completion and job placements- They reiterated these talking points time and again ; first in our sit down chat in the ai admin offices, then again in their printed promotional materials, and again online and in subsequent phone and email communications- Substantially misrepresented true cost ( that while the first year would indeed be slightly less expensive than my other option, tuition would stay the same and even increase in subsequent years, making it categorically far more expensive than my other option ) but they touted post grad job placement which my other option did not - They aggressively pushed federal student loans as an option when I was hesitant and then played on my moms concerns, pushing her into parent plus loans with cost and interest that in her then state of employment were far beyond her means. 
- I was very clear that though I had read the disorganized array of loan materials they shared, I wasnt all the way clear on implications and very earnestly stated I was reliant on their expertise and their stated care for student outcomes - When I said I wanted to circle back so that I could talk with my mom or other trusted sources who had taken loans themselves, I was discouraged and roped into longer and guilty-laden conversation - They also assured me that previous credits earned at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX would transfer, which I also reasonably expected because they were basic first year general studies courses- they did not. And of course this incurred more cost- Beyond that the recruiters and student counselors routinely made substantially misleading statements to me with regard to transferability of credits post AI. Since I made it clear that I wanted to attend for my first possibly second year, then transfer to my school of choice. 
- However, after some time and research as that date neared, I found that my credits did not indeed transfer to XXXX and that I had to either lose my credits earned in the prior 18 mos or stay and complete my education at XXXX. The counselor at the time harped heavily on guilt and fear of failure - reminding me of the time I had already lost in my previous transfer from out of state. In hindsight, I felt this was coercive and deliberate to keep me enrolled as evidenced in the attached affidavit and Senate committee report.

- I stayed, however, this resulted in my first of many depressive episodes that precipitated a steep decline in my grades, a sense of hopelessness and loss that at 20 was indescribable and masked by heightened emotions and youth. 
- They also misrepresented data on their post graduation successful placement rate stating it was very high, where later litigation in fact shows total knowledge of these falsehoods and well as encouragement by managers to obfuscate the true numbers in favor of increasing enrollment in a sales type manor. More concerned with admission and enrollment than educational outcome- The school operated both a gallery and a restaurant called XXXX XXXX ( later changed to XXXX )- where they employed programmed students and counted them in their placements and employment stats ( page 4 of the attached doc ) Omitted - true statistics on student rates of completion, as well as, true cost ( that while the first year would indeed be slightly less expensive than my other option, tuition would stay the same and even increase in subsequent years, making it categorically far more expensive than my other option ) but they touted post grad job placement which my other option did not There was never any mention of potential or ongoing accreditation issues at that campus or any of its sister campus and institutions this would have immediately raised a red flag - When XX/XX/XXXX - How it impacted my decision to attend and take out financial aid - The detriment I suffered is that I never completed my education - having to withdraw due to cost and poor performance related to having to work so much to supplement cost and it haunts me to this day, impacts my confidence because Im plagued by XXXX XXXX  I took a series of whatever I could get jobs, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX I quit without safetynet or options. Each taking me further from completing my education and reaching my professional goals.

I hope this correspondence finds you well. I am writing to bring to your attention a matter concerning my educational loans that necessitates careful consideration and resolution. 

During the period spanning from XXXX to XXXX, I pursued my education at XXXX XXXX located in XXXX XXXX, IL ( now closed ), culminating in my graduation in XXXX. Throughout my academic journey, I availed both federal and private loans to facilitate my educational endeavors. 

Recently, my federal loans were XXXX in XXXX owing to instances of misconduct and the subsequent closure of the institution. This development prompted me to explore the possibility of a similar discharge for my Signature Select private loans, which are currently serviced by Navient, formerly serviced as Sallie Mae.

I kindly request your assistance in assessing the eligibility of my private loans for discharge in alignment with the aforementioned grounds. Your attention to this matter and timely response would be greatly appreciated.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint against Navient Corporation concerning the handling of my consolidation loan, which my wife and I have maintained with Navient for over 20 years. Since XX/XX/year>, we have been attempting to transfer our loan to XXXX XXXX or a government lender to explore available forgiveness options. Despite our repeated requests for assistance, Navient has been unwilling to facilitate this transfer. 

Additionally, in an effort to compel Navient to provide the necessary assistance, I temporarily ceased making payments. However, rather than addressing our request, Navient has resorted to contacting unauthorized third parties, including my mother, my wife 's father, and at least one neighbor, disclosing our private student loan information. This conduct is not only unethical but also constitutes a violation of privacy laws and regulations governing the disclosure of confidential information. 

We are acutely aware of the available options for loan forgiveness and the legal framework that supports such transfers. Navient 's refusal to assist us in this matter and the subsequent disclosure of our private information to unauthorized parties have caused significant distress and are legally indefensible. 

I kindly request the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to investigate this matter and take appropriate action against Navient Corporation for their unethical and illegal practices. We seek your intervention to ensure that Navient facilitates the transfer of our loan to a government lender or XXXX XXXX, and to prevent any further unauthorized disclosure of our private information. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. I look forward to your prompt response and assistance.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem lowering your monthly payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to seek urgent assistance regarding my student loans with Navient, which have become an overwhelming burden over the years. 

Since XX/XX/2009, I have diligently made payments on over 7 private loans with Navient, totaling nearly 15 years of continuous repayment. Regrettably, despite these efforts, the structure of my loan payments appears to have disproportionately favored smaller, lower interest rate loans, leaving my higher interest loans largely untouched. 

Of utmost concern are my two largest loans with Navient : one amounting to {$28000.00} at a staggering interest rate of 14.5 %, and another totaling {$14000.00}, also at 14.5 %. The disparity between the original principal amounts and the accrued interest is deeply distressing. For instance, my largest loan initially bore a principal of {$12000.00}, yet the accumulated interest has ballooned to an astonishing {$30000.00}. Similarly, the second largest loan, originating at {$10000.00}, has accrued a daunting {$12000.00} in interest. 

As a single mother without external support, the financial strain imposed by these loans has become unbearable. Despite my persistent efforts, the outstanding balance remains insurmountable, compounded by relentless communication from Navient during periods of financial hardship. 

I am reaching out in desperation, seeking guidance on potential avenues for relief or renegotiation of these exorbitant interest rates. The current terms render the prospect of loan repayment unfeasible, and I am left questioning whether I have already repaid the principal borrowed, now struggling under the weight of accrued interest. 

Your expertise and support in navigating this distressing situation would be immensely appreciated. Please advise on any available resources or strategies that could assist in alleviating this financial burden. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I eagerly await your response and remain hopeful for a positive resolution. 

Warm regards, Please help.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I was notified via my online portal and email that my School Misconduct Discharge application was received by Navient. This application was submitted to dispute my private loans and request their discharge due to the mismanagement and misconduct of The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, where I attended from XXXX to XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX is no longer an open institution and has not been for quite some time. I provided all necessary documentation, including detailed responses to all questions, evidence from articles and government-affiliated sources, a signed letter, and transcripts from the community college I attended afterward, showing that none of my credits from XXXX XXXX XXXX transferred due to its lack of accreditation and affiliation with educational institution as it was a for-profit school, and much more. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I received an email from Navient stating that my loan servicer would be changing to XXXX beginning XX/XX/XXXX. Concerned and confused, I immediately called Navients department that handles school misconduct applications. The representative confirmed that my application was received on XX/XX/XXXX, and assured me that I would receive a response within XXXX business days from that date. 

However, that time has passed, and today, when I logged into my Navient account, I received a notification stating that my administrative forbearance will end in 36 days ; this notification was located in the notification center only. I have not received any communication, whether by email, letter, or phone call from advocate, regarding the status of my applicationneither approval nor denial. 

I am requesting an update on the status of my application, as I believe I have submitted all required documentation correctly and promptly. Despite being informed by a Navient representative on XX/XX/XXXX, that I would receive a response within XXXX business days, I am still awaiting an answer, and I am now faced with the unexpected news that my administrative forbearance is ending soon. 

I have attempted to contact the same department at Navient twice today, but unfortunately, I have not been able to reach anyone.

Consumer complaint narrative:
After my initial call to XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX XXXX. I was called constantly from the recruiter to enroll. He told me several times that they had a XXXX XXXX graduate placement with several connections to XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in the city of XXXX XXXX, WI. I was told the overall cost would be {$42000.00} to complete my XXXX XXXX. My decision to continue my education was based on that number. The final cost was much more than originally quoted by the recruiter ( about {$20000.00} more ; to which they never gave me an explanation ). I won the XXXX XXXX XXXX scholarship from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ; it was to be {$25000.00}. Apparently I tied with another student and they split the scholarship between the two of us for {$12000.00} each. Between the time I graduated and when I started paying my loans, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX managed to add about {$20000.00} to my debt. They also failed to apply my scholarship ( from their own institution ). 

They told me that they would assist me in finding a job after graduation and that they had several contacts in the XXXX XXXX, WI area and the base salary for a first year XXXX XXXX  would be about {$50000.00} per year ( XXXX ) and they had a XXXX XXXX job placement rate. As a matter of fact, I was contacted by an employment specialist, who was reading through the XXXX XXXX, WI local job listings and was suggesting I apply for " XXXX XXXX  '' jobs. I asked about their contacts in my community and he said they didn't have any. I was able to find a XXXX job as a XXXX XXXX for the XXXX XXXX, just to make ends meet. After a few months of NOTHING, I was able to find a job as a " XXXX  XXXX '' for a XXXX XXXX XXXX ( NOT RELATED TO XXXX XXXX  AT ALL ). When the employment specialist found out I was employed, he told me that he was closing my file and " good luck ''. 

In XXXX I enrolled in a XXXX XXXX course at XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX and was told that none of my credits would transfer from XXXX  XXXX XXXX. Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to lodge a formal complaint against Navient for its aggressive and unethical debt collection practices that are in direct violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). Despite my clear communication regarding my current financial situation, including the fact that I am in the process of being placed on XXXX, I have been subjected to relentless harassment, including multiple daily calls and unwarranted contact with my friends and family. 

The process of being placed on XXXX has been lengthy and through no fault of my own, it has taken over a year to receive a response. During this time, my financial situation has been precarious, and I have made this known to Navient representatives on multiple occasions. However, this has not deterred the company from attempting to locate me by reaching out to my personal contacts, despite having my up-to-date contact information on file. 

Moreover, during a recent interaction with XXXX XXXX, I was denied the opportunity to speak with a supervisor when requested. The agent insinuated that I have no rights under the FDCPA and proceeded to threaten legal action against me for funds I currently do not possess. The agents conduct was not only unprofessional but also deeply distressing, as they even threatened to target my XXXX grandfathers XXXX and XXXX XXXX benefits. 

This relentless pursuit has placed an immense emotional and physical burden on me and my family. It has caused undue stress and XXXX, which is exacerbated by the fear of financial insecurity for my XXXX XXXX 

I demand that Navient immediately cease these inappropriate collection tactics and adhere to the regulations set forth by the FDCPA. I also request a written apology for the distress caused and assurance that such incidents will not recur. 

Please take immediate action to investigate this matter and ensure that Navients debt collection practices align with legal and ethical standards. I expect a prompt response to this complaint and a resolution that respects my rights as a consumer.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XX/XX/XXXX 

As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX and their Parent company, XXXX were investigated by the attorneys general of several states and have been found to have acted in a fraudulent manner. 

Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by The XXXX XXXX, the Biden administration has just announced a blanket discharge for anyone enrolled at XX/XX/XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. 
My Federal loans in the amount of ( Your amount here ) were discharged and my credit repaired. 

I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. 

These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools '', but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. 

I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. 
After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates?

Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? 

Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 

I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved.

This application is a sham.

Why do we need to prove anything?

Navient knows who we are.

Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. 

Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll.

Senator Elizabeth Warren has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!

On XX/XX/year>, I received notice that I was denied : " ..., your application for School Misconduct Discharge has been denied.

A variety of criteria are used to determine eligibility, including, but not limited to, proof of resulting harm, sufficient documentation supporting your claim, date when events occurred or when you experienced harm, etc. Because we review each application holistically, it is not possible to identify specific criteria that caused your application to be denied. Consumer complaint narrative: I am currently in my XXXX year working full time at a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I have tried repeatedly over the years to get in on this program. Ive contacted them when I couldnt even access my personal student loan information for long periods of time. Then I couldnt figure out how to apply for the program or what to do. So many, many times I could not get through to anyone as Id be on hold for literally hours. Then the few times I did speak with someone - I was always told my better option was to put my loans in forbearance for the time being then sign up for the program after the forbearance was up. The most recent that this occurred was during the COVID pandemic. But that was not the first time. That was probably the tenth time that had happened, at least. My kids thought I didnt know what I was talking about because they had called and had someone super helpful walk them through step by step in the process, follow up with them to make sure everything got set up, etc. Then on a few occasions Id had them with me when I tried to call and they realized I wasnt exaggerating or making excuses- I literally couldnt get through and when I did it was suggested I just put the loans in forbearance again. My loans now, with interest over the years, have probably tripled in the amount owed ( Im not sure exactly- bc I was never able to get exact information so many times ). In the meantime, my husband died ( very unexpectedly ) and now with only my income- I barely am able to pay basic living bills month to month ( living expenses, insurance and taxes take up almost all of my pay ). Now the COVID forbearance is over and the only options Ive now been given ( and I honestly dont even know who the company is anymore thats servicing the loans- I thought it was still Navient but apparently not? ) are payments that are more than half of my bring home pay. Its so frustrating and stressful and impossible to figure out. And I accept a lot of the responsibility for taking out the loans and not paying on them for so long. But now I cant get any loans due to the high debt, Im XXXX XXXX XXXX and I dont see any kind of doable resolution. Its just that for so long I tried to get help and it wasnt available its made the situation that much worse.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem lowering your monthly payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX, I am writing to share my concerns with Navient, the services of my private student loan that I took out in XXXX to attend college. 

Since graduating in XXXX, I have consistently made my payments until recently due to financial hardship, both due to a loss of income and due to XXXX. My account is now delinquent, and I have made multiple attempts to contact Navient to adjust my payments to lower them or to extend my term giving me the ability to manage my health and wellbeing. Instead, I am consistently harassed by Navient, having received calls daily and sometimes multiple times a day. Additionally, these calls are made by people working from home across the country, so I was getting unidentified or unlisted calls which I avoided because I did not know legitimacy of the call. 


I am a XXXX XXXX with diagnosed XXXX, for which I have been trying to manage for 10 years. My original loan of {$17000.00} currently has a balance of {$20000.00}, for which I have already paid similar amount over the last 10 years. While I went to college for XXXX XXXX, I was unable to go into the field due to the paying of jobs and need for further education and instead went into another field. In these 10 years, I have made good faith efforts to pay my monthly payment and it was not until recently in the last year that I struggled, after changing XXXX  due to XXXX  in my XXXX for my XXXX and the challenges affecting my XXXX. 

I reached out to Navient, who placed me on a modified payment plan to lower the interest for 6 months, which at the end only increased my monthly payment even more. I applied again, and it dropped it only minor, and I struggled so for the past couple months have been unable to pay. 

I have shared with Navient that I am trying to pay for a XXXX XXXX for my XXXX, so this large monthly payment which only increases, drastically impacts my ability to address my health. I have been told that I am already on a plan, so I can not be put on any other. I have received harassing phone calls, often multiple times a day. When I shared I already spoke with someone, they said it wasnt reported. When I shared I physically could not pay, they marked it as me refusing to which I argued that I was not refusing, I just was not able to. I was told by a manager that I spoke with over the numerous calls that they can call as many times as they want in a day or week, even if they already spoke with me. 


I took out this loan to attend school, however it was a private loan that was sent directly to me and not the institution and covered more than the cost of attendance being used to cover other expenses at the time. I went into it knowing I would need to make payments, and over the last 10 years I have ensured my payments were received even when I was only paid monthly and dealing with other life events or the challenges of my XXXX. The harassing phone calls when I was unable to make a payment initially for the first time was so overwhelming. The multiple phone calls from unidentified numbers, from multiple different numbers and area codes. Calls while I am working. I have asked for options to make it more affordable, especially since I have already made paid back the total of original loan but owning double. But these come at a cost, because then the payments increase above the original amount I was paying, putting me even further behind which is where I currently am. 


As I have explained to Navient, I have a XXXX and am currently trying to afford just to go to XXXX  and get a XXXX XXXX which is expensive and then requires additional money for the care of XXXX XXXX. I have explained that I am basically needing to decide between my health or a loan payment that only increases. Still they continue to harass me with phone calls despite sharing I am unable to pay at this time. They say they can just keep calling, and it affects my health even more. There is no reason I should be getting calls every day, after having a conversation with them to explain my hardship, or to get multiple phone calls a day. The calls should be clearly identified as someone calling from Navient, and I should not be getting calls while at work or for them to tell me they can call however many times that they want to to collect. 


I never asked to be attacked and have this XXXX. I have had a difficult 10 years just being able to survive, and finally when I am trying to take the steps to live a better life, I am shackled by a company who has consistently raised interest rates or my monthly payment after helping. A hardship payment plan, should not mean after 6 months that they increase the monthly amount. 

When I removed my bank from Navient for the automatic payment, they still proceeded to charge my bank despite me having removed them from my account online. 

Yesterday, I got another call and shared I could not make payment with information above. Hour later I got an email that I had a payment scheduled, for which I called them and said I never scheduled a payment and that I shared I could not pay. 

This is not the first time that Navient has failed. Back in XXXX when they serviced my federal student loans- I was paying two payments a month for my subsidized and unsubsidized loans. I was contacted by them to lower my payment under the income driven repayment plan, which did help because instead of making two payments, I made one and it was about half overall. However, I then learned only AFTER consolidating them, that it restarted my PSLF qualification for those loans, eliminating all the months I had already made payments. I was then told there was nothing that could be done- and this further extended the timeline for me to pay these down with me having two more years. 

I need the CFPB to address the harassment of Navient calls, as well as their deceptive practices. They intentionally document a refusal to pay, despite trying to work out hardship or payment structure, and even then will schedule payments and authorize them even if removed. I understand fully my obligation and commitment I made to pay this, however at a time where my health is struggling and needing assistance, the harassing phone calls, failure to properly document, and increased payments after hardship plan has ended does not help. If a hardship plan is provided to assist, it should not be later increased as that is not a true good faith effort on their end.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX of XXXX, I contacted Navient to inform that I no longer was employed and wanted to setup a new payment plan. I informed them that I was receiving unemployment and government assistance. They refused to assist me with the matter. In XXXX of XXXX, I received my tax refund, and made a payment arrangement with them to get caught up. The customer service representative I spoke with informed me that my next payment would not be due until XXXX of XXXX 

In late XXXX of XXXX  I began receiving calls that my payment was now due. Between XX/XX/year> and XXXX of XXXX, I verbally asked Navient to verify the billing information with me and review the call from XXXX of XXXX. Every phone call was met with the promise that a supervisor would reach out to me, after they reviewed the call, and I assured them that once the billing was confirmed that I would make the payment. 

After a call on XX/XX/year>, I decided to submit a written inquiry about the billing request and issues. 

Navient waited until after the 60 day mark to respond and reported delinquency to the credit bureaus. 

I have requested for them to remove that marking from my credit report because according to the law, 15 U.S. Code 1666 - Correction of billing errors, I had the right to verify the debt, without penalty.

According to the law, 15 U.S. Code 1666 ( 3 ) sets forth the reasons for the obligors belief ( to the extent applicable ) that the statement contains a billing error, the creditor shall, unless the obligor has, after giving such written notice and before the expiration of the time limits herein specified, agreed that the statement was correct ( A ) not later than thirty days after the receipt of the notice, send a written acknowledgment thereof to the obligor, unless the action required in subparagraph ( B ) is taken within such thirty-day period, and ( B ) not later than two complete billing cycles of the creditor ( in no event later than ninety days ) after the receipt of the notice and prior to taking any action to collect the amount, or any part thereof, indicated by the obligor under paragraph ( 2 ) either ( i ) make appropriate corrections in the account of the obligor, including the crediting of any finance charges on amounts erroneously billed, and transmit to the obligor a notification of such corrections and the creditors explanation of any change in the amount indicated by the obligor under paragraph ( 2 ) and, if any such change is made and the obligor so requests, copies of documentary evidence of the obligors indebtedness ; or ( ii ) send a written explanation or clarification to the obligor, after having conducted an investigation, setting forth to the extent applicable the reasons why the creditor believes the account of the obligor was correctly shown in the statement and, upon request of the obligor, provide copies of documentary evidence of the obligors indebtedness. In the case of a billing error where the obligor alleges that the creditors billing statement reflects goods not delivered to the obligor or his designee in accordance with the agreement made at the time of the transaction, a creditor may not construe such amount to be correctly shown unless he determines that such goods were actually delivered, mailed, or otherwise sent to the obligor and provides the obligor with a statement of such determination.

The investigation not being completed before the 60 days violates the law, 15 U.S. Code 1666 and therefore should be removed from my credit report.

The U.S. Department of Education found that The XXXX XXXX and its parent company, XXXX XXXX XXXX, made pervasive and substantial misrepresentations to prospective students about post-graduation employment rates, salaries, and career services during that time. Why should I and so many others have to pay fraudulent student loans for a school that no longer exists, scammed and took advantage of XXXX of individuals when the Biden-Harris administration wiped federal loans for the crimes that were committed? 

Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these for profit schools, such as XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ), I was able to file a XXXX XXXX claim with the Dept. of Education against XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) XXXX years ago and it was sitting in pending review status. Luckily, the Biden Harris Administration have provided relief to XXXX students who were defrauded by the XXXX XXXX and my Fed. loans of approx. {$92000.00} are going to be discharged. 

My XXXX XXXX XXXX was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX settlement for which I was a post-class member. 

I am aware that Navient was sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend for profit schools NOW!

How do you ever expect me to pay this back? I am dropping approx {$550.00} a month for these loans to only pay interest. END THIS SUFFERING FOR ME AND SO MANY OTHERS.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: Confusing or misleading advertising
Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended the University XXXX XXXX  from XXXX  XXXX to Spring XXXX, when I graduated with my XXXX I was a community college transfer student in the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The program was marketed as a prestigious opportunity for non-traditional students, particularly those from XXXX  colleges, to earn an XXXX XXXX degree. The advertisements emphasized inclusivity and the promise of support for low-income students. All over the XXXX  website were claims that low-income students would qualify for the no-loan financial aid program. However, it wasn't until I had already moved to XXXX and registered for classes that I was informed that the no-loan policy did not include students in the XXXX XXXX 

From one of the attached recruitment emails, " As a XXXX student in thXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX you will have access to the same classes, the same faculty, the same classmates, the same resources, and the same diploma as the undergraduates who are taking a more traditional path. '' The financial strain caused by XXXX XXXX misleading practices had severe consequences for my family. My partner and I faced significant debt, causing immense stress and pushing us to the brink of XXXX. XXXX 's policies exacerbated our financial instability, undermining the dream of an XXXX XXXX education and placing a heavy burden on our household. The emotional and mental toll of this situation was profound, affecting our daily lives and well-being. 

I also experienced significant difficulty with the credit transfer process. As a first-generation college student, I had minimal support navigating this process. XXXX did not confirm which of my community college credits would be accepted until very late in the process. I had already turned down another university that accepted all my credits, believing XXXX XXXX  program offered a no-debt opportunity, only to face academic setbacks and added financial burdens due to the delayed and incomplete credit transfer process. 

I also had a negative experience with my private student loans. Misled into believing I qualified for XXXX 's no-loan policy, I was forced to take out substantial loans. My partner 's family had to co-sign these loans because my parents were unemployed. The pressure to accept these terms was intense, and I was led to believe it was my only option, resulting in a significant financial burden. The financial aid department at XXXX pushed me towards Sallie Mae, with staff members having connections with their representatives ( see attached emails ). Due to the high interest rates, I eventually refinanced through XXXX, part of the Navient/Sallie Mae family , which was absolutely necessary to manage the financial strain. The financial aid representative at XXXX that I reached out to put me in touch with her associate at Sallie Mae to help me navigate the situation. She thought they would be able to help me. This representative simply suggested that I refinance with XXXX when I could. 

I chose to attend XXXX over another four-year institution, lured by the promise of an XXXX XXXX XXXX and the supposed financial support for low-income students. This decision, influenced by misleading advertising, resulted in significant financial and academic challenges that I had not anticipated. This other institution accepted all of my other credits upon acceptance. Had I known that I was not going to be included in the no-loan program, I would not have gone to XXXX and would have been in a significantly better financial situation. The financial difficulties and the need to take out large private loans have negatively impacted my credit. I have experienced issues with credit reporting, making it difficult to secure financing for essential needs such as a car or a lease. The burden of debt has had a long-lasting effect on my financial stability and creditworthiness. 

I experienced numerous issues with the financial aid process, including pressure and misleading information. Unlike traditional undergraduates, XXXX  students received their financial aid packages on a rolling basis, creating uncertainty and stress. Critical information about the exclusion of XXXX  students from the no-loan policy was withheld until it was too late to reconsider my options, leading to significant financial strain. 

The recruitment tactics used by XXXX were aggressive and high-pressure. The program was portrayed as a beacon of hope for non-traditional students, using our stories to market diversity and inclusivity. However, the reality was starkly different, with XXXX  students excluded from the no-loan policy and facing significant financial and academic challenges. The misleading recruitment tactics lured me into a situation that was far from the supportive environment promised. 

My experience at the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  program was marked by misleading advertising, aggressive recruitment tactics, and significant financial and administrative challenges. The promises made during recruitment were not fulfilled, and the support for non-traditional students was grossly inadequate. This situation has had a profound impact on my life, leading to substantial debt, financial hardship, and negative effects on my credit. I believe I was misled and cheated by the XXXX XXXX XXXX and I am seeking legal support to address these grievances. Thank you for considering my case. 

I also recommend reading the following article where other students share similar experiences from around the time I graduated : https : XXXX Select quotes : - " For XXXX, XXXX is his dream school but certain administrative and financial aid policies in XXXX have disappointed him and many other students who envisioned a more traditional XXXX experience. '' - My financial aid package is really not big enough and sometimes it is a struggle to keep up with paying rent and taking care of my family while taking out all these loans. 
- " XXXX  lists four financing and payment options for XXXX  students on its website : loans, direct loans, direct PLUS loans and the XXXX monthly budget plan. Around XXXX percent of XXXX  students take out these loans, but for some students, it is still not enough. '' - `` XXXX said that his interaction with XXXX  was probably the most stressful part of his transition to XXXX. '' - Some noted that they received their aid packages from XXXX much later than at other institutions.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
In the mid to late XXXX, I attended the XXXX XXXX. My loans were all serviced by then Sallie-Mae , now Navient. After getting almost through the program, and realizing that I had yet to learn ( I was in the end of my third year ) anything related to the field I was trying to get a degree in, I parted ways from the school. I spent the next decade and some change struggling to pay my loans, going on income plans, seeking the various repayment plans offered, etc. Through it all, there was nothing Navient would do to lower the payments or whatever about the 2-3 private loans I had through them. So I had no choice but to pay the minimum.

Come this year, and the findings by the Federal justice system, the US Department of Education, that XXXX XXXX XXXX were basically running an elaborate fraud scheme, I started looking into my options. In regards to the two big private loans, one was initially for ~ {$6800.00}, and the other for ~ {$13000.00}. At this point, I'd paid the smaller one off ( the initial principle plus almost {$4700.00} in interest. ) and was most of the way done with the larger ( over the years, I'd paid all but about {$3500.00} off out of the {$13000.00} initial amount plus almost {$10000.00} in interest. ) Still, I wanted to be out from under it. 

Cue the beginnings of the long and arduous fight I've been dealing with since. 

First, I messaged Navient about if there were any options. It took a bit, but they sent me a vague email of " Oh, there's this school misconduct app, check your navient inbox by clicking this link! '' Which I attempted, but the link was broken. 

THen I sent them another message, saying " Hey, look, I got this response to my question, but where do I find the form. Your link is broken. '' The somewhat ugly response was " Fill out the app provided in a previous email. '' Very unpleasant form letter that all but said the word " XXXX  '' in it. Further attempts there got me nowhere. 

I ended up having to search via XXXX to find the application, and that took me to a XXXX XXXX that provided a link to a third party site because Navient was basically making this process as painful and impossible as they could. 

Then I filled out like ... .fourteen pages of application? I cited the specific loan numbers, the amounts, provided the Education Department " Summary of Findings '' in regards to the school, and had to go into extensive detail about how the school defrauding me and them was... harmful. As if being in crippling, inescapable debt wasnt bad enough, they wanted all kinds of personal details about the experience. I told them what I could. I even pointed out that while I understood we were both defrauded by the school 's overblown and glorified ponzi scheme, the feds had determined what the school had done was... well. Fraudulent. That the Federal Government was going to be REIMBURSING the money paid off on Federal loans for those schools -- and given that the federal government can be pretty miserly with cash, that's huge -- and that it felt pretty shady the way this was being handled by Navient. ( Particularly since the feds had to bully them into even doing this much. ) I honestly wanted my loans wiped out ... and I asked for the ~ {$30000.00} back I had paid them over the decade. Or at least a good portion of it, because ... if it was fraud... then it was also theft. They paid the school, but they made way more off me than they lost to the school. 

I submitted the application. Got an email after a few days that they had gotten the application, and my loan was placed in forbearance for 60 days. Over the next few weeks, I received a ton of ads from them about personal loans and the like, but nothing on the application. Then I get a " Your loans are going to be transferred to XXXX '' notice in my email. 

So I keep checking. Nothing has changed. 

This morning, XX/XX/XXXX, I check again ( I've checked a couple of nights a week since I submitted the application ). There, my loan has been updated -- what I owe has been " Zeroed out '' with a rather interesting backdate of XX/XX/XXXX. But there's no correspondence, no email ( and yes, I checked all my spam folders ), and I've gotten nothing in the mail. In addition my account is still labeled as " in forbearance '' for " another 10 days. '' Given everything, it felt shady, so I used their " Chat with us! '' button to get a person on chat. I really just wanted some kind of information. 

I was informed " oh yes, your application seems to be going through the approval process '' and that " oh, it takes a long time to process, so you'll get an email when its done. '' Okay, fair, I suppose, but really lousy customer service in a history of lousy customer service and shady actions ( Like not informing me ever when the interest rate on a loan changed -- sometimes by as much as 5 % from one month to the next, double dipping on taking money out of my account for monthly payments, etc. ). So I inquired if there was any chance of reimbursement on the money paid in to what was essentially a fraud scheme, and i was told " Oh, well, no. No money will be refunded for payments made PRIOR to your misconduct application being submitted. '' Which ... .like... Let 's think about that. Why would I pay AFTER submitting the application? The whole point of it was to get the loan wiped out and seek reimbursement for the financial damage caused by what has been revealed to be a fraud scheme by a school and capitalized on by a predatory lending company -- in addition to the recent decision about XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX and other colleges like them, I found in my search today that NAVIENT/SALLIE MAE has already been brought up in the past for BEING PART OF THIS WHOLE SCHEME -- there was a case in 2022 that revealed internal memos and stuff about how they were basically preying on people with these loans and fully expected people to default, refused to offer repayment plans, yo-yo-ing interest rates , the whole thing.

I informed the person at Navient I was talking to that I would appreciate documentation of all of this, and that at this point, I would be reporting the company for fraudulent behavior, theft, shady business practices, and seeking legal options for this.

At the end of the day, I'm one person, and they've made almost twice as much from me as they paid to the " school '' I attended. For them, $ XXXX is probably chump change... but for me thats a year 's income BEFORE taxes.

And they service millions of borrowers. There were thousands of people from the schools that the ED found guilty of this fraud scheme. If they're like me, then thats millions of dollars that Navient has STOLEN and DEFRAUDED from every day people.

Something needs to be done. Someone needs to investigate.

My XX/XX/XXXX complaint was for the same to be done for my private loans from Art Institute. 

Navient replied with a " Proactive School Misconduct '' form I received on XX/XX/XXXX. In Navients CFPB complaint response, they mentioned the 2 Art Institute loans would qualify, but my 3rd loan from another school would not. My School Misconduct Application was submitted to Navient on XX/XX/XXXX. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I received denials for my 2 Art Institute loans and the reason given was, " Navient carefully considers a variety of factors in determining whether a private loan should be discharged based on school misconduct and you do not meet the requirements for discharge based on misconduct by your school. '' This is a generic response that does not say in any means why my loans that are already proven fraudulent did not meet their 'criteria '. Navient is giving blanket denials and trying to stir up 'good faith ' by having an application but approving only a few early applicants. 

I would like at the very least a specific reason why my application was denied, and the ability to resubmit, if necessary, additional evidence on top of the evidence I provided in my application.

I received a letter from XXXX XXXX XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX stating my loans were XXXX and I would receive a refund XXXX. I didn't fully understand the different type of loans- I was told consolidating my loans would be best for me- yet I never made dent paying them off. The letter I received from the XXXX XXXX XXXX didn't explain any of this and said I WOULD receive a refund XXXX. I kept calling both the XXXX XXXX XXXX and Navient ( about 6 times ) throughout the XXXX and now into 2024 year and 3 times after the deadline of XX/XX/XXXX. I never received my refund. I finally received a response that I have a Commercial FFEL which gets relief but not a refund ( which was different than the letter stated in XX/XX/XXXX ).

Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, ( insert your school here ). As a matter of fact, ( school name ) was investigated by ( insert your story here ). 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these online for profit schools, such as ( your school ), I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against ( your school ), and my Fed. loans of ( $ dollar amount ) were discharged and my credit repaired. 
My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXX settlement for which I was a full class member. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit online schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW! 

Additionally there were multiple occasions when I was pulled out of class and told I could not go back to class without signing for more loans. So far I have paid XXXX on what was originally a XXXX loan and still owe XXXX. My federal loans were forgiven and refunded so why should I still have to pay and not get a refund on these loans.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I emailed Navient on Monday XX/XX/2024, asking for an application for the School Misconduct Discharge Application. Navient emailed me back on Tuesday XX/XX/2024, and stated the following : " Thank you for inquiring about a school misconduct discharge for your private loans. Upon review, we confirmed that your loan is not eligible for our School Misconduct discharge program since the school you attended was non-profit since the loan was originated. If you are having difficulty making your current payment amount on these loans and are seeking information on any options that are available to you for your specific financial situation, please call us at XXXX where a specialist will work with you to assist you further on this matter. More information can also be found at Navient.com '' However, according to The Project on Predatory Student Lending, there was no mention that the school has to be a for profit school only to qualify for the school misconduct application only if you felt that you were a victim of a predatory school. I attended a nonprofit university. Just because the University is a non-profit university, that does not mean they did not conspire with XXXX XXXXNavient to conspire to deceive me into predatory loan and I should be provided the chance to challenge my Navient student loan and feel that Navient is preventing me in doing so by withholding me an application. I hope that this complaint will help lead to the result that I need to challenge this wrongdoing. 

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended the XXXX XXXX University, a widely known predatory school, and want to apply for discharge of the Navient private student loans the university was issued on my behalf. 

The Project on Predatory Student Lending ( PPSL ), the nonprofit legal organization representing borrowers defrauded by predatory colleges that has been monitoring the XXXX XXXX XXXX  lawsuit, in which I am a class member, issued a press release stating " Navient began quietly sending a new application to a select few borrowers, including some PPSL clients, allowing borrowers who experienced misconduct at their school to apply directly for discharge of private loans ''. 

As a class member of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX lawsuit, which ruled that I am entitled to federal loan discharge, I believe I meet the stated criteria to apply for a School Misconduct Discharge Application for my private loan, also issued by Navient. 

I contacted Navients Office of Consumer Advocate on XX/XX/XXXX requesting a School Misconduct Discharge Application for private loans. 

XX/XX/XXXX I received a response stating that " additional information was needed in order to fully review my concerns, such as my Navient account number '' and I promptly replied with the information they had requested. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a reply stating : " Thank you for inquiring about a school misconduct discharge for your private loan. Your loan type ( Refinance ) does not meet the criteria for you to receive an application. '' I believe this is incorrect as I do not have a refinance loan. 

Navient issued standard Private loans to the university on my behalf. I did consolidate my debt with a different lender essentially leaving the Navient account as " paid in full '', however, Navient did issue the initial loans which I am currently still paying.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I contacted XXXX XXXX, which became Navient, many times over many years and asked to be placed in the most favorable repayment plan for my situation ( XXXX, unemployed, with significant financial hardship ). Instead of placing me in an income-based repayment plan, they placed me into forbearance and deferment for the maximum period allowed by law. It wasn't until I exhausted all allowable months of forbearance and deferment and called dozens of times pleading for help that I finally found someone at XXXX XXXXXXXXNavient willing to allow me to apply for an income-based repayment plan in XX/XX/year>. Since this experience, my loans have been transferred to XXXX XXXX, then XXXX, and now XXXX XXXX. It is my understanding that all of these months in forbearance, deferment, and financial hardship are supposed to be credited to my account by the Department of Education with a One-Time IDR Account Adjustment, but this has not happened yet. I am still waiting and very worried that XXXX XXXXXXXXNavient 's negligence will add many years to my loan term.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX. As a matter of fact, XXXX XXXX XXXX have shuttered all their doors and have been found guilty of illegal recruiting practices, consumer fraud, and many other violations. ( https : //www.justice.gov/XXXX ) My degree, which sunk me into over XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX dollars in student loan debt, is essentially worthless and has caused complete havoc and hardship in my life since I started chipping away at them over XXXX  years ago with all of my payments just going towards interest. I will die with these loans if something is not done. 

Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by XXXX XXXX XXXX my federal student loans were forgiven by Dept. of Education under the Biden administration. A total of {$60000.00} was discharged and my credit was repaired. ( https : //www.ed.gov/XXXX ) I am also aware that Navient was sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a `` preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of the borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for-profit schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices?

I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. I believe I completely qualify for this application and am confused as to why I have yet to be included. Though I dont understand at this point why I need to prove anything and that Navient knows who we are, I believe I am owed an opportunity to unburden myself with these loans from a scam school. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend for-profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. Senator XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I received private student loans to attend the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from Fall XXXX - Fall XXXX. I graduated with my XXXX in XXXX. ( Amount included in current statement, attached ). During that time I took out both private and federal loans. The school has since closed, having filed for XXXX XXXX Bankruptcy in XXXX after having been open since XXXX. The loan provider for my federal loans is currently XXXX and the Private loan holder is XXXX, which is operated by Navient. 

The reason I believe this is a show of misconduct by the school and should be eligible to be waived under Navient 's guidelines- it is currently not - is before I arrived in XXXX, the school had begun having major, earth shattering financial problems in the XXXX of dollars. They continued to mismanage their funds and assets all the way until XXXX when the school closed its doors. None of the financial mismanagement was reported to me, or the other prospective students, nor was it shared by the institution once I began attending. As a result, I am stuck with over $ XXXX in student loans for a school that can no longer support me as an alumni in any way. 

People do not pay XXXX figures for an education at other longstanding schools like XXXX or XXXX simply for the notable teachers or unique, thought-provoking classes- of which we had both at XXXX. No, students who attend XXXX XXXX colleges are paying for a brand name that can open doors, a legacy that withstands many decades and generations, and the continued support of an institution within the trade communities and beyond. These are things the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX can longer offer. 

If this were in fact a school where more than just artists who attended, it is my belief that a class action for the waiver of all loans would already be in the works. Unfortunately, artists are notoriously bad at paperwork, and as we are not a XXXX or a XXXX, the personal connections to local and federal government are few and surely underutilized. 

On a personal note, I am currently experiencing hardship as a result of job loss and am risking destroying my credit report because I am not able to afford the monthly private loan payments since there are few payment plans available. A lot of artists, who often work as freelancers with little social safety net in place, struggle with this same issue.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative:
I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to dispute the validity and accuracy of my student loan, specifically concerning [ Loan Account Number ]. According to my research and understanding of relevant laws, I believe there are grounds to challenge the loan on the following bases : 1. Violation of the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : I contend that the loan agreement provided by your institution did not adequately disclose all the relevant terms and conditions of the loan. This violates the requirements set forth in the TILA, which mandates lenders to provide clear and transparent information to borrowers. 



2. Failure to Provide Required Disclosures : I have not received certain mandatory disclosures as mandated by the Department of Education and other applicable laws. These include but are not limited to the total cost of the loan, annual percentage rate ( APR ), and repayment terms. 



3. Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : I have reason to believe that the loan has been inaccurately reported to credit bureaus, negatively impacting my creditworthiness. This potential violation of the FCRA raises concerns about the accuracy and integrity of the loan information on my credit reports. 



4. Lack of Verification of Debt : Pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I request verification of the debt in question. I expect you to provide detailed documentation that validates the existence, amount, and ownership of the loan. 



5. Potential Statute of Limitations : I am exploring the possibility that the statute of limitations on this debt may have expired. If that is the case, pursuing collection activities on this loan would be in violation of the applicable laws. 





Additionally, I reserve my right to seek legal counsel and take further action to protect my rights under the law if these matters are not adequately addressed. 



I look forward to your prompt attention to this matter and a resolution that upholds the principles of fairness and compliance with applicable laws. Please acknowledge receipt of this letter by mail or email. 



Thank you for your cooperation. 



Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative: I received an email inviting me to submit an application of school misconduct on the basis that I'd previously contacted my servicer ( Navient ) about discharging XXXX private loans opened during the period of time that I attended XXXX XXXX  ( i.e., XXXX  XXXX  ) in XXXX XXXX. XXXX subsequently closed due to being found guilty of defrauding and misleading the public about their job placement rates and amount of money their students would earn compared to students attending other schools. My application was denied stating that I did not meet criteria to have my loans discharged. I contacted Navient about getting a better explanation of the criteria that I did not meet. After several rounds of contacting them, I was finally furnished a letter which stated their was no evidence that I was harmed despite me submitting evidence that my federal loans opened by this school was fully discharged based upon my attendance during the years that XXXX XXXX was found guilty of misleading practices. The school that I attended used high pressure tactics to lure me into XXXX private high variable rate loans that I have been stuck paying on 20 years later and have not defaulted on because I am conscious of my credit. The loans that I opened were approximately XXXX, and XXXX respectively. Today, I have a balance greater than XXXX, yet Navient says there is no evidence of harm. Navient decided to forgive student loan debt for certain XXXX XXXX borrowers but only if they defaulted on their loan. I was not apart of that group because my loan was current. I have attempted to get someone to contact me to help with me appealing the denial. The contact phone number to the Navient Client Advocacy team is never answered by a live person. It is a voicemail box that requires borrowers to leave a message and wait for someone to call you back. This almost never works out if they call you back at all. I have been attempting to resolve this issue for a few months. I think the decision was baseless and unfair. Navient has already demonstrated their awareness of the fact that XXXX XXXX defrauded borrowers with loans that they service ; however, they are unwilling to do the right thing by borrowers who continue to pay on these bad loans.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to complain about Navients unfair handling of my XXXX XXXX XXXX debt and their refusal to honor my contractual right to a defense to repayment under the FTCs Holder Rule. 

I attended the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) in XXXX, IL, from XXXX to XXXX. This school was later named XXXX . I XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX that cost me {$51000.00}. Notably, I did not accrue any federal student loan debt in the course of attending XXXX. My financial aid advisors deceptively saddled me entirely with XXXX XXXX XXXX debt, despite the fact that I had Title IV eligibility XXXX XXXX XXXX. I currently owe Navient about {$83000.00} in XXXX XXXX XXXX, accrued as a result of my attendance at XXXX. 

XXXX, as you likely know, has been widely discredited as a notorious and predatory for-profit school, and ultimately closed around XXXX, with a reputation for scandal and fraud. It was owned by XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ), a company with an equally atrocious reputation for defrauding students across its national chain of for-profit institutions. On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted a complaint to the CFPB regarding Navients unfair collection of my XXXX XXXX XXXX debt stemming from my time at XXXX. 

The Department of Education has delivered student loan relief to borrowers who attended XXXX , as part of its settlement in the Sweet v. Cardona matter. In that settlement, the Department found that student borrowers who attended XXXX were entitled to presumptive relief because of a strong indicia of substantial misconduct by the school. However, I was denied similar relief because as Ive mentioned I hold no federal student loan debt associated with my enrollment at XXXX, just XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

The Holder Rule preserves my right to challenge the legitimacy of my loans to Navient on account of my XXXX original wrongdoing. On XX/XX/XXXX, I asserted my right to a defense to repayment of these XXXX XXXX XXXX to Navient by submitting a XXXX misconduct application ( see attached ) along with a detailed explanation and several exhibits supporting my well-established position that XXXX XXXX engaged in misconduct that should negate XXXX XXXX XXXX ( also attached ). On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a denial notice ( see attached ) from Navient that provided no reason for my denial, stating only that I do not meet the requirements for discharge based on misconduct by your school. 

This is obviously an unfair and unreasonable result. I should at least be entitled to a reason for my denial. I have contacted Navient requesting an explanation for this decision, but I have not heard back yet. 

I suspect that I am being denied because Navient determined I cant produce a discharge notice from the Department of Education, which I obviously can not do because I never held any federal student loans from XXXX. However, if I did have federal student loans from XXXX, they would indeed have already been canceled through the Sweet settlement. Again, this is an unreasonable result that I hope the CFPB can help address. 

I was wronged by XXXX substantial misconduct. Consequently, I deserve my loans from XXXX to be canceled and I think it is unfair that Navient is denying me a fair process to present my well-founded case for loan cancellation. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX

Navient has failed to provide me with any specific criteria used regarding why my application for private loan discharge was denied. Assistance is needed in obtaining this information as the school attended clearly engaged in fraudulent practices that support discharge of any applicable loans consistent with federal court decisions that have already been rendered.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. As a matter of fact, XXXX  XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX was investigated by the US Congress. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these online for profit schools, such as The XXXX XXXX of XXXX, I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, and my Fed. loans of {$100000.00} were discharged. 

My loan was discharged based on an ED finding that XXXX  XXXX XXXX made pervasive and widespread substantial misrepresentations that borrowers relied on to their detriment. This conduct affected students who enrolled at XXXX  XXXX XXXX from XXXX XXXX, XXXX through XXXX XXXX, XXXX, when the campuses were sold to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX. These misrepresentations related to the salaries and employment rates for its graduates and the benefits and connections XXXX  XXXX XXXX provided to students and graduates. Because of the pervasive and widespread nature of the misconduct by XXXX  XXXX XXXX, ED has determined that it is appropriate to discharge the outstanding loans made to all students who enrolled at XXXX  XXXX XXXX during the time period described above. 

I am aware that Navient was sued by XXXX  state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. Senator XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!
