Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, the now defunct XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

I know your office is being bombarded with claims against my and many other schools who were a part of the landmark XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. Indeed, I'm using a template provided by an organization trying to assist former students of these schools to help them file claims against Navient and others. 

I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX settlement for which I was a full class member and received both loan discharge and a refund of a portion of what I repaid. 

I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX XXXX. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. Unfortunately, I was not in default at the time of that lawsuit. Issue: Communication tactics
Sub-issue: You told them to stop contacting you, but they keep trying
Consumer complaint narrative:
Since XX/XX/year>, I have been experiencing persistent technical errors that prevent Navient from processing my student loan payments via debit card or checking account. Despite multiple attempts to make payments and numerous communications with both Navient and my bank, the issue remains unresolved. 

Details of Issues : 1. Payment Processing Failure : Navient has been unable to process my payments using my debit card or checking account. These are the same payment methods I use daily for other transactions without any issues.

2. Bank Verification : I have confirmed with my bank that there are no blocks or issues on their end that would prevent payments from being processed. The bank has investigated and found no reason why the payments should be returned as " fictitious. '' 3. Navients Lack of Resolution : Despite contacting Navient multiple times, including speaking with a representative via XXXX while I was out of the country, the technical error remains unresolved. Navient 's response has been insufficient, and they have advised me to use alternative payment methods, which are not feasible long-term solutions ( e.g. purchase a XXXX gift card for payments ). 

4. Impact on Credit Profile : This ongoing issue is negatively affecting my credit profile, as it appears that I am not making payments on my student loan, which is far from the truth. This misrepresentation is harming my creditworthiness.

5. Repeated Threats and Intimidation : Navient has repeatedly threatened me with " disassignment '' and default due to the payment issues, which are beyond my control. These threats are causing significant stress and anxiety.

6. Violation of Communication Preferences : I have requested that Navient communicate with me exclusively via email. Despite this, they continue to send letters and use other means of communication, disregarding my specified preferences. This behavior may constitute a violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ).

7. Lack of Documentation and Support : Navient has failed to provide necessary documentation, such as screenshots and error codes, that could help my bank investigate the issue more effectively. Their statement that the transactions are " fictitious '' is not a valid output and can not be properly investigated without further details.

Actions Taken : - I have communicated extensively with both Navient and my bank to resolve the payment processing issue.

- I have requested multiple times for Navient to adhere to my communication preferences and provide detailed documentation via email of the errors which they refuse and keep calling and mailing threatening letters. 
- I have kept detailed records of all communications and attempts to make payments.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX. Many students have already had their loans discharged & paid back. 

A dozen advocacy groups, including the XXXX and the Debt Collective, on Wednesday wrote to U.S. Secretary of Education XXXX XXXX, calling on the Biden Administration to cancel the student loan debt of borrowers who attended the for-profit XXXX XXXX , which from XXXX until just before its XXXX closure was owned by for-profit giant XXXX  XXXX XXXX, now called XXXX. 

XXXX offered programs in photography, filmmaking, and photo-journalism. Like other schools owned by XXXX, XXXX  used deceptive advertising and high-pressure recruiting to enroll students in over-priced programs that left many buried in debt, without the career advancement they sought. 

The letter, also signed by more than 250 former XXXX students, cites the findings of a report released this week that documents abuses at XXXX during the period that XXXX owned the school. The report was skillfully prepared by XXXX XXXX, a Debt Collective organizer and former XXXX student. 

The letter asserts that the Department already knows about a robust record of misconduct by XXXX, and the new report offers details on XXXX violations, based on hundreds of pages of records from congressional testimony, civil lawsuits, law enforcement probes, and media accounts. 

The report documents that XXXX misrepresented the costs of attending, facts about transferability of credits, and graduation and job placement rates, and enrolled students without regard to whether a program would help them succeed. 

According to the report, XXXX, which started as a family-run XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX, enrolled about XXXX students under XXXX ownership. 

In a statement, XXXX said, XXXX XXXX borrowers have suffered long enough under the weight of deceptive practices. Its time for the Department to act decisively and provide the relief these borrowers deserve. 

XXXX XXXX, whose son earned a XXXX XXXX at XXXX from XXXX to XXXX, said the degree turned out to be pretty much worthless. XXXX added, The career counseling and promised leads never happened. The accreditation they claimed would lead to great jobs turned out to be nonexistent. The loans we were told would be easily paid off by our sons guaranteed high income are still lingering and growing like a XXXX due to the predatory and deceiving pressure put on us by XXXX XXXX and XXXX. XXXX said the loan debt had grown from about {$100000.00} to over {$330000.00}. XXXX, who is XXXX, said she and her husband will die with these loans still hanging over our heads. 

The Department under President XXXX  has offered automatic debt cancellation without the need for students to individually show, under the federal Borrower Defense process, that they were harmed to groups of students attending in specified years a number of predatory colleges, including the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

Other students who have individually applied under Borrower Defense have become eligible for debt relief, including under the settlement of the Sweet v. Cardona lawsuit. But many borrowers, including former XXXX students, remain unaware of the magnitude of the XXXX scam or of their eligibility for loan relief. 

XXXX report notes that XXXX borrowers have made various efforts to cancel their debts, including through individual and class-action lawsuits against XXXX, XXXX, and lender XXXX XXXX , through the Borrowers Defense process, and other means, but none has meaningfully addressed the debt. 

Other groups signing the letter to Cardona include the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, and XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. 

As Republic Report has chronicled for over a decade, XXXX has been one of the worst actors in all of for-profit higher education, taking in billions of dollars from taxpayers for student grants and loans while repeatedly engaging in predatory abuses. 

XXXX has faced multiple law enforcement actions for predatory conduct. In XXXX, the company entered into a {$490.00} XXXX settlement with 48 state attorneys general, plus the District of Columbia, over allegations that it engaged in widespread deceptive practices against students. Later that same year, XXXX agreed to pay {$30.00} XXXX to settle charges brought by the Federal Trade Commission that its schools have recruited students through deceptive third-party lead generation operations. In each case, the company did not admit guilt. 

Recent XXXX employees have told media outlets XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX, as well as Republic Report, that company recruiters have continued to feel pressure to make misleading sales pitches and to enroll low-income people into programs that arent strong enough to help them succeed. Some of those former employees also have spoken with federal investigators. 

XXXX XXXX reported in XXXX that the U.S. Department of Education, in XX/XX/XXXX, requested information from XXXX ; the Department also asked XXXX to retain records regarding student recruiting, marketing, financial aid practices, and more. XXXX confirmed the probe, while seeming to minimize its significance, in a XX/XX/XXXX SEC filing. XXXX also acknowledged in XX/XX/XXXX that it received a request for documents and information from the U.S. Justice Department. 

Yet the company, despite its awful record of misconduct, has managed to stay in business. It not only changed its name from XXXX to XXXX, it also jettisoned all its old tarnished brands like XXXX XXXX and started fresh with two schools that have official-sounding names : XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX 

The Department of Education provided XXXX and XXXX with more than {$690.00} XXXX in student grants and loans in the XXXX school year, the most recent year reported. A XXXX XXXX from XXXX is priced at about {$65000.00}. 

But data released last year by the Department show that XXXX two schools, XXXX and XXXX, deliver poor results for students, with low graduation rates and graduate incomes and high levels of student debt. 

Before joining XXXX, company CEO XXXX XXXX ran two of the other biggest for-profit colleges operations : the XXXX  XXXX XXXXXXXX and now-demised XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. Both of those chains, like XXXX, ran into major law enforcement issues because of deceptive recruiting practices and other abuses that occurred on XXXX watch.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I made an agreement to Autopay an overdue loan back in XX/XX/XXXX. I have the agreements and payment dates in text form, " e-signed ''. 
I then continued to pay the agreed amounts each month, some months paying double because of not remembering the autopay would come out. 

Despite the fact that Navient said that these payments would be applied to both loans ( one larger loan and one smaller loan ) these payments were only applied to the smaller loan, and the larger loan went into default, which I did not know, because I knew I was making my payments on time and there was no update to the website to reflect that these autopayments were coming out. I called about this at least once and they said they didn't need to be reflected on the website because I had made the agreement over the phone. 

I continued to make these payments, again sometimes double, and the larger loan said no payment due for months... I still made the autopayments, assuming that, as agreed " to make payments current '' as part of a " forbearance agreement ''. Again, these payments were not applied to both loans ( even though I have the texts claiming that they would be ) from XX/XX/XXXX. 

On Friday, XX/XX/XXXX, at XXXX, I received a very suspicious-looking email claiming that " time was running out '' but that I needed to call by XXXX Eastern time XX/XX/XXXX. This email also ( presumably illegally ) had a list at the bottom of the email of all email addresses receiving this email ( including mine ), a very informal subject line, a number of grammatical errors, and was sent from an informal-looking, personal email address. 

When I called this number that Friday evening, " XXXX XXXX '' whose number I was given to work with directly, claimed that my loan had been in default since XXXX and even if I had called in XXXX it was too late. She claimed I needed to settle the debt for {$7600.00} by the end of the month, saying I could write a check by the XXXX to clear by the XXXX but that if it didn't clear I'd be even more legal trouble. 

When I proposed a realistic number that I could come up with by this date, she said it would " ruin her reputation '' and she would be " laughed out of the office ''. She said she would put this on hold until Monday, but that there was nothing I could do except for settle the debt before the end of the month, and that even though I had been paying more than the agreed upon amount the entire time, it wasn't their fault or problem that they had only applied these payments to one loan. 

I received a follow-up email just now XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX, with similar grammatical and spelling errors, from the same email address. It also claims that " *Business hours may vary at the end of the month. '' The email address is " XXXX XXXX XXXX '' uses the Navient letterhead and logo, and is either a scam that breached some personal data of Navient customers or Navient is scamming me, but either way it is incredibly unprofessional and I have to assume is committing illegal acts. Please advise.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: Qualified for a better loan than the one offered
Consumer complaint narrative:
I experienced high-pressure sales techniques ( calling several times a day ) to enroll in the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and take out student loans, although it was never made clear to me exactly how much i was taking out. In addition, i qualified for more federal student loans, but i was told that i didn't qualify, and would have to take out a private loan with Navient ( Sallie Mae at the time ) to get the money i needed for school. Some of the loans i got with a co-signer and received a lower variable interest rate, but the following year I was instructed try to take out on my own, and i received a 12 % interest rate. 

I was told that i was at my max for federal student loans ( not true ) at a lower interest rate. I also was lead to believe that Navient was my only option. I was the only person in my family to go to college -- i didn't have someone with experience to guide me. 

Moreover, the financial aid advisor at the school took the entrance and exit financial aid counseling exam for me -- he said it was common sense stuff and he quickly clicked through the information while i sat at another table. 

After struggling for years to pay the money back, accruing thousands of dollars in interest, I was finally able to refinance the funds under another lender for a lower interest rate. 
I was truly naive. I thought schools always had the best interest for their students in mind so i didn't think twice about it. I was wrong.

XXXX explained that this application would determine school misconduct and if I were eligible. While I didn't agree with the fact that I had to fill out an application to determine eligibility because based on the findings I am eligible, I agreed to receiving the application. XXXX confirmed my mailing address, then I had asked about the refund process and she said there may be information about a refund in the packet but she wasn't sure. 

On XXXX I called Navient to check the ETA of the application since I had not received anything in my mail yet. I was told by the representative, XXXX, that the code wasn't placed on my account and that the XXXX department would determine if I was eligible or not and if I were, then Navient would send the application out, which seems like another eligibility process. So essentially Navient is telling me that I need to be approved twice to get my loans discharged and refunded? I told XXXX that the woman I spoke with on XXXX, XXXX, told me she put the code on my account, so for the last week I was under the impression that it was already being sent out. I told him that I was eligible based on the findings and that these loans are predatory loans and said that Navient just needs to discharge my loans and give me a full refund. He then said that he would place the code on my account today and I said I'd check back in a few days on the XXXX. I don't trust that XXXX put the code on my account based on all my other experiences with Navient. 

These Navient private loans are predatory. The company ( back then known as Sallie Mae ) clearly had a relationship with the XXXX XXXX and contributed to/conducted unethical tactics, preying on vulnerable low income individuals such as myself.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to bring to your attention a matter of grave concern regarding fraudulent practices at the XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, particularly concerning student loans. As an agency dedicated to protecting consumers from financial exploitation and ensuring fair treatment in the financial marketplace, I trust that you will investigate this issue with the utmost urgency and diligence. 

The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX has been engaging in deceptive practices that have directly impacted numerous students and their financial well-being. Specifically, the institute has been implicated in fraudulent activities related to student loans, including but not limited to : 1. Misrepresentation of Loan Terms : Many students have reported that the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX misled them about the terms and conditions of their student loans. This includes false promises regarding interest rates, repayment options, and eligibility for loan forgiveness programs. 
2. Falsification of XXXX and XXXX Records : There is evidence to suggest that the institute has falsified enrollment and attendance records to fraudulently obtain federal student aid on behalf of students who may not have been actively attending classes or who were enrolled in programs that did not meet federal eligibility criteria. 
XXXX. Failure to Provide Adequate Educational Services : Despite charging exorbitant tuition fees, the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX has failed to deliver quality educational services to its students, leaving many graduates with substantial debt and inadequate skills to secure gainful employment in their chosen fields.

4. Predatory Lending Practices : The institute has been accused of engaging in predatory lending practices, targeting vulnerable students with high-pressure sales tactics to encourage them to take out loans without fully understanding the financial implications. 

These fraudulent practices have had devastating consequences for students who trusted the XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX to provide them with a quality education and support their career aspirations. Many graduates are now burdened with crippling debt and struggling to repay loans for degrees that have not yielded the promised benefits. 

I urge the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to launch a thorough investigation into the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 's student loan practices and take decisive action to hold the institution accountable for its misconduct. Additionally, I request that measures be taken to provide relief and assistance to affected students, including loan forgiveness and restitution for damages incurred. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I remain hopeful that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will take swift and decisive action to protect the rights and interests of students who have been victimized by fraudulent practices in the higher education sector.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX of XXXX XXXX XXXX and the US Department of Education determined that my federal loans will be discharged do to the misconduct of XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX and their parent company. 

I submitted a complaint previously because I also have private loans held by Navient that were used to attend the same school. Those loans should also be discharged, just like the federal loans. 

As a result of that prior complaint Navient sent me a School Misconduct Discharge application. Over XXXX weeks I spent countless hours and considerable effort gathering evidence and completing the application. 

Now, a month after submitting my application, I have received notice from Navient that they are denying my application. That denial was accompanied by an extremely unclear explanation. 

I have XXXX loans held by Navient and I am attaching all three denial letters. They are identical except for the loan number.

Consumer complaint narrative: I would like to file a school misconduct charge related to the XXXX XXXX  for Navient private student loans. The private loan I have with Navient is for an in-semester tuition hike that was charged by XXXX when I was attending school there in XXXX. XXXX has a long history of terrible business practices and they misled me on how much my XXXX XXXX XXXX would be worth, how they would help me find a job, their job placement rates, etc. I have filed a Borrower Defense case against this school and been approved, which included discharge of my federal student loans. My private loans should be discharged as well, especially because it is particularly predatory to raise tuition mid-semester, knowing that the only funding option is a private loan at a higher interest rate. The original amount of the loan was {$5500.00}. I have been paying it for almost 20 years and the current balance is still {$1200.00}. In that time I have filed for bankruptcy, been forced many times to go into default, at which time Navient aggressively sought payment using harassing phone calls, even when I explained my dire financial situation. I have made a total of {$16000.00} in payments for that original {$5500.00} loan. Both XXXX and Navient are incredibly predatory.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX of students were scammed by Sallie Mae - Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX between XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
As a matter of fact, XXXX  XXXX XXXX and their Parent company, XXXX were investigated by the attorneys general of several states and have been found to have acted in a fraudulent manner. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, the Biden administration has just announced a blanket discharge for anyone enrolled at XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. 
My Federal loans in the amount of ( Your amount here ) were discharged and my credit repaired. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX XXXX 
These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools '', but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. 
I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. 
After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? 
Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? 
Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. 
This application is a sham. 
Why do we need to prove anything? 
Navient knows who we are. 
Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. 
Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. 
Senator XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!

Much of this progress was made under the Education Departments Borrower Defense Loan Discharge ( borrower defense ), which provides debt relief to borrowers who were misled or defrauded by their school through misrepresentations about key aspects of their program, such as admissions selectivity or career prospects.16 This is a powerful tool : the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX calculates that, since XX/XX/XXXX, the Department of Education ( ED ) has announced loan cancellation for more than 1.1 million borrowers, promising to wipe out more than {$18.00} XXXX of fraudulent and predatory debt from for-profit schools.17 But many students with outstanding private loans from some of these very same colleges including those held by Navient have still not received relief.18 Navient Should Cancel Fraudulent Loans Eligible for Relief Under the FTCs Holder Rule and Due to Navients Misconduct Like millions of federal student loans eligible for cancellation under borrower defense, decadesold predatory private student loans may be eligible for cancellation due to Navients misconduct and under the Federal Trade Commissions ( FTC ) Holder-In-Due-Course Rule ( Holder Rule ), a broad rule dating to XXXX, and subsequently reaffirmed and updated numerous times by the Commission, allowing borrowers, in some cases, to raise the same claims and defenses against a loan provider that they could raise against the original seller of the good or service.19 The Holder Rule is a powerful consumer protection tool, providing relief for customers when a defective or fraudulent product or service is purchased with credit arranged by the seller, including situations where the seller referred the customer to the creditor, or is affiliated with the original creditor.20 With regard to student loans, the borrower may be able to cancel existing debt if a school fraudulently induced the student to enroll and had some relationship XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. Navient, as Sallie Mae, regularly listed the FTC Holder Rule as an operational risk for its private student loans made to students at for-profit schools. In its XXXX annual report, the company stated : If a school with which we have a business arrangement with respect to student loans closes or otherwise does not provide the borrower the promised education, the borrower could raise the same claims and defenses against us as the lender as it could against the school. As a result, our ability to collect loan amounts could be materially impaired.22 In a XX/XX/XXXX earnings call, XXXX XXXX XXXX Navients Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, announced that Navient has reserved {$35.00} XXXX in anticipation of a liability to discharge certain legacy private XXXX As an independent basis, borrowers may also assert the predatory practices of Sallie Mae against Navient as a reason to cancel their loans. Sallie Mae intentionally created subprime lending programs with for-profit colleges for the purpose of facilitating ongoing access of both companies to the federal student lending program.24 Sallie Mae knew that students were not credit worthy, were unlikely to finish the programs at these for-profit schools, and were highly unlikely to repay their student loans.25 In fact, Sallie Mae insured itself against this certainty by requiring the for-profit schools to essentially guarantee the subprime private loans.26 Incredibly, even though Sallie Mae was made whole, and reaped enormous profits from its business relationships, it continues to hold borrowers and their cosigners hostage.27 This course of conduct could bar Navient from suing on these loans, and their continued collection is unfair. Navient has already cancelled the debt for some of these loans. XXXX XXXX  of Borrowers Although there are XXXX XXXX XXXX of loans clearly eligible for cancellation under the FTC Holder Rule and because of the misconduct of Navients predecessor, Navient makes it intimidating and difficult for borrowers to solicit relief.31 While ED established a process for group discharge for borrowers to automatically get relief on predatory federal loans without having to individually apply, Navient opened a school misconduct discharge application that is inordinately lengthy and complex for borrowers.32 The 12-page application, asks questions seemingly designed to knock out applications, such as when the wrongdoing was discovered, and requires borrowers to include individualized documentation such as correspondence from the school, marketing materials, advertisements, course catalogs, manuals, school web messaging, and other products all from loans that may be more than two decades old.33 The application threatens borrowers with perjury for providing incomplete information.34 It asks borrowers if the court has awarded a favorable judgment against their school, and if so, to attach the court order and other relevant documents to the application.35 It requires a narrative explanation of how [ the borrowers ] life has been impacted by the fraudulent loans and an explanation of why the misleading information that the school concealed or omitted from the borrower was important to them at the time of their application.36 These conditions are unnecessary and impractical and will prevent XXXX  of borrowers from obtaining the relief they deserve. Navient should stop making borrowers apply for relief and instead automatically cancel student debt using information the company already has about whether borrowers attended schools that would entitle them to relief. Navient should start by cancelling debt for students making payments on predatory loans that were not provided relief by the XXXX settlement. After the return to repayment started in XXXX, at least XXXX XXXX borrowers were affected by servicing failures, such as a backlog of unprocessed Public Service Loan Forgiveness forms, payment miscalculations, and late bills.38 And after XXXX XXXX XXXX of federal loan borrowers were granted borrower defense relief in XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX representatives continued to insist that they would have to return to repayment.39 Given XXXX failure to follow guidance on canceling predatory federal loans, it is hard to believe that it will behave any better in canceling similar private loans Navient will transfer to them. Navient must discharge subprime legacy private loans now before they are transferred to XXXX. I attended The XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX from XXXX. Myself and Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit schools such as the one I attended. As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX was investigated by the federal government. They have been sued by the government a number of times. Recently the over {$6.00} XXXX in federal student loans were cancelled for people who attended the XXXX XXXX schools. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these for profit schools, such as The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, and my Fed. loans of {$81000.00} were discharged and my credit repaired. 
My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the Sweet Vs. Cardona settlement for which I was a full class member. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX XXXX. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit online schools. Its very obvious that your agency doesnt know what the FCRA is because, from the looks of my credit report and all the errors I see, you are disregarding it. So heres my breakdown.

1. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is the primary federal law governing the collection and reporting of credit information about consumers. Its rules cover how a consumer 's credit information is obtained, how long it is kept, and how it is shared with others, including consumers themselves.

2. What is an FCRA violation?

Creditors give reporting agencies inaccurate financial information about you. Reporting agencies mix up one person 's information with another 's because of a similar ( or the same ) last name or social security number. Agencies fail to follow guidelines for handling disputes.

3. My rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act Verify the accuracy of my report when it is required for employment purposes.

Receive notification if information in my file has been used against me in applying for credit or other transactions.

Disputeand have the bureaus correct and deleteinformation in my report that is incomplete, inaccurate, and unverifiable.

Remove outdated, negative information ( after seven years in most cases, 10 in the case of bankruptcy ).

I recently applied for extended credit and was denied. I am in distress because of your mistakes.

The law is very clear regarding the Civil liability and the remedy available to me ( Section 616 & 617 ) if you fail to comply with Federal Law. I am a litigious consumer and fully intend to pursue litigation in this matter to enforce my rights under the FCRA.

VIOLATION OF 15 U.S. Code 1681n - Civil liability for willful noncompliance ( a ) In general, Any person who willfully fails to comply with any requirement imposed under this subchapter with respect to any consumer is liable to that consumer in an amount equal to the sum of ( 1 ) ( A ) any actual damages sustained by the consumer as a result of the failure or damages of not less than {$100.00} and not more than {$1000.00} ; or ( B ) in the case of liability of a natural person for obtaining a consumer report under false pretenses or knowingly without a permissible purpose, actual damages sustained by the consumer as a result of the failure or {$1000.00}, whichever is greater ; ( 2 ) such amount of punitive damages as the court may allow ; and ( 3 ) in the case of any successful action to enforce any liability under this section, the costs of the action together with reasonable attorneys fees as determined by the court. ( b ) Civil liability for knowing noncompliance Any person who obtains a consumer report from a consumer reporting agency under false pretenses or knowingly without a permissible purpose shall be liable to the agency for actual damages sustained by the consumer reporting agency or {$1000.00}, whichever is greater.

Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Accuracy of Information ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) : This section requires that consumer reporting agencies follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual to whom the report relates.

Dispute Resolution ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) : This section outlines the procedures that must be followed when a consumer disputes the accuracy of information in their credit report. It mandates that consumer reporting agencies must investigate disputes, usually within 30 days, and either verify, correct or delete the disputed information.

Furnisher Responsibilities ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ) : This section details the responsibilities of entities that furnish information to consumer reporting agencies. It requires furnishers to provide accurate information, investigate disputes received from consumer reporting agencies, and correct or delete inaccurate or unverified information. You list aliases ; who provided this information to you? You listed previous addresses. Who provided this information to you?

Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) Acquisition of Location Information ( 15 U.S.C. 1692b ) : While not directly about information accuracy, this section requires any debt collector communicating with any person other than the consumer to acquire location information about the consumer without stating that the consumer owes any debt.

SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION : Various laws have been enacted to protect the privacy of individuals ' SSNs, restricting their use and disclosure. Here are five relevant laws and five case citations that reflect the legal landscape around the protection of Social Security numbers.

Laws Protecting Social Security Numbers The Privacy Act of 1974 ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ) restricts how the federal government can disclose personal information, such as Social Security numbers. It mandates that government agencies must have a relevant and necessary reason to collect an individuals SSN and must also inform individuals how their SSN will be used.

Social Security Number Protection Act of 2010 : This Act prohibits explicitly printing an individuals Social Security number on checks issued for payment by the federal government, as well as on any card required for accessing government services, to reduce the risk of SSN theft.

Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ) : FERPA protects the privacy of student education records. It applies to all schools that receive funds under an applicable program of the U.S. Department of Education. Schools must have written permission from the parent or eligible student to release any information from a student 's education record, which includes the Social Security number, except under certain legally specified circumstances.

Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act ( FACTA ) of 2003 : This act amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to enhance the accuracy of reports and includes provisions to help reduce identity theft, such as the truncation of credit cards and Social Security numbers on printed receipts.

Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 ( 18 U.S.C. 1028 ) : While not solely focused on SSNs, this Act makes it a federal crime to knowingly use another person 's identification with fraudulent intent, which includes the unauthorized use of someones Social Security number. 

Case Citations Regarding Social Security Number Privacy In re XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) : Although not exclusively about SSNs, this case dealt with the broader issue of personal information security, including SSNs, in the context of a data breach. 

XXXX XXXX  XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) : This case addressed damages related to the unauthorized disclosure of an individual 's Social Security number by the government, underscoring the privacy interests associated with SSNs. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX Cir. XXXX ) : This case involved the issue of an employer 's responsibility to protect employees ' Social Security numbers and the legal ramifications of failing to do so. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX Cir. XXXX ) : The court discussed the privacy implications of collecting and potentially disclosing students Social Security numbers without proper safeguards. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) : This New Hampshire Supreme Court case emphasized the duty of information brokers to exercise care in disclosing personal information such as Social Security numbers to third parties, highlighting the potential for harm from such disclosures. 
These laws and cases highlight the legal protections afforded to Social Security numbers and the serious considerations given to their privacy and security in various contexts, including federal records, educational settings, and identity theft prevention. 

Communication in Connection with Debt Collection ( 15 U.S.C. 1692c ) : This section prohibits deceptive collection practices, indirectly requiring that any information communicated not be misleading or inaccurate.

Validation of Debts ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) : This pivotal section requires debt collectors to provide consumers with a written notice containing the amount of the debt, the name of the creditor, and a statement that unless the consumer disputes the validity of the debt within 30 days, the debt will be assumed to be valid by the debt collector.

Consumer Credit Protection Act ( CCPA ) The CCPA is a broader act that encompasses several statutes, including the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), the FCRA, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act ( ECOA ), and the FDCPA. The acts mentioned above directly address specific requirements for verified, validated, and accurate information reporting. However, the CCPA 's establishment of these acts under its umbrella signifies the legislative framework for consumer credit protection, including accurate and fair credit reporting and debt collection practices.

Consequences for Non-Compliance Failure to comply with these requirements can result in several consequences for creditors, debt collectors, and consumer reporting agencies, including : Civil Liability ( e.g., 15 U.S.C. 1681n, 1681o for FCRA ) : As a consumer, I can bring a civil action against violators for actual damages, statutory damages, and punitive damages in cases of willful non-compliance. I prefer to bring the claim against their insurance bonds.

Enforcement Actions : Agencies such as the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), along with the Small Claims Court having jurisdiction, can enforce these laws, potentially resulting in fines, penalties, and injunction/directives to correct practices.

Reputational Damage : Non-compliance can also lead to reputational damage, i.e., libel and slander elements of defamation of character and civil action affecting the violating entity 's business relationships and consumer trust.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX of this year, I requested a review of my account as well as a school misconduct form based on the findings from the department of Education : " Based on an ED finding that XXXX XXXX XXXX  made pervasive and widespread substantial misrepresentations that borrowers relied on to their detriment. This conduct affected students who enrolled at XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX XXXX, XXXX through XXXX XXXX, XXXX, when the campuses were sold to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX. These misrepresentations related to the salaries and employment rates for its graduates and the benefits and connections The XXXX XXXX provided to students and graduates. Because of the pervasive and widespread nature of the misconduct by XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, ED has determined that it is appropriate to discharge the outstanding loans made to all students who enrolled at XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX during the time period described above. '' As well as the findings about the lender : " Beginning in XXXX, Navientknown then as Sallie Maeengaged in predatory loan practices with fraudulent, for-profit colleges in exchange for a steady supply of borrowers. Many of these loans still remain in Navients portfolio and are eligible for cancellation due to Navients misconduct and under the FTCs Holder-In-Due-Course Rule ( Holder Rule ), which allows borrowers to raise the same claims and defenses against a loan provider that they could raise against the original seller of the good or service. '' Also, I am aware that they have a pilot program for students ( such as myself ) who attended a " for profit '' school who defrauded them, to discharge the loans taken out with the lies/fraud the school fed them. 

I understand that the Holder Rule would apply here, as the product or service purchased, was done so with me receiving false or fraudulent information from the school, and wish to receive a school misconduct form from the loan servicer, and complete review of my account. 

I have yet to receive a school misconduct form from the servicer, even though I requested one.

These private loans should have been included in my XXXX Department of Education Borrowers Discharge. I have a full discharge for all loans with XXXX University and these loans are from there. The discharge should include all loans, including the private loans that were taken out with XXXX University. 

XXXX NaviRefi has {$73000.00} in loans that are being repaid by me and should be included in this discharge. There was over $ XXXX that should be included in my Borrower Discharge.

I requested XXXX  discharge my loans and refund me all payments that have been made. 

XX/XX/XXXX Borrower Defense Application # : XXXX Borrower Defense Application School : XXXX XXXX Approval of Your Borrower Defense Case Under Exhibit C of the Sweet v. Cardona Settlement Dear XXXX : You are receiving this letter because you are a member of the class of federal student loan borrowers covered by the recent settlement of the Sweet v. Cardona ( " Sweet '' ) lawsuit. You submitted a Borrower Defense to Repayment discharge application relating to your federal student loan ( XXXX ) on or before XX/XX/XXXX, and you attended a school listed on Exhibit C ( " School '' ) of the settlement agreement. 

Pursuant to the Sweet settlement, the Department of Education will do the following : discharge your federal student loan ( XXXX ) taken out for your enrollment in the XXXX XXXX  ( " Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ) '' ) ; provide a refund for any payments made to the Department of Education on your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ), including Relevant Federal Student Loan debt that you previously paid off ; and delete the credit report tradeline associated with the discharged loan ( s ).

The benefits described in this message apply to your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ). The benefits do not apply to private loans. The discharge of your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ) means that you will no longer owe the debt. You also may receive a refund for prior payments made to the Department on your discharged loan ( s ) related to XXXX XXXX. Your loan servicer will let you know if you are eligible for a payment refund, which would be mailed to you. Please check your online account with your loan servicer to ensure your address is correct so you can receive any refund. 

Other than confirming your address, you do not have to take any further action to receive your discharge. Your servicer will send you more details about the discharge, including which loans will be forgiven. Your Relevant Federal Student Loan debt will remain in forbearance and collections will be stopped until you receive relief. Your credit report will also be updated to reflect this discharge when it is complete. 

If you have questions about this notice, please call our borrower defense hotline at XXXX from XXXX XXXX on XXXX or from XXXX XXXX on XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Operating XXXX Federal Student Aid XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, Washington, XXXX XXXX StudentAid.gov/borrower-defense

Navient made these risky subprime loans as " an inducement to get schools to use Navient as a preferred lender '' for highly profitable federal and private loans without regard for borrowers and their families, many of whom were young, like myself, and ensnared in debts they could never repay. 

Navient had a multi-state settlement a few years back where they gave private loan debt relief to borrowers who had XXXX consecutive months of delinquent payments prior to XX/XX/2021. What a SLAP in the face for the people who literally struggle month to month to pay these XXXX loans!!! I can't get approved for a home. I can't get a car loan unless I pay outrageously high interest rates. If I'm even a couple days late, Navient is already calling and emailing every chance they get. I'm afraid of Navient calling my job or garnishing my wages which is why I try to be on time with payment but as a single mother of XXXX who's on public aid, it gets very difficult. 

After this settlement, Navient got out of the federal loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates and Navient had to pay restitution to the federal student loan borrowers for not informing students if XXXX XXXX XXXX student could have enrolled in but instead steered towards forbearance.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Keep getting calls about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Navient, in my opinion, has engaged in predatory collection practices that have constituted harassment. According to the Fair Debt Credit Collections Act, companies are not allowed to : " ... place repetitious phone calls or use electronic communications such as text, email, and social media messages intended to harass, oppress, or abuse you or any person ... '' Navient called me repeatedly and incessantly, between XXXX, sometimes XXXX times DAILY, while I was at work ( see attachments - I have only included a few because the amount that I would have had to include was excessive and would have belabored the point ). This was a concern in a previous complaint I lodged against Navient. Additionally, due to the fact that I was at work, the repeated calls were in danger of jeopardizing my employment. I was also attempting to deal with the impending death of a parent who was on life support and silencing my phone to prevent interruptions from Navient and to prevent possible disciplinary action at work was not an option -- I needed to be able to be reached by the hospital. During a short break XXXX day, I did answer the phone abruptly and inquire as to the reason for their repeated calls. The gentleman that responded informed me that I had a past due amount and I responded that I was aware and that I would pay them when I was able, when I obtained the funds to pay them. He stated that that was all he needed to know and I asked him/the company to stop calling me. I have been enrolled in XXXX and thought there was a discrepancy in the XXXX XXXX amount ( {$160.00} ) and the regular payment ( {$190.00} ), a difference of {$28.00}. My XXXX was active when the last XXXX payment was deducted on XX/XX/year>. My understanding is that XXXX is active unless it is stopped by the consumer. But, whatever my payment arrangements are with a company, I am responsible, aware, and do not need to be 'pushed ' to uphold my responsibilities : when I state that I am aware of my debt and that I will address it when I am able, that is what I will do. If late penalties are assessed, that is for me to address ; the harassment is unwarranted. 

Anyway, the incessant calls continued : as soon as I arrived at work, during the work day, at the hospital during visits and discussions with specialists, surgeons, out-of-town family members, even during the family hour ( my father eventually did pass away ), the funeral, the repast, during the grieving period that followed, I had to deal with XXXX calls a day from Navient, XXXX of the calls coming in the late evening both after XXXX XXXX  ( I am aware that they can call up until XXXX XXXX but the point I make is that they called me all day and I had no respite from them : the calls began shortly after XXXX XXXX and continued into the evening ). Initially, when they called, they were hanging up without leaving a message, which also is not supposed to happen : " ... debt collectors are to provide certain information when they first communicate with you, or shortly after, which is often in a letter called a validation notice ... '' They at no time left a voicemail about their reason for calling and would terminate the call and then, call right back. I began to block their calls since I had already spoken with someone about awareness of my debt and had asked them to discontinue calling. I sincerely felt harassed, felt an incredible amount of stress and anxiety, began to be afflicted with XXXX XXXX XXXX and wanted to just be left alone to deal with the death of my parent. 

Last weekend, I sat down to review my account with Navient and saw that they had not been withdrawing the basic autopay amount nor the new payment amount -- they had sent emails alerting me that the payment was going to change and because I enrolled in XXXX, I assumed the payments would continue but the new amount would be deducted. Out of stress and wanting the XXXX to end, I scheduled a payment but backed out of it when I realized I would be overextending myself. The calls stopped for XXXX day and then began again in earnest, XXXX times a day, as usual. Absolutely appalling. Now that my life has quieted, I was able to address my finances and paid the past due amount of {$390.00}. I'm assuming that I will need to re-enroll in XXXX once this payment has cleared BUT I am asking that Navient 's methods of addressing delinquencies/contacting customers be addressed. Their methods are unnecessary, harassing, and predatory and I do not care what a customer owes, that treatment should not be imposed upon anyone. Private citizens are cited by law enforcement for less in terms of making unwanted/excessive phone calls even when asked to stop.

These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools '', but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded.

Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. 

Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. 

Senator XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient does the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I took out private loans through Sallie Mae for my XXXX XXXX at XXXX XXXX ( years attended XXXX ), owned by XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX in XXXX XXXX XXXX California. I have been making monthly payments on these loans for well over a decade, have never defaulted, and have already paid beyond my original principal amount. I consolidated my loans through Navient in XXXX. Ive included my most recent XXXX ( formerly Navient XXXX ) statement. As you can see, these predatory loans have been hanging over my head for 20 years and will without relief despite recent court rulings continue for 20 more. 

As demonstrated in the recent XXXX XXXX XXXX ruling, the school I attended during the years I attended has been found guilty of misconduct ( listed on the For-Profit School List on the XXXX website ). My story is similar to many students in the same boat : we were given false promises by recruiters and suckered into high-interest private loans through Sallie Mae . At one point in XXXX or XXXX, Sallie Mae raised my interest rate to 14 % for the next trimester, telling me over the phone, Well, you can drop out, but you still owe us what youve taken out so far. I did not drop out. I graduated in XXXX of XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Of course the promised job placement never occurred. I received no help from the school, and in fact also discovered that theyd lied about regional accreditation. In short, like so many victims of XXXX XXXX and XXXX, I was scammed. 

Of course, because I did not default, I have not qualified for any of the settlements or lawsuits that have come up over the years directly pertaining to my alma mater, my years of attendance, and my exact XXXXllie Mae loans. Recently, I was told I did not qualify for the Navient XXXX Multi-State Settlement precisely because I had not defaulted. Ive been lucky in that many student debt groups have popped up in the wake of the Sweet decision ( XXXX XXXX, by the way, graduated from XXXX XXXX XXXX years after I did, so our stories could not be more similar ), including the Project on Predatory Student Lending, with whom I have also shared my story. 

It was on the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( there are so many victims that we have multiple social media groups to keep each other abreast of the happenings ) run by XXXX XXXX that I first heard whispers of a pilot program to aid in discharging these predatory private loans, whispers that offered me the first faint glimmer of hope in 20 years. There is now established legal precedent that my school acting in conjunction with Sallie Mae ( Navient/Navient XXXX ) lied to XXXX deceived, and defrauded students. In my case, this debt has defined the last XXXX years of my life, and at XXXX XXXX XXXX and a college professor myself, I am still living in a small one-bedroom apartment, trying to survive month to month, while my top financial priority each month is my loan payment.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Improper use of your report
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you as according to 15 U.S. Code 6805 Enforcement, ( a ) In general, Subject to subtitle B of the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 [ 12 U.S.C. 5511 et seq. ], this subchapter and the regulations prescribed thereunder shall be enforced by the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, the Federal functional regulators, the State insurance authorities, and the Federal Trade Commission with respect to financial institutions and other persons subject to their jurisdiction under applicable law.

As per the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681 section 602a ), it is emphasized that consumer reporting agencies must conduct their duties with fairness, impartiality, and a regard for the privacy rights of consumers. XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX operate as consumer reporting agencies, while I, as the consumer, retain the right to safeguard my private information, as stipulated by 15 USC 6801. This regulation underscores the Congressional policy, mandating that each financial institution bears a continuous responsibility to honor the privacy of its customers and uphold the security and confidentiality of their nonpublic personal information. 
XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, and NAVIENT, as defined under that title, qualify as a financial institutions. According to 15 USC 1681 section 604a, subsection 2, it is stipulated that " In general, Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' Neither the banks, XXXX XXXX, Sallie Mae, and NAVIENT, nor the consumer reporting agencies, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX, have obtained my consent to furnish this information, particularly lacking my written consent. Any form of consent, be it verbal, non-verbal, written, implied, or otherwise, given to XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX XXXX, Sallie Mae, and NAVIENT is hereby revoked. 
Moreover, 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) specifies that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unlessthe consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' XXXX XXXX, Sallie Mae, and NAVIENT failed to inform me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Additionally, as per 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ), it is stated that " Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information : Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account constitutes an adverse item being reported again without my permission, which is a violation of the law.

Moreover, according to 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A, it is prohibited for a person to furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, 15 U.S. Code 1681e mandates that every consumer reporting agency must maintain reasonable procedures to avoid violations of section 1681c and limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b. XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX are evidently not upholding reasonable procedures in this regard. 
As the CFPB has the responsibility to protect consumer rights, additional grievances are as follows : 1. The Privacy Act of 1974 ( 5 U.S. Code 552a ) defines record as any item, collection, or grouping of information about an individual that is maintained by an agency, including, but not limited to, his education, financial transactions, medical history, and criminal or employment history and that contains his name, or the identifying number, symbol, or other identifying particular assigned to the individual, such as a finger or voice print or a photograph. It defines Conditions of Disclosure as no agency shall disclose any record which is contained in a system of records by any means of communication to any person, or to another agency, except pursuant to a written request by, or with the prior written consent of, the individual to whom the record pertains, unless disclosure of the record would be to a consumer reporting agency in accordance with section 3711 ( e ) of title 31. Additionally, Part 1016- Privacy of Consumer Financial Information ( Regulation P ), 12 CFR 1016.7 Form of opt out notice to consumers ; opt out methods, section ( a ) states, under ( 1 ) form of opt out notice, that if company is required to provide an opt out notice under 1016.10 ( a ), they must provide a clear and conspicuous notice to each of their consumers that accurately explains the right to opt out under that section. The notice must state : ( i ) That company discloses or reserve the right to disclose nonpublic personal information about consumer to a nonaffiliated third party ; ( ii ) That the consumer has the right to opt out of that disclosure; and ( iii ) A reasonable means by which the consumer may exercise the opt out right. My federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality, in addition to the right of OPTING OUT, have been violated by XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. Specifically for the following accounts : I have OPTED OUT of, including the following from the attached Credit Report : XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX : Account XXXX, page XXXX : XXXX. My rights are protected under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ), a federal law enacted in 1974. FERPA safeguards the privacy of student education records and applies to both public and private elementary, secondary, and post-secondary schools. This ensures that my educational information remains confidential and can only be disclosed with my consent. ( 20 USC 1232g ( b ) ) My federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality have been violated by XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX as information pertaining to my student loans is included in the attached credit report, including SALLIE MAE : Account 2, page 34 :, NAVIENT : Account 3, page 35 :.

3. According to 15 U.S. Code 1681e - Compliance procedures, under ( b ) Accuracy of report, Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. My federally protected right to receive accurate information has been violated by XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX as there is inaccurate information on my credit report, attached : XXXX XXXX : Account 1, page 33 :, the amount indicated in the High Amounts row do not match. The dates also do not match on the row labeled Last Reported. NAVIENT : Account 3, page 35 :, the Last Reported dates do not match, nor do the High Balance amounts.

Consumer complaint narrative: My loans were transferred to Navient around XXXX and I was on the plan that increased payment every XXXX years which I was ok with. In XXXX, during the time XXXX XXXX paused student loan payments, my loans were also paused with no further correspondence or so I thought. Around this same time, my student loans disappeared from my credit. During the federal payment pause, there was no correspondence from Navient until XXXX of XXXX that was put in my twin brothers name along with all of his personal information including his social security number. Navient stated to my brother that the payment was past due. My brother told Navient that these were not his loans and gave them my social security numbee, my name, phone number and they started calling me. I wasnt sure if it was a scam because no student loans were reporting on my credit.I called Navient and was told my account was at least 45 days past due and I was hit with over {$400.00} in late fees.This was my first time hearing that my student loans were in repayment after Navient put my student loans in the wrong person name with their correlating contact information. I asked to have the student loans brought up to current and to have the late fees removed because that was not my fault all of the loans was placed in the wrong name and social security number. They brought the account to current but refused to remove the late fees. I also noticed that my balance went from approximately {$26000.00} to over {$34000.00}. I asked them what happened because I thought my student loan payments along with the interest were paused during the federal payment pause. Navient informed me that they paused payments too but interest was still incurring ( which I found out was a lie and XXXX explain further down. ) and thats when I found out that my loans were actually federally backed XXXX loans and not federal student loans. I heard that the Department of Education had a program in place that if I consolidate our XXXX loans into federal student loans, I could possibly get my student loans XXXX under the XXXX or the borrowers defense discharge due to me attending a predatory school, XXXX XXXX XXXX which XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I called the Department of Education for assistance with the federal student loan consolidation application. The representative was willing to do it over the phone but when she went into the national student loan database, my Navient loans were not showing up. She made the suggestion to manually add the loans to the consolidation application. I called Navient again to ask why wasnt my loans showing in the national student loan database and I was never given a real answer. I also inquired on why they were not showing on my credit report and was told, they wont show up on my credit until I am at least 90 days late past due. I continued on with the federal consolidation application, manually entering my Navient loans and submitted it. I received notice in XXXX of XXXX, that my loans with Navient could not be federally consolidated because they came back as private student loans. Feeling defeated and stuck with a possible predatory company, I placed this on the back burner. However, in XXXX of XXXX, my wife noticed that Navient rolled out a private loan discharge application for predatory schools which I felt I met the qualifications ( attended High tech-Anthem college and according to Navient, my type of student loans were private. ) On XXXX XXXX, I called Navient to have the loan discharge application sent to me and was told that the application didnt exist. I said yes it does and I would like to request application for it. Representative XXXX told me that my loans are federal backed loans and he couldnt see the side of the private loans. According to the federal consolidation application that I completed in XXXX of XXXX, my loans were considered private so I couldnt consolidate, but now XXXX being told by Navient that my loans are actually federally backed public student loans. I had the Navient representative to dig deeper into what has been going on with my account over the last XXXX years. According to Navient representative, in XXXX, in the middle of the federal student loan payment and interest pause, all of my loans were transferred to XXXX and stayed with aidadvantage interest free until around XXXX XXXX. Navient contacted aidadvantage and requested most of my student loans back from them, realizing they made a mistake transferring all of my loans over to them. When Navient received my loans, they placed my loans in my twin brothers social security number along with all of my brothers contact information, then added on approximately {$8000.00} of unpaid interest to the loans. They did conclude that all of this was their fault and pretty much we just got the short end of the stick. Navient representative also could not give me a reason why my student loans didnt show up in the national student loan database, nor could he give me a reason why they werent showing up on my credit. He had no clue why my student loans came back as private student loans when I tried to federally consolidate them and he had no clue how Navient could make such a big mistake and not even attempt to take any accountability for it. He did say that he would email the national student loan database to have my loans added that day so that I could reapply for Department of Education XXXX XXXX to get my loans away from them. I asked if they could remove the interest that was applied from XXXX to XXXX because if they had not made such a huge mistake, I would have continued paying on my loans and they wouldve been paid off by the end of XXXX. They said they could not do it with no explanation why. The only thing I received out of this ordeal is an apology but I feel that I deserve much more.

Many students, including myself, were misled by Navient, formerly Sallie Mae, into securing predatory private loans to fund education at for-profit online institutions, such as XXXX XXXX XXXX I attended from XXXX to XXXX with an original principal loan amount of {$25000.00}. Despite having paid {$84000.00} towards this loans, my current balance stands at {$13000.00} due to an exorbitant interest rate, which currently is 16 %. 

Notably, XXXX XXXX XXXX  was subject to investigations by various state attorneys general and found to have engaged in deceptive practices. In response to widespread allegations of fraud and misconduct by XXXX XXXXXXXX and their predatory lending practices with Sallie Mae. The AG lawsuit led to one of my loans, from XXXX XXXXXXXX and for the same Associates degree as the remains loan left, with over {$80000.00} discharged.

Navient, which was sued by the attorneys general of 39 states for its role in facilitating these predatory loans, had a specific arrangement with for-profit schools during the XXXX XXXX, making it a " preferred '' lender. Despite this, the settlement terms provided by Navient were considerably inadequate, excluding many borrowers who took loans for attendance at approximately 150 for-profit online schools, unless they resided in certain states or had not defaulted for at least seven months during a specified period. This loan was in forbearance for many months following the years of graduating. 

The only period during which I managed to reduce the principal amount was during the pandemic, when interest rates were temporarily lowered to between 0.5 % and 1 %. However, once the regular interest rates resumed, my balance skyrocketed again. This financial strain, coupled with the emotional stress and damage to personal relationships, has been overwhelming. 

Moreover, Navient exited the federal student loan servicing business amidst legislative and advocacy scrutiny, following allegations of steering borrowers away from income-driven repayment plans towards forbearance, an action for which they had to provide restitution. 

Navient has also faced multiple lawsuits for other predatory lending and illegal collection practices. Currently, Navient is distributing " applications '' to select students who may qualify for Borrower Defense claims against their schools. However, this process feels unnecessary and opaque, as Navient is already aware of the affected students. 

Under the FTC 's " Holder Rule, '' Navient is accountable for these predatory loans issued in association with for-profit online schools. As time is critical, XXXX XXXX XXXX has urged Navients CEO to immediately discharge these loans. It is crucial for Navient to take responsible action now by discharging all s

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have had MANY problems with Navient since XXXX, when I first started making payments. I have 8 Private Loans with them all with co-signers. I am also part of the XXXX settlement, post-class. Below are my on-going and continuous problems with Navient : Problem 1 : I am paid every other week, so Navient splits my monthly payment in 2 and withdraws from my checking account half the full amount each time I get paid. For months I get paid three times that month, I always tell them not to withdraw my checking account for the 3rd pay period. Sometimes they withdraw from my checking account that 3rd pay period and sometimes they do not. Either way they do it, I get bumped out of my payment programs and have to spend an additional 1+ hour to get this resolved. The last time this happened was XX/XX/XXXX and it took me 2 months to get this resolved. They did reimburse me the extra payment I made only to set up additional monthly withdrawals of {$1700.00} every month on top of the {$1600.00} I already pay them monthly. I had to call a 3rd time to get the {$1700.00} reimbursed and that additional monthly withdrawal removed from my Navient account. Every year I deal with this multiple times and am told completely different reasons as to why this happens with no accountability on their part and them telling me I did something wrong. 
Problem 2 : Misinformation amongst Navient employees is rampant! I ask them to record EVERY time I call so there is a trail of what was said. I know they do not listen to the recordings, but theres nothing I can do about that. I have been told many times two different things by two different people and both were wrong which usually only hurts me. I am also told that I misunderstood what was told even though I write everything down. I ask them to review the recording of the conversation and they tell me they do not need to and all they need to do is read the notes from the previous CSR which are also usually wrong or only have half the information. Every time I point that out, Im told there is nothing they can do. 
Problem XXXX : Ridiculous interest rates! I have paid over {$230000.00} since XXXX on loans that originally totaled {$220000.00}. I currently still owe {$240000.00}. I will never get these loans paid off and that is ridiculous. 
Problem XXXX : I have requested MANY times to have my cosigners released as I have met the criteria and they deny it every time with no explanation and when I call, no one seems to know why even managers. 
Problem XXXX : Their late fees are out of control. I have my payments automatically withdrawn from my checking account where I have NO control over the amount taken out and yet, I am constantly being charged late fees. Most of the time that happens after Problem 1 occurs and when I bring it to their attention that it was not my fault, they still charge me noting, there is nothing I can do about that. If youre late, we have to charge you, totally disregarding the error was not on me. Again, XXXX accountability on their part with all the blame on me for something I have no control over. 
Navient is a horrible lender with unscrupulous business practices. They prey on students, especially those from scam schools which mine was XXXX, XXXX, and it is next to impossible to repay them back in full. They have called friends and family of mine that I never gave them their information nor permission to call. They are never at fault, always assume I am an XXXX, and never provide me the same information twice even when I call with the same problem. I just can not tell you enough how much they have made my life and my cosigners lives difficult. My credit score has greatly suffered as has my cosigners for problems I did not create. They have yet to repair our credit scores as they promised they would and I just want them out of our lives!

And now with the evidence that XXXX XXXX press release made this doesn't make sense why I can't be absolved of these loans if the federal government is pointing that these were completely misrepresented schools. 

I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit online schools. 

After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 

I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. Why is this not offered to everyone right now? Even finding out about it was difficult and only because of the XXXX v XXXX this came to light as well for consumers. 

Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. 

Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW! Because the Dept of Education has done the right thing for federal loans due to the overwhelming evidence, us consumers deserve the right to submit and get these removed as well especially those have tried to do the right thing and continue to pay but suffer greatly to our quality of life and " education '' received.
