Consumer complaint narrative:
Since I have contacted Navient XXXX more times than mentioned in this complaint, it is clear that it has become a waste of time to try to reason with them directly. 

Things had been plodding along with my Navient IDRs until the latter part of XXXX of XXXX, when my job ended. I called their representative on XX/XX/XXXX and asked how I should proceed with recertification. The XXXX told me that I didnt need to send XXXX XXXX  XXXX, that the XXXX would be based on my income at that time ; and that I only needed to send my application with a letter of explanation. I faxed the requested documents on XX/XX/XXXX. ( See attachment ) They also told me at that time that I would not owe anything, and they would place me in forbearance or deferment. I told them that instead, I would pay them XXXX a month until I knew an exact amount. I have done so and am still doing so XXXX. 

I checked in with Navient on XX/XX/XXXX to make sure that they had processed my application from XX/XX/XXXX. They claimed that they never received it. I faxed another application on XX/XX/XXXX. It included a letter of explanation and, at the XXXX ; XXXX request, my XXXX XXXX, since I receive XXXX distributions XXXX about $ XXXX a year. ( See attachment ) Still hearing nothing, I called and was told that I should have sent XXXX XXXX! Not thinking that was possible, I asked my XXXX  holders for their input. Their rep explained that it wasnt possible before XXXX  end, that the loan company was most likely stringing me along. 

By now I was into XXXX of XXXX, with no movement and confusing and conflicting directives from Navient. When I went back to them, I was told that I should send XXXX XXXX, but to include letterhead correspondence from each XXXX  holder XXXX dated XXXX. The XXXX confirmed that they had everything needed to process my application except the above documents. I complied on XX/XX/XXXX by faxing XXXX correspondence and XXXX XXXX from the XXXX  holders XXXX Navient. ( See attachment ) I called in XXXX of XXXX to see where things stood, and was told that they had everything needed to process my app and that I would receive correspondence from Navient confirming my XXXX recertification in a XXXX  of weeks. However, as of XXXX, XXXX, I have received no such correspondence from Navient and they have not processed my XXXX IDR application. 

Though I have paid Navient XXXX every month since XXXX, XXXX, and am still doing so, they have been calling daily since XXXX, XXXX. They say that I am behind on my payments and owe them money. When I tried to explain what was going on to the rep calling me the XXXX  time in this series of harassing calls, she would not let me talk and spoke over me. 

I sent my new XXXX XXXX application by certified mail on XX/XX/XXXX. Tracking ( See attachment ) shows that my application was picked up on XX/XX/XXXX. As of XXXX  date, they have not processed my XXXX application. 

I also did not receive correspondence or a check from Navient for their class action lawsuit settled in XXXX for their past unscrupulous behavior. They need to make this right, also.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative: XXXX XXXX XXXX NAVIENT/XXXX  is in violation of multiple laws set forth by Congress in regards to the following account # XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 15 U.S. Code 1681a ( 2 ) ( a ) ( i ) states that the consumer report does not include information solely as to transactions or experiences ( payment history, charge off status ), between the consumer ( myself ) and the person ( XXXX XXXX XXXX NAVIENTXXXX ) making the report. Additionally, 15 U.S. Code 1681 s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) states that A person ( XXXX XXXX  XXXX NAVIENT/XXXX ) shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer ( ME ) to any consumer reporting agency ( XXXX, XXXX, or XXXX ) if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX NAVIENTXXXX can not collect on a discharged debt. This is now considered a certificate of indebtedness per the IRS and income can not be reported. The IRS Clearly defines a charge off as Gross or Ordinary income, INCOME DOES NOT GET REPORTED ON THE CONSUMER REPORT which in fact makes reporting of this account inaccurate! I provided a screenshot from the IRS website. By Definition, the IRS Clearly says a Cancelled debt or Charge off is Income. I have also included the 1099-C that was received from the IRS showing the discharged amount of {$290000.00} which validates that they owe {$11000.00} for overage paid on the accounts. The reporting of this account as a debt is inaccurate. I never received a XXXX from XXXX XXXX XXXX NAVIENTXXXX  for the cancelled debt of {$270000.00} in order to file as ordinary income. Where is my XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX NAVIENT/XXXX is clearly writing off debt with the IRS without sending out XXXX as required by the IRS for debts greater than {$600.00} XXXX This is unsatisfactory! XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX NAVIENT/XXXX has been HEREBY PUT ON NOTICE that they are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. In XXXX XXXX  XXXX NAVIENT/XXXX terms and conditions they agreed not to share my information with non affiliates. XXXX, XXXX, or XXXX is not an affiliate of XXXX XXXX XXXX NAVIENT/XXXX nor are they " bureaus ''. The only true credit bureau is the CFPB and they DO NOT furnish consumer reports as stated in federal law. I have a right to privacy and Per the Privacy Act of 1974 as a federally protected consumer I am now revoking any and all authorization I the consumer may have given you written, non written, verbal, and nonverbal per 5 U.S. Code 552a. Per the FCRA as a federally protected consumer I am now opting out of any and all authorization I the consumer may have given you written, non written, verbal, and non verbal per 15 USC 6802. I shall also point out their responsibility pursuant 15 U.S. Code section 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) ( ii ) : ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX NAVIENT/XXXX must also refund the remaining balance of the consumer account upon its termination. This is your 7 day notice to return ALL money due from this consumer account. XXXX Treatment of credit balances ; account termination. ( a ) Credit balances. When a credit balance in excess of { { {$1.00} } } is created on a credit account ( through transmittal of funds to a creditor in excess of the total balance due on an account, through rebates of unearned finance charges or insurance premiums, or through amounts otherwise owed to or held for the benefit of the consumer ), the creditor shall : ( 1 ) Credit the amount of the credit balance to the consumer 's account ; ( 2 ) Refund any part of the remaining credit balance within seven business days from receipt of a written request from the consumer ; ( 3 ) Make a good faith effort to refund to the consumer by cash, check, or money order, or credit to a deposit account of the consumer, any part of the credit balance remaining in the account for more than six months. No further action is required if the consumer 's current location is not known to the creditor and can not be traced through the consumer 's last known address or telephone number. ( b ) Account termination. ( 1 ) A creditor shall not terminate an account prior to its expiration date solely because the consumer does not incur a finance charge. ( 2 ) Nothing in paragraph ( b ) ( 1 ) of this section prohibits a creditor from terminating an account that is inactive for three or more consecutive months. An account is inactive for purposes of this paragraph if no credit has been extended ( such as by purchase, cash advance or balance transfer ) and if the account has no outstanding balance. ( c ) Timely settlement of estate debts ( 1 ) General rule. ( i ) Reasonable policies and procedures required. For credit card accounts under an open-end ( not home-secured ) consumer credit plan, card issuers must adopt reasonable written policies and procedures designed to ensure that an administrator of an estate of a deceased account holder can determine the amount of and pay any balance on the account in a timely manner. ( ii ) Application to joint accounts. Paragraph ( c ) of this section does not apply to the account of a deceased consumer if a joint account holder remains on the account. ( 2 ) Timely statement of balance ( i ) Requirement. Upon request by the administrator of an estate, a card issuer must provide the administrator with the amount of the balance on a deceased consumer 's account in a timely manner. ( ii ) Safe harbor. For purposes of paragraph ( c ) ( 2 ) ( i ) of this section, providing the amount of the balance on the account within 30 days of receiving the request is deemed to be timely. ( 3 ) Limitations after receipt of request from administrator ( i ) Limitation on fees and increases in annual percentage rates. After receiving a request from the administrator of an estate for the amount of the balance on a deceased consumer 's account, a card issuer must not impose any fees on the account ( such as a late fee, annual fee, or over-the-limit fee ) or increase any annual percentage rate, except as provided by 1026.55 ( b ) ( 2 ). ( ii ) Limitation on trailing or residual interest. A card issuer must waive or rebate any additional finance charge due to a periodic interest rate if payment in full of the balance disclosed pursuant to paragraph ( c ) ( 2 ) of this section is received within 30 days after disclosure.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

I had to fight a " deceased '' status on my credit report XXXX, due to Sallie Mae, which caused me so much money, time stress, heartache & XXXX. I received approximately XXXX XXXX  of forgiveness in XXXX, which I had to fight in order not to have to pay XXXX XXXX in taxes on, since it seemed no one was aware of indecency laws. I complted my XXXX application in XXXX, studentaid.gov still shows pending. I am a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX refund deadline was XX/XX/XXXX. I received a letter last summer showing approximately XXXX XXXX in discharge, which was updated on studentaid.gov. However, I am still left with over XXXX XXXX in student loans from a school found to have committed fraud, and I have yet to receive any refund of payments I made. I have struggled ever since attending XXXX, which was supposed to IMPROVE my life, rather than what I experienced. 

As a matter of fact, XXXX XXXX XXXX and their Parent company, XXXX were investigated by the attorneys general of several states and have been found to have acted in a fraudulent manner. 

Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by XXXX XXXX XXXX, the Biden administration has just announced a blanket discharge for anyone enrolled at XXXX XXXX XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. Again, I attended XXXX. 

I am aware that Navient was sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. 

These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools '', but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for XXXX  months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. 

I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. 

After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates?

Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? 

Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a XXXX XXXX times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 

I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved.

This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are.

Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools.

Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll.

Senator XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Problem lowering your monthly payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/2024 I was notified that my federal student loans used to attend XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX were being discharged due to the misconduct of the school. I also have private student loans used to attend the same school during the same time period. Those were not being automatically discharged like the federal loans. Instead I found I needed to fill out a complicated application to ATTEMPT to get the private loans discharged. This was already ridiculous as there is no reason for the private loans to remain while the federal loans are discharged. They were used for the same fraudulent school so they should both be discharged.

Specifically, the " Holder Rule '' applies and means that my private loans should be discharged due to the misconduct of the XXXX XXXX. 

But because Navient wants to make things difficult I still had to apply for and fill out an application. 

In a previous complaint I requested that Navient provide me with an application for Student Loan Discharge due to School Misconduct. Their response to that first complaint contained this excerpt : " Thank you for reaching out to the CFPB with your concerns regarding your student loan account. Navient currently services your XXXX XXXX XXXX Student Loans that were disbursed for your attendance at the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Thank you for inquiring about a school misconduct discharge for your private loans. We are in the early stages of this new process and have determined that your loans meet the criteria for you to receive an application. '' So at this point they admit that my loans are eligible to receive the application. This suggests they believe that my loans are also potentially eligible to be discharged due to school misconduct. Otherwise I don't see why they would even send me the application. 

I spent XXXX weeks gathering evidence and completing the application. I submitted it to Navient and after a month they replied that my application was denied. There was no actual explanation as to why I was denied. 

I submitted another complaint, asking for a clear explanation of why I was denied when the act of denial makes no logical sense in my situation. And I have seen others who attended an XXXX XXXX submit an application and have it approved. There seems to be no rhyme or reason to who Navient chooses to approve or deny. And without clarity from them I can only assume it's essentially random. 

Navient responded to this latest complaint with essentially the same circular logic " explanation '' for my denial. Again, there is XXXX clarity and Navient isn't doing what they are obligated to do. 

This was their latest response : " Thank you for inquiring about a school misconduct discharge for your XXXX XXXX XXXX Student Loans. Please be advised, our records confirm that weve previously addressed your concerns regarding your loans ineligibility for school misconduct discharge. While we understand why this matter is important to you, please note that our position on this matter has not changed. To explain further, each application is subject to our review and discretion. A variety of criteria are used to determine eligibility, including, but not limited to, proof of resulting harm, sufficient documentation supporting your claim, date when events occurred or when you experienced harm, etc. Because we review each application holistically, it is not possible to identify specific criteria that caused your application to be denied. Navient considers a variety of factors in determining whether a private loan should be discharged based on school misconduct. That analysis is confidential and proprietary to Navient. '' This is not a satisfactory explanation or resolution to my problem. They consider a variety of factors? Like what? How about the factor that my school committed misconduct and didn't fulfill their promises when they persuaded me to enroll and then with Navient 's help buried me under a mountain of debt?

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative: I attended XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX from XXXX of XXXX XXXX of XXXX. The lies that I was told to secure these loans were unconscionable. I was told the school would assist with job placement. I was told that these loans would be easy to pay back. I was told that it was easy to secure a job with this degree. I was told that my credits were from an accredited school and would transfer to another school without issue. This was all false information. In XXXX, the remainder of my loans were paid in full. Over {$80000.00} worth of loans were paid back only because the home I lived in, that my in-laws owned, was sold. Some of the money from that sale was used to pay off my loans. I was being crushed under the weight of my loans. So many financial things in my life were denied because of my insurmountable student loan debt. I was told that school was about {$40000.00} and I took out around another {$12000.00} to help my family while I was in school. How does it balloon out of control like that? I paid almost double, if I did the math correctly, from what I took out. Fluctuating interest rates caused principal payments to be worthless. How do these companies, Navient and XXXX XXXX specifically, get away with such things? Hardly any of my payments went towards the principal. It wasn't until a home got sold did this get fixed. Many people are getting their loans cancelled and refunded. Obviously, I no longer have this debt but I do deserve to have it refunded to me just the same as the unfortunate people who are still paying or are in default are having theirs refunded. When I have tried to reach out to Navient, they are no help because I no longer have loans with them.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Many students, including myself, were misled by Navient into securing predatory private loans to fund education at for-profit online institutions, such as university of XXXX XXXX I attended from XXXX to XXXX with an original principal loan amount of {$6500.00}. Despite having paid hundreds of dollars towards these loans, my current balance stands at {$7400.00} due to an exorbitant interest rate, which currently is 12.5 %. 

Notably, XXXX  XXXX XXXX and their parent company, XXXX, were subject to investigations by various state attorneys general and found to have engaged in deceptive practices. In response to widespread allegations of fraud and misconduct by XXXX  XXXX XXXX, the XXXX administration recently announced a comprehensive loan discharge for students enrolled at these institutions from XX/XX/XXXX, to XX/XX/XXXX. This led to the discharge of my federal loans totaling XXXX  XXXX and the restoration of my credit. 

Navient, which was sued by the attorneys general of XXXX states for its role in facilitating these predatory loans, had a specific arrangement with for-profit schools during the early XXXX, making it a " preferred '' lender. Despite this, the settlement terms provided by Navient were considerably inadequate, excluding many borrowers who took loans for attendance at approximately XXXX for-profit online schools, unless they resided in certain states or had not defaulted for at least seven months during a specified period. 

The only period during which I managed to reduce the principal amount was during the pandemic, when interest rates were temporarily lowered to between 0.5 % and 1 %. However, once the regular interest rates resumed, my balance skyrocketed again. This financial strain, coupled with the emotional stress and damage to personal relationships, has been overwhelming. 

Moreover, Navient exited the federal student loan servicing business amidst legislative and advocacy scrutiny, following allegations of steering borrowers away from income-driven repayment plans towards forbearance, an action for which they had to provide restitution. 

Navient has also faced multiple lawsuits for other predatory lending and illegal collection practices. Currently, Navient is distributing " applications '' to select students who may qualify for Borrower Defense claims against their schools. However, this process feels unnecessary and opaque, as Navient is already aware of the affected students.

Under the FTC 's " Holder Rule, '' Navient is accountable for these predatory loans issued in association with for-profit online schools. As time is critical, XXXX XXXX XXXX has urged Navients XXXX to immediately discharge these loans. It is crucial for Navient to take responsible action now by discharging all such predatory private loans associated with for-profit online education.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have had Loans with Navient since graduating from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  in 2007. Because of the nature of my industry at the start of my career I had alot of difficulty finding work and managing my payments to Navient. 

Every single time I had difficulty paying off my loans Navient either gave me absolutely incorrect information suggesting forbearance vs income based repayment or other cheaper options, often costing me money to enter forbearance and also costing me money in the form of interest accrued during those times. 

Navient also originated a predatory subprime private loans to me and my father, even though it knew that there was very high percentage chance I wouldn't be able to pay it back, due to low graduation and placement rates at the school I attended. 

Navient also continuously failed to apply correct payments to my accounts during the course of my loans often misallocating or arranging the payments in ways that would cost me more than if things had been allocated properly. 

Navient also is in direct violation of the settlement terms of the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX case and has not only ignored my requests but flat out denied responsibility to do anything. They most recently denied my attempt to enforce the complete removal of the originating loans from my credit report. In contempt of the court rulling. 

Navient also violated the Telephone Consumer Protection Act by utilizing an automatic telephone dialing system to try to collect on missed payments. Calling sometimes outside of normal business hours. I know this was an automated system from the multiple different numbers that navient used to call from making them difficult to track and from the lengthy pause and click when I would answer and it would connect and transfer me to a representative. I tried several times to revoke consent and ask them to not call me or to not call my father but this was ignored.

Consumer complaint narrative: I have been in school and am still in school. I am completing my PhD program ( am in my dissertation process ). Because I am not considered part/full time, my financial assistance has stopped, which means I am paying {$150.00} per month to remain in school and my student loan payments have picked back up. I have applied for the SAVE program with my Federal Loans and it seems as if my payments are {$0.00} because I don't make enough money to make my payments. I was not working prior to XXXX and had told Navient that I could not make my payment. Their suggestion was that I borrow {$50.00} from someone to defer my payments. I told them I had nobody to borrow from and I needed them to put that in their notes so that the phone calls could stop. I was receiving upwards of XXXX phone calls per day for the past year and a half ( after my bankruptcy was cleared ). I would block one phone call and another would come through from a different phone number. I would answer and have the same conversation. Back in XXXX I talked with a customer service rep and the conversation began as it always had. It took a turn when she would not stop speaking over me and my temper got the best of me. She told me deferment would only get me current through the end of XXXX, that I had until the end of the month to make that payment. The calls were not going to stop because I was 6 months behind on my payments. She also said that because I was yelling at her she was going to hang up on me, despite her rudeness with me and her yelling and speaking over me, not allowing me to talk. She made me feel like a delinquent who never paid her bills on time. I asked to speak with her boss, but conveniently her boss had left for the day and she refused to find anyone else for me to speak with. We hung up the conversation and I called back in tears asking to speak with a manager, anyone but her. I was informed that the lowest payment they would accept on my {$5000.00} personal loan, no matter my financial situation, is {$76.00} because it is a private loan. Once current I must always be on time. I mentioned that I had read many articles about how " Navient screws their customers, but how I had hoped it wasn't true, '' but she didn't even respond to the comment. If I am even a day late on my payment, the 10+ calls per day from all over the US start back up relentlessly 7 days per week!!

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX admissions representatives that I spoke to prior to enrolling flat out said that the majority of my loans would be federal student loans, never explained or pointed out that the loan documents I was signing were actually private student loans through Sallie Mae ( later transferred to Navient ). This stood out so much that when I attempted to take out a car loan from my bank, I double-checked the paperwork and found that the car dealership switched to a car loan from another bank. Luckily ( or not ) the previous experience taught me to pay closer attention to what I'm signing and ask questions if I'm uncertain about something.

There were so many times throughout my XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX where I was required to go out of my way to sign 'updated loan documents ' or I wouldn't be able to attend classes. It happened so much it felt like a prank. It wasn't. It kept happening all the way up to graduation. I received phone calls after finishing my last semester that again asked me to come in and sign 'updated loan documents ' or there was a possibility of my diploma being withheld.

On top of all this, when I started asking questions I was given the runaround. Scheduled meetings with admissions and loan advisors kept being changed, those same advisors were conveniently 'away from their desk ' or 'in a meeting that we don't know how long will go ' and reminded 'the time has been scheduled and there's nothing to worry about '.

I was treated as a statistic throughout my entire enrollment, then ignored completely after graduating. I asked for, but never received, copies of all the loan paperwork I signed. Same goes for my entire file. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  was essentially a front for money laundering. The victims? Every single student that trusted an institution of higher learning. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX  were sued by, and lost to, the Department of Justice. XXXX XXXX XXXX are also part of an ongoing lawsuit that includes over XXXX other fraudulent schools. Each and every XXXX of those school 's students deserves a second chance to get a worthwhile education.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a notice from the US Department of Education noting that my : " Pursuant to the Sweet settlement, the Department of Education will do the following : discharge your federal student loan ( s ) taken out for your enrollment in the Florida XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( " Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ) '' ) ; provide a refund for any payments made to the Department of Education on your Relevant Federal Student Loan ( s ), including Relevant Federal Student Loan debt that you previously paid off ; and delete the credit report tradeline associated with the discharged loan ( s ).

Subsequently, Navient sent me a letter noting that they had received my letter -- despite the fact Navient continues to report inaccurate information on my credit file, and most recently, has resumed its attempt to collect this cancelled debt. 

These repeated attempts and negative reporting, continues to cause me severe distress. Any communication with them is met with resistance and an unwillingness to adhere to the laws. 

This conduct is predatory and deceptive. Please help. Even with clear proof that the debt is forgiven/cancelled- they are reporting and inaccurate balance and now claiming I am in arrears on cancelled account.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
Navient does not offer realistic repayment plans and puts consumers in a bad position. They fail to tell customers that interest continues to accrue in Forbearance unless you ask. They ONLY look at your yearly income and do not take into account any expenses at all that affect ability to pay, in my case, medical bills and being out of work for months at the end of last year, which put us behind on everything. Also, the fact that I'm self employed is impossible to convey to them. There are no options for a person working less than XXXX a week on three unemployment option because they require you to be registered with an unemployment agency and continuously applying for jobs. That is unrealistic for the self employed or for low wage workers, like XXXX 's, gas station, etc. where hours fluctuate or are often not full time, but are close. They do not take anything into account that makes sense, and sets borrowers up for failure. They should have options that take expenses into account in the real world. 
They need realistic options for borrowers. Just because I am not on government assistance like food stamps, doesn't mean I'm fine. Just because my husband and I have a combined income of XXXX  amount, does not mean I can pay {$250.00} a month IF they took into account actual expenses and bills, which they did not and which they absolutely refused to do. They should be required to.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative: Since 2009 I have made on time automatic payments to Navient on a {$7400.00} XXXX XXXX. Since then I have seen over 13 payments apply solely to interest and when asked why years ago they said I was late with payments then that they just apply some payments on the back end. This week I was told its because I signed up for a 24month interest only payment plan. I didnt and the issue with that is the payments werent always consistent and there werent a full 24. When I asked to go over this the supervisor gave push back and treated me as if I were trash not trying to pay loan. Speaking with a rep they said Navient will sometimes do a settlement with certain amounts. I was told 60 % is the lowest if I can provide expenses. When I provided a monthly breaking showing we come out negative they said they would try for {$1800.00}. Management came back with {$2200.00}. I felt defeated. When I spoke to a supervisor she called me entitled and said I was just trying to not pay what I owed. She said they dont have to settle. When I told her that I have paid over {$15000.00} on this loan she said thats how loans work and clearly you dont know that. I asked to speak to her supervisor to which responded no, they do not speak to customers. I pushed and told me she would have her supervisor call me in a few days. I am sick of them taking my money and not applying it to the balance. I paid {$120.00} every month. I have explained that we have come into some hardships and she then took the offer off the table of {$2200.00} and said you will go into litigation. They sent me a litigation letter. They have been rude, condescending and extremely unhelpful. Constantly backtracking and providing incorrect information.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX for college, which had since changed its name to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX In the years, the school and it's parent company has been the subject of many lawsuits over fraud. Some of my loans were taken out with XXXX XXXX and later moved to Navient. Both companies were also under scrutiny for fraudulent practices over the years in relation to this and many other schools. These lawsuits led to the XXXX v. XXXX settlement, where my federal loans were forgiven. However, there appeared to be no hope for my private loans with Navient over the fraudulent practices of the school I attended or Navient 's behavior over student loans. 

In XXXX, I refinanced my Navient loans with another loan company. I tried to avoid doing this to hold hope for relief elsewhere, but my interest rate was variable and had reached 10 % interest. I could no longer afford these payments and having paid my loans since XXXX, I was getting increasingly frustrated. After doing the math, I had already paid more than twice what I had borrowed by that time. Speaking with Navient support over the years to find relief, none was offered. I had exhausted my deferments and I didn't want to defer payments anymore anyway. Reducing payments or interest were not offered. I felt that I had no choice to move somewhere else. 

However, I am not seeing Navient offering some borrowers an application to forgive their loan balances in the form of a school misconduct discharge. I am increasingly more frustrated with this situation since I had paid so much to Navient, felt hopeless in my situation, and believed my only option for relief was with another servicer to pay a reduced rate. 

Considering the school I attended engaged in fraudulent activity against thousands of students, including myself, and Navient was also scrutinized in relation to this behavior, I would like to see Navient offer me the opportunity to apply for discharge, then buy my loans back to forgive them as the same opportunity as those that still have their loans with Navient. 

I struggled to find work after graduating from XXXX in XXXX and had re-earn my XXXX XXXX XXXX from an XXXX XXXX  many years later. The fact I moved my loans somewhere else doesn't change the fact I was still victimized and taken advantage of. It should not be held against me to make an attempt to improve my financial situation without knowing relief would be coming. Navient was just at fault of my financial hardship over the years as XXXX was. It's only fair I have the ability to receive the same options for relief.

Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I've been paying on my private student loans since XXXX, my Navient ( Then Sallie Mae ) XXXX Education loans currently stand at {$160000.00}. 


I went to the school " XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  '', a branch of the " XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX '', in XXXX and Graduated with a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. This school has since closed down. 
When I took these loans out, I did so under the impression that it would be possible to pay them back, or at least pay them down. This was an impression that was instilled in me by the school 's financial department when I first visited the campus in XXXX VA. In addition to this, I was repeatedly told that I did not qualify for any other financial assistance, and that these loans were the last and only way. 


When I first began paying back the loans, I was given a monthly payment of $ XXXX to begin with, and was given six months as an initial grace period. The XXXX XXXX itself did next to nothing to assist me in finding work, instead just pointing me to a freelancing site. I struggled to find any employment in that six months, and soon needed more time. When I went to Navient ( Then Sallie Mae ), the forbearance they offered at the time costed {$150.00} each time and only lasted for ~three months each to the best of my knowledge. Due to the level of difficulty I had finding work, my forbearance was used up very early on, and I can no longer rely on them as an option. 


When I eventually was making income, I struggled immensely to make payments each month, as the Navient payments were not the only loans that had been taken out when I was going to XXXX. For many months most of my income was dedicated to student loans and little else. There were times when I was able to get on to an Interest Rate Reduction program with the Navient loans, but those were temporary and my loan amount would quickly balloon again since the interest rates were 13-16 %. As of this day, my normal payment is set to {$2000.00}, and even going on a payment plan will only decrease it to $ XXXX. Despite the difficulty, I managed to keep paying my loans without defaulting, which unfortunately made me intelligible for the Attorney General settlement debt cancellation in XXXX. As time continues, the loans will only increase in price and the monthly payments will become so high that even a payment plan won't make them manageable. 


All this for a school that was closed down due to foul play and has not given me the employment opportunity it claimed it would.

Consumer complaint narrative:
This loan originated from a predatory school. A portion The federal portion of the loans has been deleted, and the remaining is in the process of deletion following the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX lawsuit. 

Since the exhaustion of my forbearance period and back-to-school pauses ( around XXXX  with some other periods in between ), I have been making payments I can't afford. I have probably paid close to the original borrowed amount and now owe {$53.00} thousandover XXXX XXXXXXXX more than the original amount. Since the pandemic, I have been paying ever-increasing interest-only installments and seeing my principal still rising. 

Currently, I have been paying non-stop for at least XXXX. With the interest increases, I am paying close to one-third of my current income. I keep requesting an adjusted lower interest or another program that would allow me to breathe, and because I have never been in arrears or default, I always get denied. 

California sued NAVIENT regarding predatory loans, and people in default had their loans deleted. I am trapped in this situation because I can't get into a default to protect my credit and cosigner 's. I can't progress in my life because I have this anchor whose weight is suffocating me. 

I just finished a six-month interest-only program and am completely broke. NAVIENT won't do anything to help. 

NAVIENT knows that this loan originated from a predatory school ( the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and yet they are doing nothing to ease the struggle I am experiencing to get this debt cleared. It just seems to make sure it is ever-increasing and keeps me down.

'' Furthermore, Senator XXXX XXXX and 8 other Senators urged Navient to discharge predatory loans from schools like the one I attended because of " well-established school misconduct and predatory lending '' in a letter ( attached ) sent to Navient last month : We write to urge the Navient Corporation to cancel the decades-old, predatory student loans in its portfolio that are governed by the FTCs Holder Rule and subject to claims and defenses based on well-established school misconduct and predatory lending, said the senators. Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Attended the XXXX XXXX in XXXX. During this time the XXXX XXXX was owned by XXXX. 

Navient sent an application to me on XX/XX/XXXX for forgiveness of my loans for school misconduct. On XX/XX/XXXX Navient denied my application. 

Navient continues to disfranchise borrowers who were taken advantage of by for-profit schools, that even our government has admitted, defrauded borrowers. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, The U.S. Department of Education, which reviewed evidence provided by the attorneys general of Iowa, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, concluded that the XXXX  and its parent company, the XXXX XXXX XXXX, or XXXX, made pervasive and substantial misrepresentations to prospective students about post-graduation employment rates, salaries and career services. 

For more than a decade, hundreds of thousands of hopeful XXXX  borrowed billions to attend XXXX XXXX XXXX and got little but lies in return, U.S. Secretary of Education XXXX XXXX said in a statement. 

Beginning in XXXX, XXXX then as XXXX XXXX in predatory loan practices with fraudulent, for-profit colleges in exchange for a steady supply of borrowers. Many of these loans still remain in Navients XXXX  and are eligible for cancellation due to Navients misconduct and under the FTCs Holder-In-Due-Course Rule ( Holder Rule ), which allows borrowers to raise the same claims and defenses against a loan provider that they could raise against the original seller of the good or service. 

Navient is aware of its potential liability to discharge these loans, and has been forced to cancel some of these loans through legal settlements. This year, the servicer set aside {$35.00} XXXX in anticipation of a liability to cancel predatory legacy loans. While the Department of Education has promised to wipe out over {$18.00} XXXX of predatory federal debt from for-profit schools, Navient hides and establishes convoluted pathways to relief for its similar private predatory loans. 


Navient is violating the Federal Debt Collection Practices Act ( 15 U.S.C.1692 ) and the Texas Debt Collection Act ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) by continuing to collect on these loans. 

Navient knows of the fraud that was committed, they themselves are actively participating in the fraud committed, and continue to hold consumers back from financial success and obtating their goals.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Hello- XXXX of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) were investigated by the Federal Department of Education. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these online for profit schools, such as The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was able to file a XXXX XXXX claim with the Dept. of Education against The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, and my Federal loans of {$34000.00} were discharged and my credit repaired. 
My XXXX XXXX XXXX was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX settlement for which I was a full class member. 

I am aware that Navient was sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. After the XXXX settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 

I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to " select '' students who may have filed XXXX XXXX claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to " prove '' anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online " for profit '' colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online " for profit '' schools NOW! 

Thank you! 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : Loan Number : XXXX Loan Type : PRIVATE Current Owner : NAVIENT PRIVATE LOAN TRUST Current Payoff : {$34000.00} REFERNCES : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

When I refinanced it was converted to a personal loan. I believe Navient in an effort to collect used predatory practices so student loan would not be forgiven. After contacting Navi- Refi they offered a settlement attached.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
My name is XXXX XXXX. Sadly, I have learned that I am a victim of an elaborate and systematic NAVIENT scam to direct unsuspecting NAVIENT student loan borrowers to third party brokers to steer said student loan borrows into student loan forgiveness for a substantial upfront fee unbeknown to the student loan borrower. In this nefarious scheme, in my case, when a student loan borrower contacts NAVIENT 's customer service, the student loan borrower without their knowledge is automatically redirected to a third party broker under the guise that this third party broker is a representative of NAVIENT. 

Once connected to this third party broker, this individual does not identify himself/herself as a third party broker nor their intentions, but misrepresents themselves as NAVIENT representatives as they execute their scheme to convince student loan borrowers to allow the third party broker to file for student loan forgiveness as this is the only repayment option available to the student loan borrower. As part of this fraudulent process, the student loan borrower is misled to believe that s/he must pay a substantial amount towards their loan in order for the forgiveness process to move forward. However, this is a blatant lie. These funds are actually the third party broker 's fee which this individual has deliberately concealed from the student loan borrower. In short, the student loan borrower is misled to believe that ( 1 ) pursuing student loan forgiveness is their only option to repay their student loan ( 2 ) a payment is required in advance to apply for student loan forgiveness and ( 3 ) that this payment is put towards their student loan when in fact it is a fee to enrich the pocket of the third party broker. 

That said, on XX/XX/year>, I contacted NAVIENT customer service to adjust my long-standing IDR repayment plan as, unfortunately, I was made redundant by my employer on XX/XX/year> and would not be able to make the current payments as I did not have any income. Before contacting NAVIENT, I resubmitted my IDR repayment plan through the Student Aid Gov website, however, as time was of the essence and making sure that a did not default on my student loan, I thought it best to also contact NAVIENT to make sure that they are aware of my unemployment status and confirm that my IDR repayment plan was adjusted accordingly to reflect XXXX income. 

I was connected to whom I believed to be a NAVIENT representative, and explained my change of income circumstances. This individual proceeded to tell me that I needed to pay USD XXXX in order to change my IDR repayment plan so that my payments would go to XXXX. I responded by saying that in the over 25 years of this outstanding student loan that I have never been required to pay a fee to amend my IDR repayment plan. He responded by saying that then there was no guarantee that my IDR repayment would be adjusted to my current income of XXXX. I then requested to speak to a supervisor, and after waiting for almost an hour to no avail, I discontinued the call. 

Thinking that perhaps this NAVIENT representative was mistaken, I immediately called NAVIENT customer service again to speak to a different representative. I was connected to XXXX XXXX, whom I believed was a NAVIENT representative. At no time, during our conversation, did XXXX XXXX identify himself as a third party broker, or state that NAVIENT redirected my call to a third party broker. Again, I informed XXXX XXXX of my unemployment status and that I wanted to adjust my current IDR repayment plan as I would not be able to make the payments. I, also, told XXXX XXXX about my encounter with the previous representative who asked for an upfront payment to adjust my IDR repayment plan. As XXXX XXXX had access to all of my NAVIENT account information, and spoke with authority about my student loan, hence, I assumed XXXX XXXX was a legitimate NAVIENT representative. XXXX XXXX proceeded to tell me that the previous representative did not provide an adequate explanation. And so, with more XXXX salesmanship insisted that I should enter into student loan forgiveness as my loan was over XXXX XXXX XXXX and should have been forgiven a long time ago, and that he was the best person to do this as he has XXXX years of experience. Next, he proceeded to say that I needed to make an upfront payment towards my student loan in the amount of USD XXXX, in order to start this process, and that there was an urgency to do this in order to meet the XX/XX/year> deadline. Thus, I explained to him that I was unemployed and what little savings I had was crucial to my survival until I could find employment. XXXX XXXX persisted that this was the best option and he was advocating in my interest to alleviate my concerns about my student loan repayment. Thus, with much reluctance and dismay taking XXXX XXXX at his word as well as believing that the USD XXXX would go towards my student loan payments for XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year> so that in XX/XX/year> when the U.S. Department of Education determines who qualifies for student loan forgiveness, I would have completed all of the requirements for student loan forgiveness. Hence, I issued an electronic payment in the amount of USD XXXX through a XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXt XXXX XXXX sent to me via email. Once I completed the PSLF/TEPSLF form and submitted payment, XXXX XXXX instructed me to keep him informed of every correspondence so that he could monitor the student loan forgiveness proceedings. 

On XX/XX/year>, the USD XXXX posted to my checking account. However, when I checked my NAVIENT student loan account payment history, I did not see a record of the USD XXXX. I became concerned that this payment did not appear in my NAVIENT payment history. I contacted XXXX XXXX as to the whereabouts of this payment, and he said that it would appear in XXXX once my NAVIENT student loan was consolidated with the U.S. Department of Education. Once I received confirmation from XXXX of my NAVIENT student loan consolidation with the U.S. Department of Education, I created an account, and much to my dismay, there was not a record of the USD XXXX payment towards my student loan. Extremely distraught, I contacted an XXXX representative and shared the backstory of my student loan forgiveness as well as inquired about the missing USD XXXX payment. The XXXX representative kindly informed me that there is not an upfront payment to apply for student loan forgiveness. The XXXX representative grew concerned that I may have fallen victim to a scam. The XXXX representative escalated an investigation into the missing USD XXXX payment which is still ongoing as of this email correspondence. 

Following my many conversations with several XXXX representatives over several weeks, on XX/XX/year>, I, again, contacted XXXX XXXX, and inquired about the missing USD XXXX payment. Through his continuous deceptive tactics, he said that the USD XXXX payment was part of the consolidation amount and not to worry it was there. I pushed back saying that if this was true then there should be a written record with NAVIENT and XXXX with the USD XXXX reflected in the consolidation. XXXX XXXX continued to try to convince me otherwise. But, I was skeptical of his response. 

Distraught and distressed ever more so, on XX/XX/year>, I contacted XXXX again. I spoke with a representative named XXXX, who kindly reiterated that there is not an upfront payment for consideration by the U.S. Department of Education for student loan forgiveness and that this can be done by any individual for free. She advised that unbeknown to me that I could be dealing with a third party broker as third party brokers request a broker fee to process student loan forgiveness. I told her that I initiated this process through NAVIENT and at no time was I informed of working with a third party broker as I was led to believe that XXXX XXXX was an official NAVIENT representative. 

Desperate for the truth and concern that XXXX XXXX appropriated the USD XXXX for his own personal gain at my expense, I, again, called XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/year> and demanded answers about the whereabouts of the USD XXXX, and if he was in fact a third party broker and not a representative of NAVIENT. After many exchanges, XXXX XXXX finally admitted that he was indeed a third party broker explaining that NAVIENT redirects all student loan holders with loans over 20 years directly to third party brokers. Adding insult to injury, XXXX XXXX confessed that the USD XXXX was his broker fee to process and submit my student loan forgiveness application to the U.S. Department of Education.

Profoundly upset and in tears, I said to XXXX XXXX that both he and NAVIENT acted fraudulently forcing me to pay for something that I did not want to pursue in the first place- I contacted NAVIENT with the expressed desire to amend my IDR repayment plan, but instead, XXXX XXXX and NAVIENT had other nefarious intentions. I continued that XXXX XXXX knew that I was unemployed and needed that USD XXXX to pay my bills, keep a roof over my head and survive until I could find employment. I sobbed as I told XXXX XXXX that I was on the verge of losing my home and possessions, and that USD XXXX would be the necessary funds and the only life raft to my imminent survival. XXXX XXXX did not display any empathy, but stood firm in the belief that he did not do any wrong. 

At the conclusion of my conversation with XXXX XXXX, I demanded a refund of the USD XXXX to my account, immediately, along with a written correspondence confirming the refund. He said he would refund my USD XXXX and provide the requested written correspondence, however, with the caveat that he would withdraw my student loan forgiveness application with the U.S. Department of Education.

As of this email correspondence, on XX/XX/year>, I have received neither from XXXX XXXX. And given his duplicity, I do not expect XXXX XXXX to right this wrong and act in good faith. 

Over the last twenty-four hours, I have read countless media reports of NAVIENT 'S XXXX activities with the Federal Trade Commission , U.S. Senators as well as many state Attorney Generals efforts to hold NAVIENT accountable and provide some relief to its innocent victims. I am saddened that even the weight of these governing bodies can not prevent others, such as myself, from falling victim to the predatory student loan industry - An education should not inflict pain and suffering on those trying to build a life. 

As a result of the fraudulent actions of NAVIENT and XXXX XXXX and to prevent this from happening to other innocent student loan borrowers, in reporting this to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, it is my profound hope that you will pursue justice not only for myself, but more importantly, for all who continue to suffer irreparable harm at the hands of those whose self-interest is more important than the greater good. 

Thank you so very much for your kindness and guidance through this incredibly disheartening situation that has left me in a fog of despair. 

If you have additional questions, please contact me as I am happy to provide any additional information. 

With sincere appreciation, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I filed a complaint ( XXXX ) against Navient on XX/XX/24 related to my private student loans, and its response did absolutely nothing to resolve my complaint. 

Per Navient 's instructions in its response, I contacted its call center on XX/XX/24 to " reevaluate my options '' and was told, again, that there is no deferment or forbearance option available to me, even though I was laid off from my job in XXXX and currently have no income ( I have filed for unemployment benefits but have not received them yet ). I was told that the lowest, interest-only monthly payment available given my circumstances is {$610.00}, which is slightly higher than the payment of {$610.00} quoted in Navient 's response. 

Even if I get the maximum unemployment benefit of {$430.00} per week/ {$1700.00} per month ), it will not cover my housing expenses of {$2100.00} that includes mortgage payment and HOA fees, so paying over {$600.00} per month in student loans is obviously not doable right now. I also have a car payment, credit card bills, medical costs, and support my daughter as a XXXX parent. 

Navient 's refusal to assist me by temporarily lowering or eliminating my student loan payment following an unexpected loss of employment will also ruin my credit score when delinquent payments start getting reported to the credit bureaus at the end of this month, and this will negatively impact my financial situation and my ability to contribute to the local economy for years to come. I can only imagine how many others in a similar situation are out there, and how big of a collective impact these practices make. 

If needed, I will contact the Congressman representing my District ( XXXX XXXX ), as well as my Senators, state representative, and applicable state government agencies and federal/state advocacy organizations to ask for their help in resolving this issue. 

It should not be this difficult to get a temporary deferment or forbearance for a student loan during a time of extreme financial hardship.

I only received XXXX federal loan for the amount of {$3500.00} in which the balance was ultimately forgiven on XX/XX/XXXX due to the verdict of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX case which the court declared that all individuals who borrowed federal student loans to pay the cost of attendance for any of the XXXX persons named in the Massachusetts Attorney Generals exhibit have the right to borrower defense relief under XXXX C.F.R. XXXX ( c ) ( XXXX ) ( XXXX ) and not related to Then-Attorney General XXXX XXXX lawsuit against XXXX XXXX XXXX 

Unfortunately for me, I had XXXX other loans that were privately owned by Navient, the XXXX XXXX loan and the XXXX XXXX loan, both of which were subprime private loans. Despite the $ XXXX settlement on XX/XX/XXXX against Navient , I did not qualify for that forgiveness either as I was never late for at least seven continuous monthly billing cycles. 

For context, I originally borrowed a total of {$17000.00} which was disbursed in XXXX. From XXXX, I paid Navient a total of {$29000.00} and accrued {$29000.00} in interest. After my interest rate kept fluctuating and went up to 13 % on one loan and 14 % on another in XXXX, I decided to refinance the remaining balance of my loans for {$18000.00} the remaining balance on a {$17000.00} loan from 15 years ago. 

Summary : o Initially borrowed : {$17000.00} o Total payments received from XXXX = {$29000.00} o Total balance refinanced in XXXX = {$18000.00} o Out of pocket payment = {$47000.00} ( payments received + refinanced balance ) o {$29000.00} more than what was initially borrowed ALL interest. 

I have been negatively affected by this because I not only attended a predatory school but also received subprime loans that were designed to never allow me out of debt and despite governments efforts to forgive these loans, I never qualified for its forgiveness. These private loans deserve the same forgiveness as the federal loans because even after 17 years of repayment, I am still suffering from the grips of these harmful tactics by XXXX XXXX and Navient.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have never missed a payment and have been in good standing, despite staggering loan amounts and questionable forbearance practices by my lender that caused my loans to balloon well beyond their normal value. 

Going from 8.99 % to 15 % in a matter of a few months is ridiculous and also coincided with weekly mailers trying to urge me to use Navi-Refi . It seems like they jacked my rate as high as they could in an effort to get me to refi so they could cover their risks of canceling my loans. Had I met the default criteria, my loans would have been discharged as a part of the multi-state settlement from litigation over forbearance practices and other questionable behaviors.

All of this aside, I tried to go through the proper channels to get a rate reduction, but I was denied because that wasnt available at that time.

Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative: I am filing this complaint because I have reason to believe that a creditor called NAVIENT is retaliating against me for disputing 2 accounts bearing inaccurate and incomplete account information in my consumer reports through the consumer reporting agencies that they have furnished. Since I have been disputing over the course of 2 to 3 months to have them rectify the inaccurate and incomplete account information, this company has demanded full payment of loans I borrowed from them which amounts to {$19000.00} in which obviously I do not have to give in one bulk, and they are threatening to either sue, garnish my wages, and or take my income taxes. When this company was disputed initially, there was no comment on the account indicating that they had been disputed as seen on XXXX. I received the company 's threat via email and the date they wrote the notice was on XX/XX/year>. I am currently in default with the company, but I did intend to pay them back. I fell behind to financial hardship and I do not appreciate this company 's aggressive behavior. I was disputing inaccurate accounts reported on my consumer reports because I am trying to improve my life and my finances, and this company happened to be one of the companies that is currently furnishing inaccurate and false information in my consumer reports with all 3 of major consumer reporting agencies. It is prohibited by federally law for any creditor to retaliate against consumers for exercising their legal right to dispute any information they find to be inaccurate or incomplete in their consumer reports per the Fair Credit Reporting Act. It is our legal right as consumers. This company is in violation of 18 U.S. Code 894- Collection of extensions of credit by extortionate means- ( a ) Whoever knowingly participates in any way, or conspires to do so, in the use of any extortionate means ( 1 ) to collect or attempt to collect any extension of credit, or ( 2 ) to punish any person for the nonrepayment thereof, shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than 20 years, or both. I recently demanded XXXX to remove the accounts that came back verified while still be inaccurate and incomplete on XX/XX/year> after I disputed to have the accounts rectified. Soon after this notice was sent, I received a letter directly from NAVIENT via email threatening to sue. I am aware that an account being removed from a consumer report does not remove the obligation to pay the creditor, but NAVIENT 's approach is aggressive and unfair. It is plain bullying.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Incorrect information on your report
Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
The Internal Revenue Service ( IRS ) acknowledged the 1099-C form regarding Navient Corporation 's handling of a student loan on XX/XX/2024. Despite this, Navient has failed to respond to correspondence sent to corporate headquarters regarding the loan cancellation. Consequently, the company persistently attempts to collect the debt has reported adverse credit information, and has not updated the credit report to reflect paid in full. 

Navient Corporation 's actions are in violation of the following statutes : 15 U.S.C. 1666 ( b ) : Stipulates the timing of payments.

15 U.S.C. 1681 ( a ) : Outlines Congressional findings and the statement of purpose.

15 U.S.C. 1666 ( d ) : Governs the treatment of credit balances.

Additionally, Navient may is in contravention of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ) is a Federal law that protects the privacy of student education records. The law applies to all schools that receive funds under an applicable program of the U.S. Department of Education.

FERPA gives parents certain rights with respect to their children 's education records. These rights transfer to the student when he or she reaches the age of XXXX or attends a school beyond the high school level. Students to whom the rights have transferred are " eligible students. '' Parents or eligible students have the right to inspect and review the student 's education records maintained by the school. Schools are not required to provide copies of records unless, for reasons such as great distance, it is impossible for parents or eligible students to review the records. Schools may charge a fee for copies. 
Parents or eligible students have the right to request that a school correct records which they believe to be inaccurate or misleading. If the school decides not to amend the record, the parent or eligible student then has the right to a formal hearing. After the hearing, if the school still decides not to amend the record, the parent or eligible student has the right to place a statement with the record setting forth his or her view about the contested information. 
Generally, schools must have written permission from the parent or eligible student in order to release any information from a student 's education record. However, FERPA allows schools to disclose those records, without consent, to the following parties or under the following conditions ( 34 CFR 99.31 ) : School officials with legitimate educational interest ; Other schools to which a student is transferring ; Specified officials for audit or evaluation purposes ; Appropriate parties in connection with financial aid to a student ; Organizations conducting certain studies for or on behalf of the school ; Accrediting organizations ; To comply with a judicial order or lawfully issued subpoena ; Appropriate officials in cases of health and safety emergencies ; and State and local authorities, within a juvenile justice system, pursuant to specific State law. 

Schools may disclose, without consent, " directory '' information such as a student 's name, address, telephone number, date and place of birth, honors and awards, and dates of attendance. However, schools must tell parents and eligible students about directory information and allow parents and eligible students a reasonable amount of time to request that the school not disclose directory information about them. Schools must notify parents and eligible students annually of their rights under FERPA. The actual means of notification ( special letter, inclusion in a XXXX XXXX student handbook, or newspaper article ) is left to the discretion of each school. 

Furthermore, there are suspicions of securities fraud involving the presentation of unregistered securities on the secondary market and evading taxes. 

A forensic securitization audit is presently underway regarding this account.

Furthermore Navient used my open ended credit plan in accordance to 16 C.F.R. 433.2 ( a ) to furnish which furthermore proves they did not extend credit to me in regard to this alleged debt.

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 a states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' XXXX and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies and I am the Consumer. I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states '' It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' Navient is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. Navient never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option.

I have contacted the Department of Education multiple times and each time i am being told it is being worked on. This has been going on since i received the letter in XXXX of XXXX. 

I would like for the loans to be discharged as stated in the letter. While the discharge is occurring I would like for Navient to stop try to collect payments, and i would like all negative credit reporting removed from my Credit Report.

Looking for guidance and assistance as I feel that this is completely unfair to harass someone that has been making consistent payments for years, but once they have fallen a few payments behind due to hardship, theres no understanding or compromising with different options that can work for all parties. Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am a XXXX XXXX XXXX  class member, I was lucky enough to get a small subset of my loans for the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX forgiven as part of this settlement but, because of deceptive practices by the school and by Navient ( Previously Sallie Mae ) the majority of the student loans I borrowed are under Navient 's private loan category and I unfortunately have to deal with them all the time, I've been trying to work with them since XXXX and they have been very mean, aggressive and deceptive with their collection tactics and overall very non-transparent and hard to work with. To date I probably owe them more than what I originally borrowed because their only intent and goal in mind is to make profit out of me, they never offered to help me bring down my balance and instead would put me on plans, deferments, payment plans, etc. that ultimately ruined me, have me unable to purchase a reliable car to drive and scrapping by since my early XXXX, I am now XXXX XXXX XXXX and I, to date, still have very bad memories and experiences with Navient that tarnished my life in a negative way.

Navient ( And Sallie Mae ) have very poor customer service, it is hard to reach them over the phone, nearly impossible to get a representative over the phone unless they are calling to collect from you. Navient, in the past, has reached out to random people that I know to try and get a hold of me. In previous calls, Navient has had my cosigner on the line, listening in to my conversation with them as if trying to ambush me into a worse standing with my co-signer and attempt to collect money from me. Navient ( and Sallie Mae ) have collected payments from me and applied them poorly throughout my multiple loans with them. I vividly remember one year I was required to set up monthly payments, at least for XXXX  months in advance, I had to pay a fee too. After setting up the payments I continued to get harassing calls from them on a regular basis to the point where one time I spoke with a representative and told them I had a payment scheduled for that month ( XXXX ) and asked them to please stop harrassing me, my cosigner and anyone else they had on file as a contact. That same month of XXXX, Navient took out XXXX payments in the same month without my approval, back then, those payments were a very large percentage of my income and I unfortunately had to pay my rent late, borrow money from my mother and miss out on giving my family XXXX gifts. I had to speak with many people to get the duplicate, unauothrized payment refunded to my account, they attempted to deny the refund, they were mean and harrassed me multiple times.

All of the above is current, in the past, when I initially took out my loans, Navient mislead me and my cosigner into getting the majority of my loans as private signature loans that I later found out would benefit them and the school 's recruiter more, financially. It was very unfair because as private loans, I was awarded less rights as a consumer and was heavily targeted and harrassed by navient ( and sallie mae ) 's customer service departments.

Navient has poor transparency surrounding their fees, rates and repayment options. They would not tell me and still don't tell me, whenever they feel like increasing my interest rate. When I first took out the loans, my payments for the private signature loans were around {$450.00}, today, the are around {$650.00}. I don't even think I've been able to decrease my due amount from what I originally borrowed. Navient is a loan shark, they charge a lot of fees to set up payment plans, if you fall behind they are relentless and treated me like garbage. Many times I had a lot of financial hardship with making rent, paying for car repairs, hospital bills, etc. and Navient was very bad to work with on deferments, loan modifications, forbearance or income-driven repayment plans. One time, when I first bought my home I was going through economical hardships because we needed to do a home repair and that repair along with our mortgage amount put me in the negative. When I called customer service to attempt to set up a payment plan, deferment or some sort of financial relief they spent a long time with me on the phone, went over all of my expenses, clearly saw that at the end of month I was spending more money than what I was making and told me that my mortgage payment was a luxury, that I didn't have to buy my home and that it was my fault for buying a home and they would not be able to help me with any income-driven repayment plan or any sort of payment help or option what so ever. It was disgusting to speak with them, go through all of my personal expenses to at the end be told that because I decided to buy a home and better my life they could not help me out.

There was also a period of time where I was going through a lot of economical hardships that I wanted to go through a loan modification with them because the minimum payments I was making were not impacting my balance, they were very deceptive and never wanted to go through loan modifications with me, they would always steer me towards going on deferment until I completely wiped it out as an option, they never told me my options, I always had to plead to them to help me out and I would never get told what my options were.

I hope this is helpful so whomever reads this can be informed of the bad payment mismanagement, poor customer service, lack of transparency, deceptive practices and difficulty obtaining loan modifications that Navient puts people like me under.
