Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX was investigated into and, due to my attendance there, I have experience extreme hardship and even homelessness. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these for profit schools, such as The XXXX XXXX, I was able to file a XXXX XXXX claim with the Dept. of Education against The XXXX XXXX, and my Fed. loans of {$79000.00} were discharged and my credit repaired. 
My Borrower Defense Claim was not a part of the Sweet Vs. Cardona settlement but the settlement itself is worth noting to show the state of which the situation has become.

I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of XXXX payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. Senator Elizabeth Warren has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW! 
I have been through a lot of hardship due to these loans and was even told that mistakes were made on their end when my loan payments were misallocated which caused one of my loans to default and capitalized interest was applied. This situation put me in a downward spiral and after years of attempting to correct this, I was then coaxed into signing up for NaviRefi, now XXXX. This was also a sham as unnecessary interest was already applied. 
I have called and requested information and the application for discharge due to school misconduct. When I contacted Navient, I was given the usual runaround and redirected over 5 times before someone was able to answer any questions. I asked for the discharge application and was told that there is no such thing. After being redirected further I was then told that there was a document but they refused to send it to me and also refused any sort of reason why. I requested written forms of this denial and/or an email explaining but was again refused.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to request that my private loans I had taken out with Navient while attending XXXX XXXX XXXX be refunded to me. 

I attended XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX from XXXX for a total of just one year. I am a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and lacked the understanding and guidance of enrolling in college for the first time. When I decided to go to college I was interested in the fashion marketing degree at XXXX XXXX XXXX. From my first communication with them there was a lot of pressure to apply and get enrolled and start as early as possible. They pushed for me to start in the summer session right after college and the whole acceptance felt like it took minutes to go through. Looking back now the situation reminds me of when you go to buy a car and the sales people are pressuring you to drive off that day with a brand new car. In this case it was an expensive college degree. One area I was adamant about asking is the accreditation of the school and if I decided to transfer later if my credits were transferrable. They assured me they had the highest accreditation and any other school would accept their credits. When I transferred out a year later I found out this was not the case. I transferred to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  a year after starting at XXXX and they would not accepts any o the credits I had 'earned ' at XXXX. I knew I had made the right decision to leave after one year. 

During my enrollment process at XXXX they assisted me in their office with filling out all of the paperwork I need. This included my FAFSA and loan agreements. They asked me to sign them after they went over them without me going through myself and reviewing the documents. Later on when I had transferred I remember having to complete an educational guide on borrowing money for college which I did not go through when enrolling at Ai. In this guide it discussed subsidized and unsubsidized loans and repayment. I'm not sure if regulations had changed from XXXX to XXXX, but this may have made me stop and think and make a different decision. As I was enrolling they brought to my attention that the federal loans I would be receiving were not enough to cover the cost of the school. XXXX made it seem mandatory that we attend school year round for 4 quarters instead of two semesters like a traditional college. I learned later on that student aid only covers so much for the year and if you attend two semesters instead of year round more would be covered for that time frame. However, since they said there wasn't enough to cover tuition they said I should take out Private Loans to cover the difference and that this was common practice when people attend college. XXXX was the only college I had to take out private loans, when I transferred my student aid and federal loans was enough to cover my tuition. 

I had taken two private loans out in XXXX school term for a total of {$21000.00}, one with an interest rate of 11.25 % ( {$15000.00} disbursed on XX/XX/XXXX ) and the other 8.75 % ( {$6300.00} disbursed on XX/XX/XXXX ). Much like student loans I was not required to make payments while XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  however interest was still accruing. The total amount of interest the accrued while I was enrolled through the duration of my education was {$18000.00}. By the time I completed my XXXX XXXX XXXX  my private loans had ballooned to {$40000.00}. This is almost equal to the amount I borrowed for 4 years at a state school. 

It is clear looking back now that XXXX XXXX XXXX along with Navient took advantage of young adults who did not have experience or guidance in making these life decisions.

Without BDTR, I would have no hope of getting out from under the ballooning interest on my student loan debt.

A few years ago, Sallie Mae ( now Navient ) mishandled the consolidation of my student loans and therefore, as a result, the government revoked the " insured '' status of 1 of my loans -- in particular, a FFELP loan ( for approx. {$1800.00} ). 

All the rest of my student loans are held by XXXX and are in PSLF. 
But because of Navient 's fault, XXXX informs me that the Navient FFEL does not qualify for consolidation, because Navient lost its " insured '' status for this loan. 



Now I am contacting you, the CFPB, to ask if you could intervene for people like me who are being victimized by Navient. Through no fault of the borrower ( me ), Navient 's mishandling of my loan led to the loss of its " insured '' status, and depriving me of using PSLF. 



How many tens of thousands of other Navient loan holders are being similarly victimized, deprived of the ability to use PSLF because of Navient 's negligence and fraud, leading to the revocation of the " insured '' status of our loans? 



Please help us all by making all of these Navient " uninsured '' loans now qualify for inclusion in consolidations with XXXX and placed into the PSLF program. 



Many thanks!

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX I enrolled into XXXX XXXX XXXX under the understanding that when I finished school I would have a college education that would better my life. Consumer complaint narrative: I attended a for-profit scam school ( XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) . This for-profit scam school closed years ago, not too long after I graduated. I was misled with information by an admissions rep, and was promised job placement, work while I attended school, etc, etc. Believing this to be true, I enrolled and took out a loan with Sallie Mae, who was eventually turned over to Navient. Sallie Mae promised easy, affordable repayment. This was far from true! I have been paying on my loan for XXXX years, and my balance has only decreased {$3000.00}! I am post class with the XXXX vs XXXX case, as I have filed Borrowers Defense ( case # XXXX ) on my federal loan for this same school. My private loans should be discharged, because I took them out under circumstances that led me to believe I was getting the education promised to me. In reality, the school I attended was a fraud, and ended up closing. I have requested deferment or forbearance on my private loan but have been told for years that interest only payments is the only option. I recently became disabled, and told Navient I could no longer make the payments. They never provided me with any options. After doing some research on their website, I called back and requested a disability loan forgiveness application to be mailed to me. I never received this application, and they reported to the credit bureaus that I defaulted on my loan. I called back and they FINALLY offered me forbearance and said it would bring my account current, said they would mail me an application for XXXX loan forgiveness ( have not received it yet for the 2nd time ), but refused to remove the late payment from my credit report even though my account is current. I explained that in my entire credit history with ANY lender, I have NEVER been late on a payment ... .ever! My credit has always been over 800. Due to Navient 's lack of options and cooperation, my score dropped XXXX points!!! My daughter ( XXXX ) and I are in the middle of a move, and this massive drop in my credit is affecting my ability to secure housing. I am a single, solo mom trying to stay afloat and provide for myself and my daughter. This loan is literally ruining everything I worked so hard at maintaining. This private loan needs to be discharged, as I have been paying for XXXX years with only {$3000.00} movement which is a total scam by Navient. I also need my credit reinstated, as my account with Navient is current!

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, of XXXX I was approved for Borrower Defense for my Federal loan debt, the information about that event is as follows : -- Borrower Defense Application # : ( REDACTED, provided upon request ) Borrower Defense Application School : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( The ) Approval of Your Borrower Defense Case Under Exhibit C of the Sweet v. Cardona Settlement -- As my Federal debt was forgiven, and being as the Art Institutes have been found to be have defrauded students by the PA Attorney General ( see : XXXX : XXXX ) I am writing to complain about my repayment of my private debt. 

In XXXX of XXXX, I consolidated my private debt, originally with Navient, to XXXX XXXX This was done to remove my brother as a cosigner and to lower the monthly fee as they would not otherwise remove the cosigner. That information is at the bottom of this document, but it can be expounded upon by request. 

Some background information : I had no intention, originally, of obtaining private loan debt. During my time studying at XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Online / XXXX ) I was told that Federal loans ( FFELP/Creative Plus? ) would no longer cover my tuition. As such, I was advised to supplement with private loans which were provided through Navient ( SallieMae. ) I had little option at that time, having sunk thousands of dollars of cost and years into a degree I could no longer afford. I obtained a cosigner and begrudgingly went forward. 

I applied and was given the private loans and finished my degree, albeit in massive debt now mixed Federal and Private. This was always a burden but I made 100 % on-time payments despite that fact. That is until I learned about the DOJ fining the XXXX for {$95.00} XXXX dollars in XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ). This gave me pause because my school was owned and managed by the XXXX. I applied for defense to repayment, and my application was in limbo for a long time. On XX/XX/XXXX I was denied by the XXXX administration of the DoE. Eventually, due to the efforts of XXXX XXXX and some excellent attorneys, I was able to obtain full forgiveness on my federal debt in XXXX, as mentioned above, when the lawsuit was successfully won. A suit that was defended successfully against appeal, over and over again before being finalized. 

Which brings me to today, where I am currently saddled with private debt, consolidated from my original lender, for a degree that has been defamed and trounced upon by the shadow of illegitimacy cast by these settlements and forgiveness. My school is now the punchline of a joke I can't laugh at, indeed I am hesitant to even mention what school I attended at this point, so my degree is a byline of nothing more than past expensive mistakes. 

While I have no qualms about paying back debt for products rendered in fair exchange, this is clearly not such an exchange. The school was found to be culpable in profiting off the backs of students like myself who foolishly sought out unique educational opportunities only to be pressed under the wheel of profiteering gluttony. This has caused the all too common problem of delayed entry into home ownership, slowed progress in all areas of life, and stress and strain in addition to the diminishment of our achievement by the aforementioned shadow of shame now staining our degrees. 

I vehemently dispute that I should have to pay these private loans back, and I would humbly request the remaining debt be cancelled and a refund issued for any funds paid. This won't make up fully for being defrauded of tens of thousands of dollars, nor the over two decades of my life spent in debt, the loss of my degree 's legitimacy, nor the distrust I have for all the involved institutions, but it certainly would be a step in the correct, fair direction. 

-- Navient Loans : Loan data from navient : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX consolidation loans : Current Repayment Plan : Level Monthly Payment Amount : {$400.00} Payments Required : XXXX Maturity Date : XX/XX/XXXX Principal Balance Disclosed : {$47000.00} Date Loan Disclosed : XX/XX/XXXX CURRENT balance : Principal Balance : {$18000.00} Accrued Interest as of XX/XX/XXXX : {$45.00} Payoff Amount : {$18000.00}

Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX XXXX  from XXXX and took out private student loans with XXXX XXXX , and those loans were transferred to Navient in late 2014. I made payments on these loans from the time of my graduation until they were paid off in XXXX. XXXX has been acknowledged by the Department of Education as having engaged in misconduct in recruiting prospective students by claiming higher than actual job placement rates for graduates. I was one of the students that was led to apply in part due to these job placement rates, and I graduated from XXXX in XXXX. I experienced first-hand the lack of jobs available after my graduation and felt taken advantage of by the University. 

I am a class member of the XXXX vs. XXXX lawsuit where the Department of Education has settled with the class offering federal loan forgiveness and refunds of payments made. That process is ongoing. 

I have recently been made aware of a pilot program for school misconduct discharge for private loans by Navient. This program would not only discharge any private loan balance from a school that has engaged in misconduct, but also refund any payments made to Navient on these loans. I called Navient to inquire about this program, and was told that since my loans are at a zero balance, this was not something I was eligible for. 

Given that I attended a school that has been acknowledged by the government to have engaged in misconduct, I should not be penalized or excluded from this program due to having done the right thing and paid off my loans. I should still be eligible for an application, and I believe, a full refund of payments made on these loans. I humbly request that Navient be compelled to provide me with an application for this program. Thank you. 

The attachments to this complaint include the XXXX  XXXX XXXX settlement agreement where XXXX XXXX is listed in Exhibit C as having engaged in misconduct worthy of having my federal loans forgiven and refunded, as well as an email I received from the Department of Education documenting my status as a certified class member entitled for relief as defined by the settlement agreement.

After medical school, I did not get an MD residency ( I passed all my tests, etc., but I just didn't get it due to to many medical students and not enough residency positions ), so I transitioned to public health. I started my public health service in XXXX, and it wasn't until XXXX that XXXX informed me about the XXXX program as an option. Because of the late transfer, I missed several monthly payments that weren't counted for XXXX, and it delayed my XXXX for 1 year.Also, aAs my federal student loans were more, I focused on them with XXXX. For my private student loans, whatever income I had outside XXXX 's narrow criteria ( home, gas, car, utilities, food ), went to my private student loans based on my income. When I couldn't make a payment, they would put me into deferment, paying the missed payments in higher percentages. I also never consolidated because I would lose any original protections for income-based repayments. missed it because of the birth of my children ( XXXX during XXXX ), an a/c unit going out, food/childcare, and the car being stolen. On average, I paid between {$XXXX and {$XXXX} a month for my private loans. My original private student loans were $ XXXX, and after 12 years ( 2 years in deferment for my XXXX XXXX XXXX ), I owed {$XXXX}. So I paid $ XXXX over the 10 years and owed {$XXXX  more. After the XXXX XXXXwsuit, I spoke with XXXX, and they said I did not qualify because I had never defaulted. Because I did the right thing and made payments, I was penalized. I contacted my XXXX senate & congress representatives and XXXX XXXXttorney General, and all said there was nothing they could do, and they couldn't comment on litigation or the XXXX lawsuit. So, in XXXX, I stopped paying because, by XXXX  's criteria, defaulting was the correct financial method. For the next 5 months, XXXX  called, emailed, and faxed everyone from an ex-bother-in-law to my new employer. Only because of my mother ( co-signer ) did I finally re-engage with XXXX. They offered to negotiate a settlement, which after weeks of back and forth, came to {$XXXX0} ( a total of {$XXXX to the $ XXXX I had already paid ). In order to find that money, I pulled out my XXXX retirement, which was an inheritance from my grandmother, paid the federal penalties and taxes, and emptied my emergency XXXX savings that had taken me 10 years to accumulate. I settled with XXXX  ( loans show balance of {$XXXX} and that they have been consolidated ) and have been living paycheck to paycheck, making significant sacrifices for my family just to not live under a private student loan debt that had no end for me based on my public health career salary. Through the years, the private student loan crippled me for any financial progress, from being able to mortgage a house or start a small business.

The estimated payoff date for both of these loans is in XXXX.

They used scare tactics as well as other means of harassment to get me to agree to various repayment terms. Eventually I was scared into an extended repayment plan which the company has profited from greatly due to the ridiculous amount of interest that has been paid and will continue to need paid.

o pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? n access to the applicati

on even though this is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. nts to enroll.

Not only was my school a scam school it also has lawsuits against it. I also should not be paying these high interest rates. I am furious

Issue: Communication tactics
Sub-issue: You told them to stop contacting you, but they keep trying
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am a student loan borrower with Navient, and I make my payments on time every month with no outstanding balance. 
However, Navient has called me on 3 separate occasions trying to locate another borrower who is in no way associated with my account. ( I have Navient in my contact list and they appear on my caller ID as being from Navient. ) I told them the first time not to contact me about other people 's accounts. They said " Okay '' and we hung up. The second time they called me about the same account, and I advised them not to contact me unless it was specifically about my account, at which point the caller from Navient said " What account are you talking about? '' I told them not to call me again and we hung up. The third time they called I again advised them not to call me regarding this person 's account and hung up. I have other friends who are being contacted by Navient about this person 's account who also have no connection with the Navient account in question, and I will be advising them to also file complaints with the FTC.

There is no way they could report me as late at the time. I have never been late on payments for the accounts. Please investigate and provide proof with statements showing that these payments were late. If proof can't be provided, I demand these payments be updated to " OK '' on time as they should be due to the fact that I was never late.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I attended from XXXX. As a matter of fact, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, was investigated by XXXX for XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. It is a part of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Lawsuit. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these online for profit schools, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Other students were able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, and their Fed. loans were discharged and credit repaired. 
My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX settlement for which I was a full class member. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit online schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to submit a Borrower Defense to Repayment application regarding the federal student loans I obtained to finance my education at the XXXX XXXX, a subsidiary of the now-defunct XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

I enrolled at the XXXX XXXX in XXXX with the expectation that I would receive a quality education and that the programs offered would lead to meaningful employment opportunities upon graduation. However, my experience at XXXX XXXX XXXX was marred by deceptive practices that misled me and other students about the true value of the education we were receiving. 

The XXXX XXXX engaged in deceptive practices, including but not limited to : Inflating Job Placement Rates : XXXX XXXX XXXX misrepresented its job placement rates, leading students to believe that a higher percentage of graduates secured employment in their field of study than was actually the case. These inflated statistics were a significant factor in my decision to enroll in the program. 

Misrepresenting Program Value : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX misrepresented the value of its programs by exaggerating the skills and knowledge students would acquire and the earning potential upon graduation. These misrepresentations induced me to take on significant student loan debt to finance my education. 

In my final year, they advised they had a new loan product, the signature private student loan ( formerly through Sallie Mae ) which would allow me to complete the remainder of my classes and graduate on time based on their initial trajectory. 

As a result of the XXXX XXXX 's deceptive practices, I have incurred substantial financial hardship, and the education I received has not provided the promised benefits. I am now struggling to repay my student loans while not even being able to land a job in my field of study that could even support the payback amounts.

Consumer complaint narrative: I notified Navient a year ago that I was part of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and they haven't been giving me accurate information about how to discharge the loan under the Holder Rule. They have been collecting payments on these loans while violating the Fair Debt Collections Act while giving me bad information, collecting on a debt they aren't legally allowed to and giving the false impression that I need to give them more information on top of what I already gave them in the form of a 12-13 page application. They are miscontruing the statements of the Federal Government to lie about statements given about the Insitutional Misconduct that was reported on and in an attempt to continue collecting on the debt or delay to where the company can transfer the contract to another company.

Issue: Getting a loan
Sub-issue: Confusing or misleading advertising
Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX for an XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  couldnt finish due to no financial aid remaining ). Recruitment tactics included misleading job placement rates. When finishing my associates portion of the degree, the career services offered applying to retail stores as a career. The only job I could get out of school was a XXXX XXXX  that didnt require a degree, of which many graduates worked at. 

I have been making semi consistent payments on my loans for $ XXXX a month for almost 10 years, and now I owe almost double what I borrowed. Ive come close to defaulting at least 3 times, and have had to return to a state school to get a degree in a totally unrelated field in order to afford my loan payments. 

the XXXX  has since been sued for fraud, shut down and parent company has closed. Navient settled to discharge loans of students in my exact circumstances but had defaulted- and I am stuck now with {$72000.00} in private loans from an associates with an unfinished XXXX degree.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended the XXXX XXXX under the XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) from XXXX to XXXX. Like many other students, I was misled into securing predatory private loans for this " education. '' My original principal loan amount on my private loans was {$85000.00}. Despite making regular payments on these loans over the last 15 years, my current balance is {$110000.00}. This is due to exorbitant interest rates ranging from 13.5 % to 19 %. To date, I have paid more than {$150000.00} toward these loans. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX  and its parent company, XXXX, were subject to investigations by various state attorney generals and were found to have engaged in deceptive and predatory recruitment practices. In response to these widespread allegations of fraud and misconduct, the Biden Administration recently announced a comprehensive loan discharge for students enrolled at these for-profit scam schools from XX/XX/XXXX, to XX/XX/XXXX. This led to the discharge of my federal loans. 

Navient, which the attorney generals of XXXX states sued for its role in facilitating these predatory private loans, had an arrangement with for-profit schools during the early XXXX, making it a " preferred '' lender. Despite this lawsuit, the settlement terms provided by Navient were inadequate, as it excluded many borrowers who were coerced into taking these loans to attend for-profit scam schools like XXXX XXXX XXXX  unless they resided in certain states or had not defaulted for at least seven months during a specified period.

The only period during which I could reduce the principal amount on my loans was during the pandemic when interest rates were lowered to between 0.5 % and 1 %. However, once the regular interest rates resumed, my balances quickly accelerated. This financial strain has led me to forgo health procedures, home ownership, and having a child.

Navient has also faced multiple lawsuits for other predatory lending and illegal collection practices. Navient is currently distributing " applications '' to select students who may qualify for Borrower Defense claims against their schools. However, this process feels intentionally opaque and unnecessary, as Navient knows about the school misconduct and the affected students. I am unable to receive any information as far as eligibility, and the only information I do have is from leaked copies of the School Misconduct Discharge application. Based on these copies, the application requires excessive documentation like correspondence from the school, marketing materials, advertisements, course catalogs, manuals, and school web messaging from loans that are over a decade old. Since then, XXXX  XXXX XXXX has lost its accreditation and closed. The application also threatens borrowers with perjury for providing incomplete information.

Despite this, I requested an application and was told, " If it is determined you are eligible for further review, in the coming weeks we will mail you an application to submit a claim. '' Again, I do not understand the need for this process or its lack of transparency.

To make matters worse, with the recent news that Navient is exiting the federal student loan servicing business amidst legislative and advocacy scrutiny following allegations of steering borrowers away from income-driven repayment plans towards forbearance, I am concerned that the application process for a discharge based on school misconduct is an attempt to defer action until MOHELA takes control of their loans.

Under the FTC 's " Holder Rule, '' Navient is accountable for these predatory loan issues associated with for-profit scam schools. As time is critical, Senator XXXX XXXX has urged Navient 's CEO to discharge these loans immediately. As she stated in her letter, " Given XXXX  failure to follow guidance on canceling predatory federal loans, it is hard to believe that it will behave any better in canceling similar private loans Navient will transfer to them. '' Navient must be held accountable and take responsible action by discharging all such predatory private loans associated with for-profit " education. ''

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I took at a private loan for XXXX XXXX XXXX  ( XXXX ) in XXXX. I have been making payments on weekly, bi-weekly and monthly intervals depending on pay scales. I have over paid my monthly payment in an effort to pay it off sooner. However, I feel like I'm in a never ending cycle. XXXX is listed in the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX lawsuit as a predatory school. Navient has been the subject of so many lawsuits that I don't know how they are still in business. The very first private loan that I received is the only outstanding private loan I have left. XXXX promised help in finding a job after XXXX, that never happened. I couldn't even find a position as a XXXX XXXX XXXX because the programs used at XXXX were out dated before I even XXXX. The original program cost roughly {$32000.00} and the enrollment/financial ad staff instructed me to apply for Federal and private loans that covered the cost of the program. All told, I borrowed {$63000.00} for {$32000.00} program. I was a first time borrower and honestly relied on the school staff to direct me. That was a huge mistake. Now fast forward XXXX  years and the every first Sallie Mae Signature loan for {$8400.00} still has a balance of {$6900.00}. This loan had a co-signed, my father-in-law. He passed in XXXX of XXXX. I reached out to Navient and provided the death certificate asking that he be removed as the cosigner. It was my understanding that he was, but now when I get phone calls on the remaining the amount, I'm asked about my co-signer. I don't know how many times I can tell them that he died. XXXX has been the subject of I don't know how many settlements, but I never saw anything. When I ask, I get told I don't qualify, but can't get an explanation of why I don't qualify. Navient was recently sued by multiple state Attorney Generals. I got {$500.00} and didn't qualify for complete relief because I was XXXX enough to pay on my loans. I never went delinquent for 7 months consecutively. XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX has found in favor of the borrower. The fact that Federal Loans are being forgiven and refunded for the same XXXX  I attended should provide some kind of legal precedence to have my loan discharged and refunded. I do not owe the remaining {$6900.00}, I have been paying and paying and paying and the term of my loan never decreases. I was placed in forbearance or deferment by Navient when I shouldn't have been. They obviously did not place them on the oldest loans first. Why else would private loans from XXXX, XXXX ect be paid off but this one is not.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I submitted a school misconduct application for my private student loans for XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX noting, the XXXX administration has proven that this school and its parent company engaged in misconduct that led me and thousands of other students to enroll without the proper recourse and under false pretences. The department of education has cancelled all federal student loans for this school and its parent company because of the previously mentioned, proven misconduct. 

When I reached out to Navient about this matter in a separate complaint they stated they were piloting a program that would behave similarly to the process of dismissal for federal student loans that i've worked on in the past for this school. 

I completed a thorough document they mailed to me as well as provided documentation and back up, I took this application as serious of a matter as the XXXX application, provided almost the same exact answers to each question they asked, the federal application was approved months ago but Navient denied mine in XXXX and did not provide a reason for the denial. 

Navient knows this school has been proven to have engaged in misconduct and should dismiss my student loans without the need for me to fill out a very long and complicated document that has no clear indication from Navient as to what the requirements are, how they determine if XXXX is or is not eligible for this dismissal or not. 

It is unfair and unethical of Navient to know that misconduct has been proven for this school but denied my application for dismissal. 

Navient 's document was long, confusing, had very little room to fill out question and in certain places was very misleading. When it came to attaching supporting documentation I attached a lot of relevant and important information such as court cases, articles published by the department of education and images from the school 's website from that time period. 

Navient is not acting in good faith by having denied my school misconduct application and needs to provide a valid reason why they denied it. 

Note, supporting documentation should also not be needed if the very own Department of Education has proven that XXXX XXXX preyed on people trying to better their lives and set them up for failure. 


XXXX XXXX XXXX
